superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter v v
The fourth letter of the alphabet: called vaMCN and vaA [respecting which latter see the letter b]: the pl. [of the former] is vaMCaAtN; and [of the latter,] OavowaMCN and OavoyaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllRynp.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed livawiyRap [or gingival], which are v and c and Z. (TA at the commencement of f.) ― -b2- It is sometimes substituted for f as in the instance of HuvaAlapN and HufaAlapN; and for s as in the instance of juvomaAnN and jusomaAnN; and for other letters. (TA in the latter place.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Five hundred.]

vaA vA vAC
vaA and vaMCN: see the letter v, and arts. vwO and vI.

R. Q. 1 vaOovaOa c
R. Q. 1. vaOovaOa He watered camels to their satisfaction: (S, M, K; but in some copies of the S, the verb is made trans. by means of bi:) or he watered them (T, M) so as to quench their thirst, (T,) but not so as to satisfy them. (T, M.) ― -b2- Also, contr., He kept camels thirsty; i. e. he did not water them at all; or he watered them little, so that they were not satisfied. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He extinguished fire. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- He stilled another's anger. (TA.) And vaOovaOa Eanohu gaDabahu He quenched his anger. (M.) [Or this may be rendered He dispelled from him his anger: agreeably with what follows.] ― -b5- He removed (IDrd, M, K) a thing (M) from its place. (IDrd, M, K.) ― -b6- vaOovaOa Eani Alqawomi He repelled from, or defended, the people, or company of men, (As, S, K,) and rendered them reciprocal aid. (As, TA.) ― -b7- vaOovaOa, (T, M, K,) inf. n. vaOovaOapN, (T,) also signifies He restrained, or withheld, (T, M, K,) a man (T, M,) from (Eano) another man, (T,) or from (Eano) a thing, or an affair. (M.) ＝ -A2- vaOovaOati AlUibilu The camels drank to their satisfaction: (M, K:) or drank, but not so as to satisfy themselves. (M.) ― -b2- And, contr., The camels thirsted. (K.) ― -b3- And vaOovaOa It became stilled; (K;) said of anger. (TA.) ― -b4- See also R. Q. 2. ＝ -A3- vaOotaOa biAltRayosi, (AA, AZ, M, K,) inf. n. vaOovaMCN, (K,) like taOotaMCN, (TA,) He called the he-goat (AA, AZ, M, K) to copulate. (AA, K.)

R. Q. 2 tavaOovaOa c
R. Q. 2. tavaOovaOa He deemed it right that he should abide, or remain, where he was, (AZ, T, K,) and abstain, (AZ, TA,) after he had desired to make a journey (AZ, T, K) to a country, or land. (AZ, TA.) And tvO Eani AlOamori, (M,) or Eani vOvO↓ AlXRaIoCi, (TA,) He deemed it right that he should abstain from the affair, or thing, (M, TA,) or that he should pause at it, (M,) after he had desired it. (M, TA.) ― -b2- laqiytu fulaAnFA fatavaOovaOotu minohu I met such a one, and feared him. (As, S, K. *)

1 vuYiba c
1. vuYiba, ('Eyn, T, M, K,) like EuniIa, (K,) and vaYiba, (IKoot, L, and so in a copy of the A,) inf. n. vaOobN, (K,) or vaOabN, (M,) He became relaxed and sluggish; said of a man: (A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor; (M;) as also tvMCb↓: (M, A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness; as also tvMCb↓ and tvORb↓; (K;) which last is approved by IDrd and Thábit Es-Sara- kustee, who disallow tvMCb↓, though this is the form commonly known and approved, and is the most chaste form: (TA:) or he became affected with languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that he had eaten or drunk, without becoming insensible; (T;) as also tvMCb↓: (L:) or ↓this last signifies he yawned, or opened his mouth, (Mgh, Msb,) by reason, (Mgh,) or on the occasion, (Msb,) of languor (Mgh, Msb,) like the heaviness of drowsiness; (Mgh;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and stretched himself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety; (MF, TA, on the authority of IDrst;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and emitted wind from his stomach, by reason of some affection thereof: (TA on the authority of EtTedmuree:) AltRavaAWubu is from AlvRuWabaMCu; (AZ, T, S, Mgh;) and is on the occasion of one's stretching himself, and being languid: (Lth, T:) one should not say tavaAwaba; (AZ, T, S, O, Mgh;) [for] this is vulgar. (Msb.) Hence, OaHadukumo faloyugaTRi UicaA tavaOaCaba↓ faAhu [When any one of you yawns, he should cover his mouth with the back of his left hand; for it is believed that the devil leaps into the uncovered yawning mouth]. (Mgh.)

5 tavaARa^a
5: see 1.

6 tavaARa^a
6: see 1, in six places.

vuWabaMCu c
vuWabaMCu, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) as also vuWobaMC, accord. to Ibn-Mis-hal, but this is strange, (TA,) is a subst. derived from AltRavaAWubu, like muTuwaMCu from AltRamaTRiI; (T;) or from vaYiba; and means A state of relaxation and sluggishness: (A:) or sluggishness and languor (M, K) like the languor of drowsiness: (K:) or languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that one has eaten or drunk, not attended by insensibility: (T, L:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, by reason of languor like the heaviness of drowsiness: (Mgh:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and stretching oneself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety: (IDrst, MF, TA:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and emitting wind from the stomach, by reason of some affection thereof. (Et-Tedmuree, TA.) Hence the prov., OaEodaI mina AlvRuWabaMCi, (S, A, TA,) and [AlvRuwabaMCi,] without C, as some say; (MF;) or the pronunciation without C is vulgar, (IDrst, TA,) or erroneous; (TA;) [More catching than yawning;] for when a man yawns ( AcA tvACb ) in the presence of others, they become affected as he is. (TA.)

mavoWuwbN c
mavoWuwbN Affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness: from vuYiba, q. v. (K.)

1 vaOarahu c
1. vaOarahu, (T, S, Msb,) and vaOara bihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K) aor.
vaAa^a
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. vaOorN and vuWorapN, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., as is also vuWuwrapN, (Lh, M, K,) He revenged, or avenged, his blood, by retaliating his slaughter; he slew his slayer. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) [Hence, vuYira maqotuwluhu and bimaqotuwlihi The blood of his slain relation was revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter: see 10.] ― -b2- [Hence also,] laA vaOarato fulaAnFA yadaAhu, (K,) or EalaI fulaAnK, (A,) (tropical:) May his arms, or hands, not profit such a one. (A, K.) ― -b3- Also vaOarahu, and vaOara bihi, (M, K,) and vaOara Alqawoma, inf. n. vaOorN, (T,) He sought to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, (T, M, K,) his blood, (M, K,) and the blood of the people, or party. (T.) It is said in a prov., laA yanaAmu mano vaOara [He will not sleep who seeks to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood]: in the Kámil of Mbr, [and in some copies of Meyd,] mani QvRaOari↓ [which seems to signify the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- [And vaOarahu and vaOara bihi signify also He slew him in blood-revenge, or in retaliation of the blood of a relation: see mavoWuwrN.] ― -b5- vaOarotuka bikacaA I have obtained my bloodrevenge, or retaliation, of thee by such [a deed, or person]. (S, K.)

4 OavoAa^a
4: see 8.

8 AivRaOara c
8. AivRaOara originally AivotaOara He obtained his bloodrevenge, or retaliation; syn. Oadorak vaOorahu; (T, S, M, K;) minohu from him; (T, S;) as also OavoOara↓: (M, K:) and AivRaOara minohu he slew the slayer of his relation. (T.) Lebeed says,
waAlnRiybu Uino taEoru minRiI rimRapF xalaqFA *
baEoda AlmamaAti faUinRiI kunotu OavRaYiru *
[And the old she-camels, if they seek to obtain benefit from a worn rotten bone of me after death, I used to retaliate upon them by anticipation]: (T, S:) i. e., I used to slaughter [some of] them for guests, and so I have retaliated upon them during my life for their nibbling my rotten bones
after my death: for when camels do not find herbage of the kind called HamoD, they eat the bones of dead men and of camels instead thereof. (T.) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 AstvOr c
10. AstvOr He (a relation of a slain man, A) sought, or asked, aid, in order that the blood of his slain [relation] might be revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter (luyivoOara bimaqotuwlihi), (AZ, S, K,) or in order that he might take, or seek, revenge, or vengeance, for his slain [relation]. (A.)

vaOorN c
vaOorN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) which may be also pronounced vaArN, i. e., with the C suppressed, (Msb,) and vaOorapN↓, (A,) and vuWorapN↓, (S,) which last is a subst. [from vaOara], as also vuWuwrapN↓, (Lh, M, K,) Blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide: or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood: [see 1, of which vaOorN is an inf. n.:] or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it: syn. caHolN: (S, A, Msb:) or Talaba biAldRami: (M, K:) or HiqodN: (Mgh:) or (so accord. to the M; but accord. to the K, “ and ”) blood (M, K) itself: (M:) pl. OavoMrN and MvaArN; the latter formed by transposition. (Yaakoob, M.) You say, Oadoraka vaOorahu (S, Mgh, K) and vuWoratahu↓ (As, T, S) [He obtained, or attained, or took, his bloodrevenge, or retaliation: or] he attained the object of his pursuit [for blood-revenge, or retaliation]; from vaOarahu: (As, T:) or he slew the slayer of his relation. (Mgh.) And Talaba bivaOorihi He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; syn. Talaba bicaHolihi. (S and Msb in art. cHl.) And OanaA OaTolubu vaOoriI Einodahu I seek my blood-revenge of him; syn. caHoliI. (A.) And vaOoriI Einoda fulaAnK My blood-revenge is a debt owed to me by such a one; syn. caHoliI: meaning such a one is the slayer of my relation. (A.) ＝ -A2- vaOorN also signifies, (A,) or vaAYirN↓, (T,) One who seeks blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of his relation: and one of whom is sought blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of a relation: (T, A:) the latter primarily signifies a slayer; and hence, a slayer of a person's relation in vengeance, or retribution: (Ham p. 637:) and the former, one who is sought, or pursued, for blood-revenge; an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Ham p. 87:) the slayer of a person's relation; (S, M, A, K;) as also vaAYirN↓: (A:) pl. of the former OavoMrN and MvaArN [as above] (K) and vaOoraAtN: (S, A, K:) the first of which three is [also] pl. of vaAYirN. (T.) You say, huwa vaOoruhu He is the slayer of his relation. (S.) And yaA vaOoraAti fulaAnK O slayers of such a one. (T, S, K.) yaA vaOoraAti EuvomaAna, occurring in a trad., which is also related with the substitution of taAraAt for vOrAt, may be explained in the same manner; or it may mean O ye seekers of the blood-revenge of 'Othmán, aid me to obtain it; the prefixed noun TaAlibiI, or Oahol, being understood. (Nh, TA. [See also taArapN in art. twr.]) vaOorN muniymN [A slayer of one's relation who causes his slayer to sleep,] means one with whom the seeker [of blood-revenge or retaliation] is contented, if he find him [and slay him], so that he sleeps after; (S, K;) one who, if slain, causes the pursuer of blood-revenge to cease from the pursuit: (Ham p. 87:) or a person who is an equivalent for the blood of one's relation [and who therefore, by his being slain in retaliation, makes the avenger to sleep]: (T:) or a person of rank, or note, in whom [i. e. by the slaughter of whom] one has his full desire accomplished. (A.) In a trad. of Mohammad Ibn-Selemeh, relating to the day of Kheyber, occur the words, OanaA lahu yaA rasuwlu QllRehi Almawotuwru lilvRaAYiri↓, meaning [I am for him, i. e. I am he who should slay him, O Apostle of God:] the seeker of blood-revenge [is for him of whom blood-revenge is sought]. (L. [The explanation there given is clearly shown to relate to Almwtwr.]) ― -b2- vaOorN signifies also An enemy: pl. OavoMrN: so explained as occurring in the following words of a trad.; laA tugomiduwA suyuwfakumo Eano OaHodaAvikumo fatuwtiruwA OavoMrakumo Do not sheathe your swords from your young ones, [neglecting to teach them the use thereof,] and so make your enemies to attain their desire of blood-revenge. (TA.)

vaOorapN c
vaOorapN: see vaOorN.

vuWorapN c
vuWorapN; said in the S to be an inf. n. of 1: see vaOorN, in two places.

vuWuwrapN c
vuWuwrapN: see vaOorN.

vaAYirN c
vaAYirN: see vaOorN, in three places. ― -b2- Also One who does not pity anything (laA yuboqiI EalaI XaIoCK) so that he may obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation. (S, K.)

mavoWuwrN c
mavoWuwrN and mavoWuwrN bihi [Revenged, or avenged, by the retaliation of his slaughter; by the slaughter of his slayer: and also slain in blood-revenge, or in retaliation for the blood of a relation of the slayer]: these two expressions [thus] apply to one's enemy as well as to one's relation. (A.) ― -b2- Also, the latter, [simply,] Slain. (T, and Ham p. 87. [But retaliation is generally meant to be understood.])

Q. Q. 1 vuWolila c
Q. Q. 1. vuWolila He (a man, M, Mgh) had vaMliyl [i. e. warts] come forth upon him. (M, Mgh, K.)

Q. Q. 2 tavaOolala jasaduhu c
Q. Q. 2. tavaOolala jasaduhu (T, M, K) biAlvRaMliyli (T, TA) His person had vaMliyl [or warts] come forth upon it. (T, M, K.)

vuWoluwlN c
vuWoluwlN, (T, S, M, &c.,) which may also be pronounced with the C suppressed, [vuwluwlN,] (Msb,) [A wart; thus called in the present day;] a certain excrescence (M, Mgh, K) on the person of a man, (Mgh,) small, (K,) hard, and round, (Mgh, K,) and of various forms; one description being inverted; another, cracked and scabrous; another, pendent; another, nail-shaped, large in the head and slender at the root; another, long, and bent backward; another, opened; all arising from a thick, tough humour, phlegmatic, or bilious, or a compound of both these kinds: (K, TA:) pl. vaMliylu. (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, (as being likened to the excrescence above mentioned, TA,) The nipple of the breast. (Kr, M, K.)

1 vabata vAb vbt vbtt
1. vabata, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
vabuta
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. vubuwtN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and vabaAtN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) [unexplained in the S and M and A and K, as being well known,] It (a thing, S, M, Msb) continued, subsisted, lasted, endured, remained, remained fixed or stationary, stood, or rested; it was, or became, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: it obtained, or held: syn. daAma: (Mgh, Msb:) and AisotaqarRa: (Msb:) [it stood, as a fact or truth; it stood, or held, good; it was, or became, a fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] it was, or became, or proved, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper; syn. SaHRa. (Msb.) ― -b2- vabata biAlmakaAni, inf. n. vuburtN, He continued, remained, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (T.) ― -b3- vabata AljaraAdu, and vRbt↓, and Avbt↓, The locusts stuck their tails into the ground to lay their eggs. (T.) ― -b4- vabatRu EalaI AlOamori [I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair]. (K in art. zmE.) ― -b5- vabata liboduka (tropical:) May thy case, or state, or condition, be permanent. (A, TA.) ― -b6- [vabata Einodahu kacaA Such a thing was, or became, a settled, or an established, fact, or truth, with him, or in his opinion; it became established, substantiated, made good, or verified, in his opinion or estimation: like SaHRa. And vabata Ealayohi It was, or became, established against him. Hence, vabata lahu Ealayohi kacaA Such a thing became established, or verified, as due to him from him: like SaHRa. And hence,] vabata is also syn. with wajaba [as meaning It was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: and it was, or became, necessitated, necessary, or requisite: so that vabata Ealayohi means also it was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him; or it rested, or lay, on him; as a debt, or a duty: and it (a sentence &c.) became necessitated to take effect upon him: and vabata lahu it was, or became, or proved to be, due to him, or owing to him]. (Telweeh, TA in art. wjb.) ― -b7- [vabata lahu also signifies It belonged, or appertained, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; it was affirmable, or predicable, of him, or it.] ＝ -A2- vabuta, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
vabuta
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. vabaAtapN (M, A, K) and vubuwtapN, (M, K,) He was, or became, firm in intellect, understanding, or mind: (S:) or firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M:) or intelligent, and possessing self-restraint: or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault: (A:) or firm of heart in war: (Msb:) or courageous as a horseman, (K, TA,) earnest in the charge. (TA.)

2 vabRata AljaraAdu vbt AljrAd
2. vabRata AljaraAdu: see 1. ＝ -A2- vbRthu: see 4, in two
places. ― -b2- vbRthu Eani AlOamori i. q. vabRaTahu [He hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, &c., from doing the affair, or thing]. (M.)

3 muvaAbatapN mvAbp mvAbth mvAbtp
3. muvaAbatapN i. q. mumaAwatapN [meaning The vying with another in firmness, or steadiness, or the like]. (TA in art. mwt.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 Avbt AljaraAdu Avbt AljrAd
4. Avbt AljaraAdu: see 1. ＝ -A2- Avbthu trans. of vabata, as also vbRthu↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) signifying He made it to continue, subsist, last, endure, remain, remain fixed or stationary, stand, or rest; to be, or become, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: he made it to obtain, or hold: [he made it to stand, as a fact or truth; to stand, or hold, good; to be or become, a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] he made it, or rendered it, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper. (Msb.) ― -b2- TaEanahu faOavobata fiyhi AlrRumoHi He thrust him, and made the spear to penetrate into him so that the extremity protruded while part remained within him; syn. Oanofacahu (M.) ― -b3- Avbthu biwivaAqK [He made him fast with a bond, or ligature]. (TA.) ― -b4- liyuvobituwka, (S, Mgh, K,) or liyuvabRituwka↓, (CK,) in the Kur [viii. 30], means (tropical:) That they might inflict upon thee a wound by reason of which thou shouldst not be able to rise: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) or that they might confine thee [to thy place]. (K, TA.) You say, TaEanotuhu faOavobatRuhu (tropical:) I thrust him, or pierced him, and confined him to his place, so that he could not quit it. (TA from a trad.) And Darabuwhu HatRaI Oavobatuwhu (tropical:) They smote him, or beat him, so that they enervated him [and rendered him motionless]. (A, TA.) And Oavobata AljariyHa (assumed tropical:) He weakened the wounded man so that he was unable to move. (Mgh.) And Oavobatatohu jiraAHapN (tropical:) A wound rendered him unable to move: (T, * A:) and in like manner one says of a malady. (A.) And Ouvobita (assumed tropical:) His malady became violent, or a wound affected him, so that he did not [or could not] move. (T, TA.) ― -b5- Avbt HuHRatahu He established his evidence, or proof, and made it clear, plain, or manifest. (M.) ― -b6- Avbthu, (M, K,) inf. n. UivobaAtN, (TA,) also signifies (tropical:) He knew him, or it, certainly, or assuredly; and so vAbthu↓, (M, K, TA,) inf. n. muvaAbatapN. (TA.) And you say, naZarotu Uilayohi famaA OavobatRuhu bibaSariI (tropical:) [I looked at him, or it, but I did not know him, or it, surely with my eye]. (A, TA.) And Avbt AlXRaIoCa maEorifapF (tropical:) [He knew the thing certainly, completely, or thoroughly]. (A. [Explained in a copy of that work, followed in the TA, by qabilahu; but this is undoubtedly a mistranscription for qatalahu, q. v.]) ― -b7- Also, (i. e. Avbthu alone,) He verified it. (Har p. 175.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) He wrote it, [set it down, registered it, or recorded it,] i. e., a man's name, (A, Msb, TA,) fiI AldRiywaAni [in the register of soldiers or pensioners or accounts]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- [And i. q. Oawojabahu as meaning He made it, or declared it to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, (Ealayohi on him,) or due (lahu to him): and, said of a sentence &c., as meaning he necessitated it to take effect, or necessitated its taking effect, Ealayohi upon him: see HaqRahu. ― -b10- And He affirmed it; he averred it; i. q. Oawojabahu as contr. of nafaAhu. And hence, Avbthu lahu signifies also He made it, or declared it, or asserted it, to belong, or appertain, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; he affirmed it, or predicated it, of him, or it. ― -b11- And He authorized it; namely a word, a signification, &c.] ― -b12- Avbt fulaAnFA He kept, clave, or held fast, to such a one; scarcely, or never, quitting him. (Msb.) And Avbthu AlsRaqamu, i. e. [The malady clave to him;] did not quit him. (S.)

5 tvbRt fiI AlOamori c
5. tvbRt fiI AlOamori, (T, S, M, A, TA,) and AlrRaOoIi; (T, TA;) and Astvbt↓; (S, M, A, K, TA;) He acted, or proceeded, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (T, M, A, K, TA,) in the affair, (T, M, A, TA,) and the opinion, judgment, or counsel; (T, TA;) not hastily: (T, M, TA:) both signify the same: (S:) [or] fiI Oamorihi Astvbt↓ he consulted respecting his affair, and sought for information respecting it, or investigated it. (T, TA.) [In the KL, tavabRutN is explained by the words drnG krdn w bhjAI Mwrdn, perhaps meaning The delaying in an affair and (then) executing or performing.]

10 Astvbt Ostvbt Astvbt QstvAb Qstvbt Qstvbtt
10. Astvbt: see 5, in two places. ― -b2- [Also He sought, or desired, or demanded, confirmation, evidence, proof, demonstration, verification, assurance, or positive or certain information, Eanohu respecting him, or it. ― -b3- And He desired, or meant, an affirmation: see a remark on a verse cited voce bayoda.] ＝ -A2- Astvbthu He found it to be sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Har p. 175:) and he assured, or certified, himself of the true state of his case. (Idem, p. 426.) You say, SagRara Eayonahu liyasotavobita AlnRaZara (assumed tropical:) [He contracted his eye in order to assure himself of the correctness of the view; i. e., to obtain a sure view]. (M in art. wS.) ― -b2- It is also said to mean He made him, or asserted him to be, firm of heart: but Er-Rázee says, I have not met with this verb used as one that is immediately transitive. (Har p. 426.)

vabotN vAb vbt vbtt
vabotN: see vaAbitN. ― -b2- Also A man firm, or steady, of heart; (S;) and so vabotu AljanaAni; (A, Msb, TA;) pl. vubotN: (TA:) or a man who acts, or proceeds, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (A, Msb,) in his affairs: (Msb:) and a courageous horseman, (M, K, TA,) earnest in the charge; (TA;) as also vabiytN↓: (M, K, TA:) both of which signify also intelligent, and possessing self-restraint; or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault. (A, TA.) And vabotu AlmaqaAmi A man who does not quit his station, or abode. (M.) And vabotu Alqadami [Firm-footed;] one who makes no slip in contention, or in fight. (A, TA.) And vabotu Algadari A man firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M, L, TA:) or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions. (S, TA.) ― -b3- See also vabatN: ― -b4- and vabiytN.

vabatN vAb vbt vbtt
vabatN Firmness of heart in war. (Msb, TA.) You say, lahu vabatN Einoda AlHamolapi He has firmness, or steadiness, on the occasion of the charge, or assault. (S, A.) And lahu vabatN Einoda AlHimaAmi He has firmness on the occasion of death. (L.) [See also vabaAtN.] ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) A proof, and evidence, or a voucher. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, laA OaHokumu bikacaA UilRaA bivabatK I will not decide so unless on the ground of proof, or evidence. (S.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the day of doubt, [i. e. the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán,] vumRa jaMCa AlvRabatu OanRahu mino ramaDaAna Then came the proof, or evidence, or voucher, that it was of Ramadán. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (Mgh,) applied to a man, (A, Mgh, [in which latter it is said to be tropical when thus applied, but not so in the A,]) and sometimes written vabotN↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) One who is an authoritative evidence, or voucher, by reason of his trustworthiness in that which he relates: (A, TA:) or (tropical:) one who is trustworthy (Mgh, K *) in that which he relates: (Mgh: [in the K, only the pl. is mentioned:]) or (assumed tropical:) one who is just, or equitable, [in that which he relates,] and exact, or honest: (Msb:) pl. OavobaAtN. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) An index, or a table of contents, in which a relater of traditions collects a list of what he has related from others, and of his sheykhs [who are his authorities]: said by some to be a conventional term of the relaters of traditions: perhaps tropical. (TA.)

vabaAtN vbAt
vabaAtN, a subst. from vabata, [or an inf. n., like vubuwtN↓, used as a simple subst.,] Continuance, subsistency, lastingness, permanence, endurance, remanence, remanence in a fixed or stationary state, a state of standing or resting, constancy, firmness, steadiness, steadfastness, stableness or stability, fixedness, fastness, settledness, establishment or a state of being established: &c.: and soundness, validness or validity, substantiality or substantialness, reality, sureness, certainty, trueness or truth, &c. (Msb.) [See also vabatN.]

vubaAtN vbAt

(K.) ― -b2- And A strap, or thong, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is bound: (M, K:) pl. OavobitapN. (M.)

vubuwtN vbwt

vaAbitN vAb vAbt
vaAbitN part. n. of vabata; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also vabotN↓ (M, A, K) and vabiytN↓; (K;) Continuing, subsisting, lasting, enduring, remaining, remaining fixed or stationary, standing, or resting, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: obtaining, or holding: [standing, as a fact or truth; standing, or holding, good; having the quality of a
fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Msb: see 1:) dim., when it is used as an epithet, vuwayobitN; but when it is a proper name, its dim. is vubayotN. (T.) ― -b2- vaAbitN bimakaAnK Continuing, remaining, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- AlkawaAkibu AlvRaAbitapu [and AlvRawaAbitu] The fixed stars. (Kzw &c.) ― -b4- sinuwna vaAbitapN Years lasting long. (TA in art. qEs.) ― -b5- qawolN vaAbitN A sound, valid, true, right, correct, just, or proper, saying. (M.) biAlqawoli AlvRaAbiti in the Kur xiv. 32 means By the assertion of the unity of God. (Jel.)

muvobtN mvbt
muvobtN Bound with the strap, or thong, called vibaAt; applied to a camel's saddle (raHol). (M, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Motionless by reason of disease (T, K, TA) that has become violent, or by reason of a wound: (T, TA:) or the same, (M,) or in this sense muvobitN↓, (K, TA,) (tropical:) heavy (M, K, TA) by reason of old age or some other cause, (TA,) and not quitting the bed. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- [kalaAmN muvobatN lit. An affirmed sentence; i. q. muwjabN as contr. of manofiIRN; virtually the same as kalaAmu muvobitN↓ an affirming, or affirmative, sentence.]

OavobaAjN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The middle (S, K) of a thing, (K,) of anything: (S:) and the main part thereof; (K;) so of a heap, or tract, of sand: (A'Obeyd, S:) and the higher, or highest, part of a thing: pl. [of pauc.] OavobaAjN and [of mult.] vubuwjN. (TA.) (tropical:) The middle of the sea: the main part thereof; and of the night: (A, * TA:) the height of the middle of the sea, where the waves meet one another: the higher, or highest, parts of the waves. (TA.) mino vabaji Almusolimiyna (assumed tropical:) Of the middle class of the Muslims: or of the higher, or highest, or chief, class of them. Ejr on the authority of Fr:) and having a projecting, or prominent, breast, or chest: (L:) dim. Ouvayobiju↓, occurring in a trad. (S, Mgh, Msb, * K.)

, (M,) or

, inf. n. as above, He confined, restricted, or limited, him (a man) to the thing. (Msb.) And vabarahu Eanohu, (T, S, M,) aor.

, (T,) or

, (S, M,) inf. n. as above; (S, K;) and vbRrhu↓; (IAar, TA;) He, or it, restrained, withheld, hindered, or prevented, him from it; (IAar, T, S, K;) turned him away, or back, from it, (AZ, IAar, T, M, K.) And maA vabaraka Eano HaAjatika What restrained, withhold, hindered, or prevented, thee, (T, * S, A,) or retarded thee, (A,) or diverted thee, (T, A,) from [accomplishing, or attaining,] thy want? , (Msb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (Msb, K,) He (God, M, A, Msb) destroyed him (M, A, Msb, K *) with a destruction from which he should not rise again. (M, A.) ＝ -A2- vabara, aor.

, (Msb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (S, Msb, K,) He perished: (S, Msb, K:) he suffered loss; erred, or went astray; or became lost. (S.) [See also vubuwrN below.] ― -b2- Also, (M,) inf. n. vaborN, (K,) It (the sea) ebbed. (M, K.)

vubuwrN Perdition: (Katádeh, T, S, M, K:) loss; a going astray; or becoming lost: (S:) woe: (Katádeh, T, M, K:) destruction (M, A, K) from which there is no rising again. (M, A.) Hence it is said that the people of Hell will call out, waAvubuwraAho Alas for destruction from which there is no rising again! (M, A.) In the Kur xxv. 14 and 15, vubuwrFA is in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though they said, vabaronaA vubuwrFA; and, being an inf. n., it is used as a sing. and pl. (Fr, Zj, T.)

mino raOoIa mavobuwrK wavaAbiro
waraOato quDaAEapu fiI AlOayaA
And Kudá'ah, in asserting their relationship to El-Yemen, formed the opinion of one who is made to suffer loss, or to err, &c., and one who is suffering loss, or erring, &c.; mvbwr here meaning maxosuwr. (S.)

mavobuwrN mvbwr
mavobuwrN, as used in the Kur xvii. 104, Overcome; withheld, or prevented, from attaining what is good: (Fr, T:) driven away; expelled; banished; outcast: punished; chastised: (IAar, T:) cursed; accursed: (Fr, IAar, T:) made to lose, or suffer loss; to err, or go astray; or to become lost, or to perish: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt cited above, voce vaAbirN: (S:) in a state of destruction. (Mujáhid, T.)

[of pauc.] OavobaATN and [of mult.] vibaATN, (K,) and, applied to men, vabiTuwna also. (TA.)

vibaAnN vbAn vbnp
vibaAnN A receptacle, such as when one folds the skirt of his shirt and puts in it a thing and carries it before him: (S:) or the part, of the garment, which is the place wherein one carries, when he wraps it around his body, or puts a portion thereof under his right shoulder and another portion over his left shoulder, then folds before him a part of it, and puts a thing in it; as also vubonapN↓: (M:) or the part, of one's garment, which is the place wherein he carries; folding its extremity, and sewing it, before him, and then putting in it some dates or other things: as also vabiynN↓ and vubonapN↓: (K:) and the extremity of the [garment called] ridaMC when one folds it before him and sews it [and puts a thing in it to carry]: (M:) or a receptacle in which one carries a thing before him; (T:) and vubonapN↓, of which the pl. is vubaAnN, (T,) or its pl. is vubanN, like as the pl of xubonapN [which has a similar meaning] is xubanN, (Har p. 427,) the doubled upper border of the trousers or waist-wrapper, in which one carries [before him] fruit and other things: [see also xubonapN:] or, as some say, vibaAnN does not signify a receptacle, but dates that are put and carried in a receptacle or some other thing: and sometimes what a man carries in his sleeve; and vubonapN↓ signifies only what one carries before him, that is little in quantity: and what is great is not called vibaAnN. (T.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, UicaA marRa OaHadukumo biHaAYiTK faloyaOokulo minohu walaA yatRaxico vibaAnFA [When any one of you passes by a garden of palm-trees, let him eat thereof, but not take for himself, or make, a vbAn]: i. e., when a necessitous hungry person passes by a man's garden of palm-trees, he may eat of their dates what will repel his hunger. (T. [See also another reading voce xubonapN.]) And one says, qadima fulaAnN bivibaAnK fiI vawobihi maA OadoriI maA huwa [Such a one came with a vbAn in his garment: I know not what it was]. (T.)

vabiynN: see vibaAnN.

1. vabawotu lahu xayorFA baEoda xayorK, or XarRFA, I sent him good after good, or evil [after evil]. (TA.) [See also 2.]

2 tavobiyapN tvbyh tvbyp wvb
2. tavobiyapN, [inf. n. of vbRI, mentioned in the T and K, in all its senses, in art. vbI, and so in the M, except in the first of the following senses, which is there mentioned in art. vbI and also in art. vbw,] The act of collecting (K, TA) in successive assemblages (vubapF vubapF↓). (TA.) You say, vbRAhu He collected it, namely, a thing, (M,) and water: (M * and TA in art. vbw:) and he added to it, and collected it. (M, TA.) ― -b2- The collecting what is good: and also, what is bad, or evil: thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- [And hence,] The praising a man in his life-time: (AA, S, K:) or praising him time after time in his life-time: (TA:) or praising him much; as though relating to him collections (vubaAt↓) of praise: (Z, TA;) or the mentioning of the sundry good qualities or actions: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and the magnifying [a person]; or honouring [him]. (T, * K.) You say, vbRI AlrRajula, (M,) or vbRI EalaI AlrRajuli, (T,) He praised the man in his life-time: (T, M:) because the doing so implies the collecting his good qualities or actions. (T, * M.) ― -b4- [Hence also the contr. signification,] The blaming, or censuring, much; collecting blame, or censure, from this and that source. (TA. [The act. part. n. is rendered in the M agreeably with this explanation.]) ― -b5- The act of completing [and augmenting a thing]. (K.) You say, vabRi maEoruwfaka Complete and augment [thy beneficence, or bounty, or favour]. (T.) And vbRI QllRehu laka AlnRiEama [May God complete and augment to thee benefits, or blessings: or] may God send to thee benefits, or blessings. (TA.) [See also 1.] ― -b6- The putting a thing into a good, right, or sound, state, and augmenting it. (T, K. *) ― -b7- vbRI AlmaAla He kept, preserved, guarded, or took care of, the property. (Kr, M.) ＝ -A2- vabRayotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (As, S,) inf. n. tavobiyapN, (As, T, S, M, K,) I kept constantly, or perseveringly, to the thing. (As, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- The inf. n. signifies also The keeping, (T,) or pursuing, (K,) the way, course, mode of acting, or the like, of one's father: (T, K:) or the doing, or acting, like one's father. (M.) ― -b3- Also The complaining of one's state, or case, and of one's want; and asking aid, or assistance, and vengeance, or avengement. (K.) [One of the meanings assigned to the verb by Golius, as on the authority of the K, and by Freytag after him, is “ Disposuit paravitque se: ” app. from the former's having found AlAisotiEodaAdu written in a copy of the K for AlAisotiEodaMCu.] ＝ -A3- OanaA OaEorifuhu tavobiyapF I know him, or it, with a seeming, not a certain, knowledge. a pl. of vubapN as meaning a company; (L in art. vwb, and Ham p. 271;) and hence the phrase AlvRubaI AlEaAliI, for AlvRubaI AlEaAliyapu, [the high, or exalted, companies,] the former word being made masc. because it is like zulamN [which is sing. and masc.]; but some say that this word here means the assemblies of the nobles: (Ham ubi suprá:) IAar says, AlvRubaI AlEaAliI mino majaAlisi AlOaXoraAfi; but [ISd observes,] this is extraordinary, and I have not heard it except in the poetry of El-Find EzZimmánee. (M.) Accord. to some, it is from vaAba, being originally vuwbapN; and its dim. is vuwayobapN: (T:) or it is originally vubaIN: (S:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the letter elided from vubapN as meaning “ a company, ” but not as relating to a wateringtrough or tank, is I; and ISd holds it to be I: and [if so,] its dim. is vubayRapN↓: (TA:) [but ISd adds,] IJ says that the elided letter is w, because it is this in most cases, as in OabN and OaxN and sanapN and EiDapN &c. (M in arts. vbw and vbI.) [See also art. vwb. It seems to signify also An assemblage, or a collection, of things of any kind:] see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also The middle of a wateringtrough or tank, (T, S, M, K,) to which the water returns [when it has been emptied], (S,) or to which what remains of the water returns: (T:) and the place where the water collects in a valley or low ground: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) but this is from vaAba; (T, S; *) the p is a substitute for the w, the medial radical, which is suppressed; for it is originally vuwabN: (S:) or it is originally vuwbapN: (T:) or it may be from vabRayotu “ I collected: ” but Aboo-Is-hák makes it to be from vaAba AlmaMCu, aor. yavuwbu; and this he infers to be the case from their saying that the dim. is vuwayobapN. (M.) [See also art. vwb.]

(MF in art. vnd.) ― -b2- vunoduWapu AlOanofi, occurring in a trad., The tip, or fore part, of the nose. (IAth, TA.)

vadoIN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and vidoIN and vadFI: (K:) the first of these is the form most commonly obtaining: (TA:) [The breast, or mamma;] the part of the chest whereof the Halamap is the head; each of the two parts whereof the HalamataAni are the two heads: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) [and sometimes, but not properly, the Halamap alone; i. e., the pap, nipple, or mamilla:] you say vadoI muqoEadN a breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant, (S, A, L, K, in art. qEd,) that fills the hand, (A in that art.,) and has not yet become folding: (S, L, K, in that art.:) and raDaEa vadoIa OumRihi [he sucked the breast, meaning the pap, or nipple, of his mother]. (IKtt in TA, art. rDE:) it is peculiar to woman; (T, K;) or common to woman and man; (S, Msb, K;) being sometimes used in relation to a man; (Msb;) accord. to the opinion held to be most chaste and best known by the lexicologists [in general]: (TA:) and is masc.; (T, M, Mgh;) or masc. and fem.; (S, Msb, K;) but most chastely masc.: (TA;) the pl. [of pauc.] is OavodK, (S, M, Msb, K,] [originally OavoduIN,] of the measure OafoEulN, (Msb,) and [of mult.] vudiIRN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [originally vuduwIN,] of the measure fuEuwlN, (S, Msb,) and vidiIRN, with kesr to the v because of the kesr to the letter following, (S,) and sometimes vidaMCN, [originally vidaAIN,] like sihaAmN; (Msb;) and a poet says,
waOaSobaHati AlnRisaMCu musalRibaAtK
lahunRa Alwayolu yamodudona AlvRudiynaA
[And the women became widowed, or bereft of relations, and without their ornaments, or in mourning, having woe, pulling the breasts]; but this is something like a mistake; and it may be that he meant AltRudiyRaA, and changed the [latter] I into n for the sake of the rhyme. (M.) It is said in a prov., tujawRaEu AlHurRapu walaA taOokulu vadoyayohaA, meaning, Oujorapa vadoyayohaA, [i. e. The ingenuous woman will be made to hunger and will not eat the hire of her breasts,] the prefixed noun being suppressed; or, as some relate it, bivadoyayohaA, which is plain [as meaning, by means of her breasts]: it is applied in relation to a man's preserving himself from ignoble means of acquiring wealth. (Mgh.) And judRa vadoIu OumRihi, May his mother's breast be cut off, is a form of imprecation against a man, and used to imply a wish for his separation. (As, L in art. jd.) The saying of 'Alee, on the day of his slaughter of the Khawárij, AunoZuruwA faUinRa fiyihmo
rajulFA UiHodaI yadayohi mivolu vadoIi AlmaroOapi [Look ye, for among them is a man one of whose arms is like the breast of the woman], not AHdI vadoyayohi as some relate it, was applied to a man who had, in the place of one arm, a lump of flesh upon his shoulder-joint, which lump, when it was stretched, became equal in length to his other arm, and when it was left, returned [to its original form]. (Mgh.) Respecting vudayRapN↓, the dim., whence the surname caw AlvRudayRapi, he who holds vadoIN to be masc. [only] says that the p is added because the word [virtually] means Alyad, [which is fem.,] for the man thus surnamed had a short arm, of the size of the vadoI, as is indicated by the fact that they also called him cuw AlyudayRapi: (S:) or, accord. to Fr, (A'Obeyd, T,) p is added, in this instance, in the dim., though vadoIN is masc., because it applies to what resembled the remains (baqiyRap) of a vadoI, the greater part of it having gone, so that it is like luHamoyapN and XuHayomapN [dims. of laHomapN and XaHomapN]: (T, M:) or the p is added because the word is regarded in this case as meaning AlbaDoEapu [the piece, or lump, of flesh]: (Mgh:) some say that it is the dim. of vanoduwapN; (Mgh, TA;) but this requires consideration. (Mgh.)

, the second pers. of the pret. being app. vaTuTota,] vaTaATapN and vuTuwTapN; (Lth, K;) or the last two, accord. to IDrd, are simple substs., and ISd approves of this distinction; (TA;) He (a man, Lth, S) was, or became, such as is termed vaTRN and OavaTRu [explained below]. (Lth, IDrd, S, K.)

vaTRN vT
vaTRN and OavaTRu↓, (Lth, S, K,) but the former is the more correct and the more common, (Lth,) or the former only, (IDrd, and IB on the authority of Ibn-El-Jawáleekee, and K,) the latter being vulgar, (IDrd, K,) but AZ asserted his having heard the latter, (AHát, cited in the Jm,) [and the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh,] A man (S, Mgh) having no hair upon the sides of his face, but only upon his chin; syn. kawosajN: (S, Mgh, K:) or having a scanty beard: (IDrd:) or the former signifies having little hair in the beard, and in the eyebrows: (K:) or [when you mean the latter] you say rajulN vaTRu AlHaAjibayoni, (K,) a man having thin, or scanty, eyebrows; as also AlHaAjibayoni OavaTRu↓; (TA;) the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable; (IAar, K;) and AimoraOapN vaTRapu AlHaAjibayoni [a woman having thin, or scanty, eyebrows]: (S TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OavoTaATN (Kr, K) and (of mult., TA) vuTRaAnN and viTaTapN (AZ, K) and vuTuTN, (IAar,) [all of which may be of either sing.,] and viTaATN, (AZ, S, K,) which is of the former sing., (S,) and vuTRN, (AZ, S, K,) which is of the latter. (S.) You say also AimoraOapN vaTRaMCu↓ A woman having no Uisob, (Lth, TA,) i. e. hair on the pubes; in the copies of the K incorrectly written Aisot. (TA.) And EaAriDN OavaTRu↓ A side of the cheek, or of the face, having the hair falling off. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, the former, Heavy in the belly; (K, TA;) slow; applied to a man. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The former also signifies Human excrement or ordure; or thin human excrement or ordure; syn. saloHN. (Sgh, K.) [See also valoTN.]

OavaTRu c
OavaTRu, and its fem. vaTRaMCu: see vaTRN, in four places. ― -b2- AlvRaTRaMCu also signifies The spider: or another
creeping thing, that stings, or bites, vehemently: (K:) this is from Lth, as in the O and L: but in the Tekmileh we find AlvRaTRaMCu, like XafRaMC, [app. a mistake for AlvRiTaMCu, like XifaMC,] a certain small creeping thing: or, as some say, it is AlvRaTaA, of the measure of qafFA. (TA.)

1 vaEabahu vEb vEbh vEbp
1. vaEabahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
vaEaba
, (K,) inf. n. vaEobN, (S,) He gave vent to it; or made it to flow forth, run, or stream; namely, water, (S, A, K,) and blood, and the like. (K.) vEb damFA, [thought by MF to be vaEaba, but I see no reason why it should not be vaEaba,] said of a wound, means It flowed, or ran, with blood. (TA.)

7 AnvEb AnvEb
7. AnvEb It (water) had vent; or it flowed forth, ran, or streamed; (S, A, K;) in, or through, a mavoEab: (S TA:) and in like manner, rain: (TA:) and blood from the nose. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] SaAHa bihi faQnovaEaba Uilayohi (tropical:) He called out to him and he sprang up and ran to him. (A, TA.)

vaEobN vEb
vaEobN, applied to water, (K,) and to blood, (TA,) Flowing, running, or streaming; as also vaEabN↓ and OuvoEuwbN↓ and OuvoEubaAnN↓. (K, TA.) You say sayolN OuvoEuwbN↓ [A flowing torrent]. (A.) ― -b2- And [hence,] XarRN OuvoEuwbN↓ (tropical:) [Evil that takes its course like a stream]. (A.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

vaEabN vEb
vaEabN, (so in the S, expressly said to be biAltRaHoriyki,) or vaEobN↓, (so in the K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, mavoEab, (TA,) A water-course of a valley; a channel in which water flows in a valley: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, the rubbish and scum that collect in the channel in which the rainwater flows; but Az disapproves of this explanation of the word, and says that it signifies, in his opinion, the channel itself: (TA:) the pl. is voEobaAnN. (S, K.) One says, saAlati AlvRuEobaAnu kamaA saAla AlvRuEobaAnu, i. e. The torrent [or rather the torrents ran like the serpent called vEbAn]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also vaEobN.

vuEobaAnN vEbAn
vuEobaAnN A kind of long serpent: (S:) a great serpent; applied to the male and the female: (Msb:) a bulky and long serpent, (Sh, K, TA,) that hunts the rat or mouse, to which latter animal the name is sometimes metaphorically applied, and that is more useful in the house than are cats: (Sh, TA:) or particularly the male [serpent], (Ktr, K,) that is yellow, and ruddy: (Ktr:) or the serpent in general, (ISh, K,) male and female, great and small: (ISh:) [also applied to an enormous fabulous serpent; described by Kzw and others:] pl. vaEaAbiynu. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [raYyisu AlvRaEaAbiyni The basilisk. (Golius, from a Glossary.)] ― -b3- damu AlvRuEobaAni: see damN.

fuwhu yajoriI vaEaAbiyba fwh yjry vEAbyb
fuwhu yajoriI vaEaAbiyba, (As, S, K,) or famuhu, (TA,) and saEaAbiyba, (S,) His mouth runs with clear water, having an extended [or a ropy] flow. (As, S, K.)

OuvoEubaAnN c
OuvoEubaAnN: see vaEobN.

OuvoEuwb c
OuvoEuwb: see vaEobN, in three places.

mavoEabN mvEb
mavoEabN [The outlet, or place of outpouring, of the water of a watering-trough &c.;] the place of passage for the water, in the side of a wateringtrough or tank: and a channel, or conduit, for water: (KL:) pl. mavaAEibu. (S, A.) You say mavoEabu AlHawpa [The outlet for the water of the watering-trough or tank]: (S, A:) and mavoEabu AlsRaToHi [the outlet for the water of the house-top]: (A:) and mavoEabu AlmaTari [the outlet, or channel, for the rain-water]: (TA:) from vaEaba AlmaMCa “he gave vent to the water,” or, “made it to flow forth,” &c. (A, TA.) And mavaAEibu Almadiynapi, meaning The channels, or places of flowing, of the water of the city: (K, TA:) whence it appears that MF has erred in saying that mavoEabN signifies [only] a mizoraAb [or spout for conveying away water from a housetop &c.]: not a channel, or place of flowing. (TA.) [See also SunobuwrN, and lawolabo.]

vaEodN vEd
vaEodN, as an epithet applied to a leguminous plant, or to an herb, Fresh, juicy, or sappy; (S, A, K;) soft, or tender. (S, A.) You say vaEodN maEodN in this sense; (S, A;) the latter word being an imitative sequent, not [generally] used alone; but some use it alone: (S:) and it is said to be syn. with the former. (TA.) You say also ruTabapN vaEodapN maEodapN, meaning A fresh, juicy, ripe date. (IAar, TA.) And varFI vaEodN Soft, moist earth; (S, K;) as also jaEodN. (Sudot;.) ― -b2- [As a coll. gen. n.,] Fresh ripe dates: or dates for the most part in a state of ripeness: (K:) or ripening dates when they have become soft: n. un. with p: (As, S:) that which is ripening, but as yet hard and indigestible, is termed jumosapN. (As, TA.) [See busorN.] ― -b3- Fresh butter: so accord. to Is-hák Ibn-Ibrá- heem El-Kurashee, in a trad. related by him. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- maA lahu vaEodN walaA maEodN He possesses not little nor much. (K.) [Here, again,] the last word is an imitative sequent. (TA.)

1 vaEila vEl
1. vaEila, aor.
vaEala
, inf. n. vaEalN, His teeth were irregular in their places of growth, and overlying one another: (Msb:) [or he had a tooth, or teeth, in excess, or exceeding the usual number, and growing behind the others: see what follows.] And vaEilati AlsRinRu The tooth exceeded the usual number, (Msb, K,) being behind the other teeth: or entered beneath another, being irregular in the place of growth. (K.) [See also vuEolN.]

4 AvElwA AvElwA
4. AvElwA, said of guests, They were, or became, numerous, or many, (K, TA,) and straitened, or crowded, one another: (TA:) so, too, said of men coming to water. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AvElwA EalayonaA They acted contrarily, or adversely, to us; they opposed us. (Lth, S, K.) ― -b3- AvEl said of a recompense, or reward, It was, or became, great. (K.) ― -b4- And said of an affair, It was so great that one knew not how to apply himself to it: (K:) it implies incongruity. (TA.)

vaEolN vEl
vaEolN: see vuEolN.

vuEolN vEl
vuEolN (K, and Ham p. 647) and vaEalN↓ and vuEoluwlN↓, (K,) the last from Ibn-'Abbád, (TA,) A tooth in excess, or exceeding the usual number, (K, and Ham ubi suprà,) behind the other teeth: (K:) or the entering of a tooth beneath another, with irregularity in the place of its growth: (K:) or vaEalN↓ signifies superfluities in the teeth, and irregularity in their places of growth, so that they overlie one another: (S:) or the teeth's overlying one another, and the excess of a tooth among them [beyond the usual number]. (Har p. 243.) ― -b2- And vuEolN (S, K, and Ham ubi suprà) and vaEolN↓ and vaEalN↓ (K) An excess, or a redundance, (K and Ham,) [i. e.] a small teat in excess, [in addition to the usual number,] (S,) in, or among, the teats of a sheep or goat, (S, K, Ham,) and of a she-camel, (S, K,) and of a cow: (K:) it does not yield milk, though hyperbolically described as doing so. (S. [But see vaEuwlN.]) ― -b3- Also vuEolN, [not vuEaAlN as in Freytag's Lex.,] A certain animalcule that appears in a skin used for holding water or milk when its odour has become bad. (Ibn-'Abbad, K. *)

vaEalN vEl
vaEalN: see vuEolN, in three places.

vuEalN vEl
vuEalN: see vuEaAlapu. ― -b2- One says in reviling a man, heciA AlvRuEalu waAlkuEalu, meaning This ignoble fellow, that is naught. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

vuEoluwlN vElwl
vuEoluwlN: see vuEolN. ― -b2- Also A ewe, or she-goat, that may be milked from three places, or four, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) by reason of an excess in the [number of] teats. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA. [See also vaEuwlN.]) ＝ -A2- Angry. (Lth, K.)

vaEaAlK vEAl
vaEaAlK: pl. of vaEolabu [q. v.]. (K in art. vElb.)

vuEaAlN vEAl
vuEaAlN: see vuEaAlapu.

vaEuwlu vEwl
vaEuwlu, applied to a she-camel, a cow, and a sheep or goat, Having an excess, or a redundance, in the [number of] teats: or having, above her teat, a small teat: or having a nipple in excess: (K:) or a ewe, or she-goat, having a vuEol [q. v.]: or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, a ewe, or she goat, that may be milked from her vuEol. (Ham p. 647. [See also vuEoluwlN.]) ― -b2- TaEonapN vaEuwlN A wound made with a spear or the like from which the blood is scattered, or sprinkled. (TA.) ― -b3- jayoXN vaEuwlN A numerous army. (TA.) And katiybapN An army, or a collected portion thereof, having with it much rabble and many followers: (K:) regard is had in it to multitude and crowding. (TA.)

vuEaAlapu vEAl vEAlh vEAlp
vuEaAlapu, a determinate noun, The vaEolab [or fox]; (S, O;) as also vuEalN↓: (IDrd, TA:) or the female vElb; as also vuEaAlN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- vuEaAlapu Dry herbage: or vuEaAlapu is [the plant commonly called] Einabu AlvRaEolabi [see art. vElb]: (K:) this is from AHn. (TA.)

OavoEalu c
OavoEalu A man whose teeth are irregular in their places of growth, and overlying one another: (Msb:) or having superfluities in his teeth, and irregularity in their places of growth, so that they overlie one another: (S:) or having a tooth
in excess, (Mgh, K,) behind the other teeth: (K:) or having a tooth entering beneath another, being irregular in the place of growth: (K:) fem. vaEolaMCu, applied to a woman; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and also to a gum (livapN): (K:) pl. vuEolN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- A portly, or corpulent, personage, or chief, characterized by superabundances of benificence, or bounty. (Lth, K.)

muvoEilN mvEl
muvoEilN Spread, scattered, or sprinkled. (TA.) ― -b2- wrodNmuvoElN [A company of men coming to water] straitening, or crowding, one another. (K.) ― -b3- jaMCa Alqawomu muvoEiliyna The people, or company of men, came in a connected, or continnous, body. (TA.)

OaroDN mavoEalapN c
OaroDN mavoEalapN A land in which are many vaEaAlib [or foxes]; (S, K;) like maEoqarapN meaning “ a land in which are many EaqaArib [or scorpions]; ” (S;) as also muvaEolibapN. (K in art. vElb. [But see this last word.])

Q. 1 vaEolaba vElb
Q. 1. vaEolaba He (a man) was cowardly, and eluded, or turned away, or went this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully; as also tavaEolaba↓: his doing so being thus likened to the running of the vaEolab. (TA.) And vElb minohu faraqFA [He was cowardly, and eluded him, or turned away from him, &c., through fear]; i. e., from another man. (TA.)

Q. 2 tavaEolaba tvElb
Q. 2. tavaEolaba: see above.

vaEolabN vElb
vaEolabN [The fox; canis vulpes of Linn.: but in the dial. of Egypt, the jackal; canis aureus of Linn.: the former animal being there called Oabuw AlHuSayoni, as it often is by the Arabs of other countries:] a certain beast of prey; (TA;) well known: (S, K:) applied to the male and the female; so that one says vaEolabN cakarN and vaEolabN OunovaI; but if one would designate the male by a single word applying to it only, he says vuEolubaAnN↓, with damm to the v and l: (IAmb, Msb:) or the former applies to the female: (K:) or the female is called vaEolabapN↓; (Ks, S, Msb, K;) and the male, vuEolubaAnN↓ (Ks, S, K) and vaEolabN, (K,) [accord. to some,] like as one says EaqorabapN [and EuqorubaAnN] and EaqorabN: (Msb:) or vaEolabN is the male; and the female is called vuEaAlapu↓: (Az, TA: [but see this word is art. vEl:]) the pl. of vElb is vaEaAlibu and vaEaAlK, (K,) accord. to Lh: but ISd disapproves of this [latter pl.]; and Sb does not allow it except in poetry. (TA.) F charges J with error in citing, as a proof that vuEolubaAnN↓ signifies the male, the following verse:
OarabRN yabuwlu AlvRuEolubaAnu biraOosihi
laqado calRa mano baAlato Ealayohi AlvRaEaAlibu
[Is he a Lord, upon whose head the he-fox makes water? (the b in brOsh being syn. with EalaI: so in the Mughnee, in art. b:) Vile indeed is he upon whom the foxes make water!] said by a man who was keeper of an idol, on seeing a he-fox make water upon it: but in this, F opposes also Ks and others; and it is asserted by several authorities that the correct reading of the word vElbAn in a trad. whereby F attempts to establish his charge against J is not vaEolabaAni, dual. of vaEolabN, as he pronounces it to be, but vuEolabaAni, which is said to be the masc. of vaEolabN, like as OufoEuwaAnN and EuqorubaAnN are mascs. of OafoEFI and EaqorabN. (TA.) ― -b2- daMCu AlvRaEolabi [for which Golius seems to have found in a copy of the K dawaMCu AlvRaEolabi] A well-known disease, [namely, alopecia,] (S, K,) in consequence of which the hair falls off. (S.) ― -b3- Einabu AlvRaEolabi [Fox-grape: rendered by Golius “ uvæ vulpinæ, i. e. solanum: ” but now applied by some to the gooseberry: and the solanum nigrum, or gardennightshade, is now commonly called Einabu AlcRiYobi:] a certain astringent, cooling plant: seven (or, as in one copy of the K, nine) HabRaAt [which here seems to mean berries] thereof, swallowed, are a cure for the jaundice (AlyaraqaAn), and stop pregnancy, (K, TA,) like the berries of the xirowaE [or castor-oil-plant], for the year, or, as some say, absolutely. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A hole, or aperture, (juHor,) whence rain-water flows. (TA.) [And particularly,] The outlet, hole, or aperture, (maxoraj, S and Msb, or juHor, K, or vaqob, TA,) whence the rain-water flows from the place where dates are dried. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And The place whence the water flows forth (L, K) from, (L, TA,) or to, (K, [probably a mistake,]) a watering-trough or tank. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- The upper extremity of a spear-shaft that enters into the head thereof. (S, K.) ― -b2- The lowest part of a palm-shoot when it is cut from [the root of] the mother-tree: or the lowest part of a [shoot such as is termed] rAkuwb, on the trunk of a palm-tree. (AA, K.)

vaEolabapN vElb vElbh vElbp
vaEolabapN: see vaEolabN. ＝ -A2- Also The os coccygis, or tail-bone; syn. EuSoEuSN. (K.) ― -b2- And The podex, or the anus; syn. AisotN. (K.)

vuEolubaAnN vElb vElbAn
vuEolubaAnN: see vaEolabN, in three places.

vaEolabiyRapN vElb vElby vElbyh vElbyp
vaEolabiyRapN A running of the horse like the running of the dog. (K.)

voEaAlapu vEAl vEAlh vEAlp
voEaAlapu: see vaEolabN, and see art. vEl.

OaroDN muvaEolibapN c
OaroDN muvaEolibapN A land having vaEaAlib [or foxes]: (S:) or, having many thereof; as also OarDN mavoEalapN; (K;) which is from vuEaAlapN; or it may be from vaEolabN, like maEoqarapN applied to “ a land having many EaqaArib [or scorpions]. ” (S, L.)

1 vagarahu vgr vgrh vgrp
1. vagarahu, (T, A, K,) aor.
vagara
, (K,) inf. n. vagorN, (T,) He broke it; (T, A;) namely, a part of a wall; (A;) he demolished it: this is [said to be] the primary signification: he demolished it, or pulled it down; namely, a wall: (T:) and he broke it (namely, anything, [as a wall and a vessel, &c.,] A) so as to make a gap in it, or a hollow in its edge. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb, K,) He broke his vagor [or front teeth], (S, Msb, K,) or his teeth. (IAar, and TA as from the K.) And vugira, in the pass. form, inf. n. vuguwrN, He (a boy) had his vagor [or front teeth] broken. (Msb.) ― -b3- vagarotu sinRahu I pulled out his tooth. (El-Hujeymee, TA.) And vugira He (a man) had a tooth, or teeth, pulled out. (As, TA.) ― -b4- Also vugira, (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. vagorN, (AZ, Msb,) He (a boy) shed his central milk-teeth, (AZ, S, Mgh, K,) or his vagor [or front teeth]: (AZ, Msb:) or Oavogara↓ has this latter meaning, (A, K,) or AitRagara↓; (As, TA;) and vagira, (K,) or AitRagara↓, (Sh, TA,) or AitRagara↓, (Msb,) signifies he shed his teeth: (Sh, Msb, K:) vugira is said to have this last signification in the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh; and AvRgr↓ and AtRgr↓ are there said to have the contr. signification, explained below [see 8]. (Msb.) ― -b5- vugira also signifies He had his mouth bruised; and so Ouvogira↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- vagara AlvRulomapa, aor.
vagara
, He stopped up, or obstructed, the gap, or breach: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) And vagaronaAhumo We stopped up, or obstructed, against them the gaps, or passes of the mountain; (S, TA;) we stopped up, or obstructed, against them the place of exit, so that they knew not what way to take. (A.)

4 Oavogara
4: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and 8 also, in two places.

8 AitRagara Atgr
8. AitRagara (AZ, Sh, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and AivRagara (AZ, Mgh, Msb) and AidRagara, (K,) originally Aivotagara, (AZ, S, K,) He (a boy) bred his central milkteeth, (S,) or his vagor [or front teeth]; (Sh, * Msb, K;) as also Oavogara↓: (K:) or he bred his teeth after the former ones had fallen out: (AZ, Mgh:) and Oavogara↓, inf. n. UivogaArN, of the measure of Oakorama, inf. n. UikoraAmN, he grew his vagor [or front teeth] after the former ones had fallen out: by some, AvRgr and AtRgr are used specially in relation to a beast: the Benoo-Kiláb thus used the former; not in relation to a boy. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in five places.

vagorN vgr vgrp
vagorN The front teeth; (S, A, K;) syn. mabosimN; (Msb;) described by a poet as eight in number, four upper and four lower: (TA:) afterwards applied to the central incisors: (Msb:) or all the teeth (TA) while they remain in their places of growth, (K, TA,) before they fall out: (TA:) or the teeth, (K, TA,) all of them, whether in their places of growth or not: (TA:) or the mouth: (K:) pl. vuguwrN. (TA.) [Hence, DaHika vagoruhu He laughed so as to show his front teeth, or his teeth.] ― -b2- Any gap, opening, interstice, or open intervening space, (M, K,) in a mountain, or in the bottom of a valley, or in a road along which people pass; (TA;) as also vugorapN↓: (A, * TA:) or the latter signifies a gap, or breach, in a wall &c.; the hollow of the broken edge of a vessel &c.; and its pl. is vugarN. (S.) You say, hecihi madiynapN fiyhiA vugarN↓ This is a city in which are gaps, or breaches. (S.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A frontier-way of access to a country, [in the CK, quruwH is erroneously put for furuwj, the word occurring in its place in MSS. of the K and in the S,] such as is a place of fear; (S, K;) as also vugoruwrN↓: (K:) the part of a country from which the invasion of the enemy is feared; so that it is like a gap in a wall, from
which one fears the invasion of the robber: (Msb:) a place from, or through, which one fears the enemy's coming, in a mountain or fortress: (T, TA:) the frontier of a hostile country: (K:) a place that is a boundary between the countries of the Muslims and the unbelievers: (IAth, TA:) pl. vuguwrN. (Msb.) You say, fulaAnN yasudRu AlvRagora (tropical:) [Such a one stops up, or obstructs, the frontieraccess of the country by his bravery]. (A.) ― -b4- See also vugorapN, in two places. ― -b5- OamosuwA vuguwrFA (tropical:) They became dispersed, or scattered, (JK, A, K,) and lost, or in a state of perdition: (A, K:) sing. vagorN. (JK, K.)

vugorapN vgr vgrh vgrp
vugorapN; pl. vugarN: see vagorN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The pit of the uppermost part of the breast, or chest, between the two collar-bones; (S, M, K;) the pit in the middle of the naHor: pl. as above: (Msb:) in a camel, the pit which is the stabbingplace: and in a horse, [the part] above the juWojuW, (K,) which is the prominent portion of the naHor, between the upper parts of the fahodataAn [or two portions of flesh on the right and left of the breast]. (TA.) ― -b3- A tract, or quarter, of the earth, or of land; (JK, K;) as also vagorN↓. (TA.) You say, maA bitiloka AlvRugorapi mivoluhu There is not, in that tract, or quarter, of the earth, his, or its, like. (TA.) ― -b4- A plain, level, or even, road; (K;) as also vagorN↓: (TA:) or any road that people tread, or pass along, with ease; because they furrow its surface: (T, TA:) pl. as above. (A.) [Hence,] vugaru Almasojidi The ways leading to the mosque: or vugorapu Almasojidi means the upper part of the mosque [app. next to the kibleh]. (TA.) And huwayaxotariqu vugara Almajodi (tropical:) [He travels] the ways of glory. (A.)

vugoruwrN vgrwr
vugoruwrN: see vagorN.

vaAgirapN vAgrh vAgrp
vaAgirapN The root, or lower part, of a tooth: pl. vawaAgiru. (JK.)

mavogarN mvgr
mavogarN The place through which a tooth passes, in the head [or gum]. (TA.)

muvogarN mvgr
muvogarN: see what follows.

vafinapN [The callosity, or callous protuberance, upon] the knee; and what touches the ground, [in the act of lying down,] of [the callosity upon the breast called] the kirokirap and the saEodaAnap, [two words having the same meaning, for the latter of which the K erroneously substitutes the pl. form,] and of [each of the stifle-joints, i. e.,] the roots, or lower parts, of the thighs; of the camel: (M, K: *) pl. vifanN and vifaAnN (M, K) and vifinaAtN: (T, S, M:) the vafinaAt of the camel are the parts that fall upon the ground when the animal lies down, and that become rough, or callous, such as the two knees, &c.; (S;) the parts that are next the ground when the camel lies down, one of them being the kirokirap, with which they are five in number [as explained above]: or, as some say, the vafinap is [only the stifle-joint, i. e.,] the joint between the thigh and the sAq [or leg properly so called], internally, [meaning anteriorly,] and [the knee, i. e.,] the joint between the shank and the arm: (T:) or, accord. to some, any part that is next the ground, of any quadruped, when he lies down like the camel and like the sheep. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) [The stifle-joint, i. e.,] the joint between each thigh and leg, internally, [meaning anteriorly,] of a horse. (M, K.) ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) The knee of a man: or [so accord. to the M, but in the K “ and, ”] the place of union of the shank and thigh: (M, K:) [or the lower portion of the fore part of the knee, which becomes callous in consequence of much kneeling: see 3, first sentence. Hence,] 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Wahb Er-Rásibee was surnamed cuw AlvRafinaAti (S, M, K *) from his much praying, (M,) because long prostration produced an [indurating] effect upon his vfnAt: (S, K:) and 'Alee Ibn-El-Hoseyn Ibn-'Alee, (K, TA,) known by the appellation of Zeyn-el-'Ábìdeen, (TA,) was [likewise] so surnamed, (K, TA,) because those parts of him upon which he prostrated himself were like the vfnp of the camel in consequence of his much praying: (TA:) so too was 'Alee Ibn-AbdAllah Ibn-El-'Abbás. (A, K.) ― -b4- AlvRafinapu mina AljulRapi, (K, [in some of the copies of the K AlHulRap, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,]) or vafinataA AljulRapi, (AHn, M,) The two edges of the lower part of the julRap, (AHn, M, K,) [meaning,] of the dates [contained in the receptacle thus called; app. because the dates in the edges become more dry and hard than the main portion].
