[See also Kur vii. 7 and xxiii. 104.] ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy, or weighty, as meaning onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome.] You say, vaqula Alqawolu (tropical:) The saying was [heavy, or weighty, &c.; or] unpleasant to be heard. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur vii. 186, vaqulato fiI AlsRamewaAti waAlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) It (the time of the resurrection) will be momentous, or formidable, [in the heavens and on the earth, or] to the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, (Bd, Jel,) to the angels and men and genii; app. alluding to the wisdom shown in concealing it: (Bd:) or it means the knowledge thereof [is difficult]: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or it is occult, or hidden. (Kt, TA.) [vaqula is also said of a word, and of a sound, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: see 2. And of an affair, or action, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was afflictive, grievous, troublesome, or difficult. In these and similar senses, it is trans. by means of EalaI: you say, vaqula Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy, weighty, onerous, &c., to him. In like manner also it is said of food, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion.] You say also, vaqula samoEuhu (tropical:) [His hearing was, or became, heavy; or] his hearing partially went. (K, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, heavy in sickness, or disease: [and in like manner, in his sleep:] the verb is thus, with damm to the q; though said in the K to be vaqila, like fariHa, as meaning his disease became violent; (Fet-h el-Báree, TA;) not improbably through error or inadvertence. (MF.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit, or intelligence; stupid.] You say, yavoqulu Eano qubuwli maA yuloqaI Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) [He is averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or is
slow to receive, &c., what is said to him]. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, said of the Earofaj, and of the vumaAm, (tropical:) Its shoots became luxuriant, or succulent, or sappy. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- vaqalahu, (JK, S, K,) biyadihi, (K,) aor.
vaqula
, (TA,) inf. n. vaqolN, (K,) He tried the weight of it, (JK, S, K,) namely, a thing, (K,) or a sheep or goat, (S,) by lifting it [with his hand] to see if it were heavy or light. (S, TA.) ― -b2- vaqala AlXRaIoCu AlXRaIoCa fiI Alwazoni, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) The thing surpassed the thing in weight; outweighed it. (PS.) ― -b3- See also 2.

2 vqRlhu vql vqlh vqlp
2. vqRlhu, inf. n. tavoqiylN, He, or it, made it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]: (K:) tvqyl is the contr. of taxofiyfN; (S;) and signifies the making heavy in weight [&c.]; as also vaqolN [inf. n. of vaqalahu↓]. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He made it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: and particularly a word by uttering hemzeh with its true, or proper, sound, which is commonly termed taHoqiyqu Alhamozapi, and opposed to taxofiyfuhaA; and by making a single consonant double; and by making a quiescent consonant movent: often occurring in these senses in lexicons and grammars: opposed to xafRafahu.]

4 Avqlhu Ovql Ovqlh Avqlh Avqlp vql
4. Avqlhu He, or it, (a load, S, or a thing, Msb,) [burdened him: or] burdened him heavily: (K:) or beyond his power; overburdened him. (JK, Msb, TA. *) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) In the latter sense, said also of a debt: and of sickness, or a disease: (JK:) or, said of sickness, or a disease, and of sleep, and of meanness, or sordidness, (tropical:) it [burdened him,] overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (K, * TA, * TK.) ＝ -A2- Avqlt, said of a woman, She became gravid; her burden became heavy in her belly: (S:) or she had a burden, (Akh, S, and Bd in vii. 189,) by reason of the greatness of the child in her belly: (Bd, Jel:) or her pregnancy became apparent, or manifest; as also vaqulato↓. (K.)

6 tavaAoqala
6: [tvAql EalaI XaIoCK He pressed heavily, or bore his weight, upon a thing: see mutavaAqilN.] ― -b2- tvAqlwA (assumed tropical:) [They were heavy, sluggish, or spiritless:] they did not rise and hasten to the fight when commanded to do so. (IDrd, K.) And tvAql UilaI AlOaroDi, (S and K in art. ArD, &c.,) and AivRaAqala AlI AlrD, the former being the original form of the verb, (Bd and Jel in ix. 38,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, slow, or sluggish, (Bd, Jel,) averse from warring against the unbelievers, (Jel,) and inclining to the earth, or ground; (Bd, Jel;) or propending thereto. (Bd.) And AivRaAqala UilaI AldRunoyaA (assumed tropical:) He propended to the present world. (TA.) And tvAql Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He was heavy, or sluggish, and held back from it. (K.)

10 Astvqlhu Ostvqlh Astvqlh Astvqlp Qstvql Qstvqlh
10. Astvqlhu contr. of AisotaxafRahu; (S and K and TA in art. xf;) He deemed it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He deemed it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: often occurring in this sense in lexicons and grammars.] ― -b3- Ausotuvoqila nawomFA (assumed tropical:) [He was overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep: and in like manner, maraDFA, by sickness or disease: and luWomFA, by meanness or sordidness: see its pass. part. n., below]. (JK.)

viqolN vql
viqolN Weight: or a weight: syn. wazonN: (S, Msb, KL:) pl. OavoqaAlN. (S.) So in the phrase OaEoTihi viqolahu [Give thou him his, or its, weight]. (S, Msb.) See also mivoqaAlN. You say also, OaloqaI Ealayohi viqolahu or viqalahu↓ [He threw upon him his weight: see mivoqaAlN, last sentence: and see jiromN]. (S in art. Awq &c., accord. to different copies.) ― -b2- And A load, or burden: (KL:) or a heavy load or burden: pl. as above. (K.) wataHomilu OavoqaAlakumo, in the Kur xvi. 7, means And they carry your loads, or burdens; (Bd;) or your heavy loads or burdens. (TA.) ― -b3- OavoqaAlN (as pl. of viqolN, K, or of vaqalN↓, Bd) also signifies (tropical:) The treasures, or buried treasures, of the earth: and its dead, or corpses. (K, TA, and Bd and Jel in xcix. 2.) ― -b4- Also (as pl. of viqolN, K) (tropical:) Sins. (JK, K.) So in the saying in the Kur [xxix. 12], walayaHomilunRa OavoqaAlahumo waOavoqaAlFA maEa OavoqaAlihimo (tropical:) [And they shall assuredly bear their sins, and sins (of others whom they have seduced) with their sins]. (TA.)

vaqalN vql
vaqalN A thing, or things, that a man has with him, of such things as burden him: (Ham p. 295:) [and particularly] the household-goods, or furniture and utensils, (El-Fárábee, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, Ham ubi suprà, and Bd in xcix. 2,) and (accord. to El-Fárábee, Msb) the household and kindred and party, or domestics, or servants, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, and Ham,) of a man, (Ham,) or of a traveller: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [or the travelling-apparatus and baggage and train, of a man:] pl. OavoqaAlN; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) with which vaqilapN↓ is syn., (JK, S, K,) as are also vaqalapN↓ and viqolapN↓ and vaqolapN↓ and viqalapN↓; (K;) as meaning all the household-goods or furniture and utensils of persons going on a journey. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also viqolN. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man: (Ham ubi suprà:) as, for instance, (tropical:) the books and writing-reeds of the learned man: every craftsman has what is thus termed. (TA.) By the saying
kilaA vaqalayonaA TaAmiEN biganiymapK
the author thereof, Iyás Et-Tá-ee, means Each of our two armies, the possessors of the vaqalaAni [or apparatus, or weapons, &c., of war, is longing for spoil]: or an army may be termed vaqalN because it is heavy in assault. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b4- Anything held in high estimation, in much request, and preserved with care. (K, TA.) Hence the trad., UinRiI taArikN fiykumu AlvRaqalayoni kitaAba QllRehi waEitoratiI [Verily I am leaving among you the two objects of high estimation and of care, the Book of God, and my kindred, or near kindred]: (K:) or they are thus called because of the heaviness of acting in the manner required by them: (Th, TA:) or as being likened to the requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b5- Also Eggs of the ostrich; because he who takes them rejoices in them, and they are food. (TA.) ― -b6- AlvRaqalaAni Mankind and the jinn or genii; (S, Msb, K;) because, by the discrimination that they possess, they excel other animate beings. (TA.) It may also mean The Arabs and the foreigners: or mankind and other animate beings. (Ham ubi suprà.)

viqalN vql
viqalN Heaviness; weight, or weightiness; ponderousness; gravity; contr. of xifRapN: (S, K, and Er-Rághib:) and preponderance: in its primary acceptation, relating to corporeal objects: then, to ideal objects. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See vaqula, throughout.]) See also viqolN. ― -b2- fiI Oucunihi viqalN (tropical:) [In his ear is a heaviness, or dulness,] is said of him whose hearing is not good; as though he were averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or slow to receive, &c., what is said to him. (TA.)

vaqolapN vql vqlh vqlp
vaqolapN: see vaqalN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A fit of drowsiness, or of slumber, that overcomes one: (JK, M, K:) and (tropical:) a heaviness experienced in the chest, (K, TA,) or in the body, (TA,) from food: as also vaqalapN↓: (K, TA:) or the former, or ↓the latter, (accord. to different copies of the S,) (assumed tropical:) a heaviness and languor in the body: (S:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) a heaviness that is experienced on the heart. (JK.)

viqolapN vql vqlh vqlp
viqolapN: see vaqalN.

vaqalapN vql vqlh vqlp
vaqalapN: see vaqalN: ― -b2- and see vaqolapN, in three places.

vaqilapN vql vqlh vqlp
vaqilapN: see vaqalN.

viqalapN vql vqlh vqlp
viqalapN: see vaqalN.

vaqaAlN vqAl vqyl
vaqaAlN: see vaqiylN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a woman, (JK, S, K,) Heavy; (S;) large in the hinder part, or posteriors: (JK, * S, * K, TA:) or heavy (K, TA) in an ideal sense. (TA.)

vuqaAlN vqAl vqyl
vuqaAlN: see vaqiylN.

vaqiylN vqyl
vaqiylN part. n. of vaqula; (S, Msb, K;) Heavy, weighty, or ponderous: (S, K, and Er-Rághib:) and so in relation to another thing; preponderant: primarily applied to a corporeal thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and vaqaAlN↓ and vuqaAlN↓ signify the same: (K:) pl. viqaAlN and vuqolN and vuqalaMCu [which last, however, seems to be applied only to rational beings, agreeably with analogy]. (K.) ― -b2- [Like its verb,] it is also applied to an ideal thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Thus it signifies (assumed tropical:) Heavy, or weighty, in the sense of onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome: momentous, or formidable: difficult: heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear; applied to a word and a sound; and particularly to a word in which a single consonant is made double, and to one in which a quiescent consonant is made movent, like muvaqRalN↓: heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion: heavy applied to the hearing: see the verb.] qawolFA vaqiylFA, in the Kur [lxxiii. 5], means (assumed tropical:) A heavy, or weighty, saying. (TA.) AlnRuwnu AlvRaqiylapu means (assumed tropical:) [The heavy-sounding n; as in yafoEalanRa &c.;] the contr. of Alxafiyfapu. (TA in art. xf.) ― -b3- It is also applied to a man, (JK,) meaning (tropical:) [Heavy in sickness, or disease; or] suffering a violent disease: (K:) [and (assumed tropical:) heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit,
or intelligence; stupid:] and so is musotavoqalN↓: (JK:) which also means, particularly, (assumed tropical:) overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep (nawomFA), (JK, * K, * TK,) and by sickness or disease (maraDFA), and by meanness or sordidness (luWomFA). (K.) viqaAlu AlnRaAsi [expressly said in the TA to be with kesr, but in the CK, erroneously, vuqAl,] and vuqalaMCu AlnAs mean (assumed tropical:) Those men whose company is disliked; (K;) whom others deem heavy: each is pl. of vaqiylN. (TA.) One says, Oanota vaqiylN EalaI julasaAYika (assumed tropical:) [Thou art heavy, or dull, or unwelcome, to thy companions with whom thou sittest]. (TA.) And (to him who is vaqiyl, TA in art. nsm,) maA Oanota UilRaA vaqiylu AlZRilRi baAridu AlnRasiymi (assumed tropical:) [Thou art no other than one who casts a gloom upon others, and chills them: lit., heavy of shade, or shadow; cold of breeze]. (TA.) vaqiylN, applied to a man, is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes, in praise: (Er-Rághib, TA:) used in praise, it signifies (assumed tropical:) Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (Kull.) Applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) Slow; (Kull;) and so vaqaAlN↓ applied to a camel; (K;) a meaning also assigned to vafaAlN, with f; (TA;) and muvoqalN↓, applied to a horse or the like. (JK.) AinofiruwA xifaAfFA waviqaAlFA, in the Kur [ix. 41], means (assumed tropical:) [Go ye forth to fight] prompt and not prompt: (Katádeh, Bd, Jel, TA:) or whether moving be easy to you or difficult: (Bd, * TA:) or riding and walking: or lightly armed and heavily armed: or healthy and sick: (Bd:) or strong and weak: (Jel:) or rich and poor: (Jel, TA:) or young and old. (TA.)

vaAqilN vAql
vaAqilN A deenár of full weight; (Z;) not deficient: (S, K:) pl. vawaAqilu. (S, Z, K.) ― -b2- OaSobaHa vaAqilFA (assumed tropical:) He became, or became in the morning, heavy by reason of sickness, or disease. (Aboo-Nasr, K, TA.)

Oavoqalu c
Oavoqalu More [and most] heavy. (TA.)

muvoqalN mvql
muvoqalN Heavily burdened: (TA:) or burdened beyond his power; overburdened. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Weighed down, or oppressed, by sickness, or disease, (JK,) and by debt. (JK, Er-Rághib.) ― -b3- See also vaqiylN.

muvoqilN mvql
muvoqilN, applied to a woman, Gravid; whose burden has become heavy in her belly: (S:) or whose pregnancy has become apparent, or manifest. (K.)

muvaqRalN mvql
muvaqRalN: see vaqiylN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Ill received; disapproved; not rendered an object of love to hearts. (Ham p. 37.)

muvaqRalapN mvql mvqlh mvqlp
muvaqRalapN A stone of marble; (JK;) a piece of marble by which a carpet is made heavy: (K:) by rule it should be with kesr to the q. (TA.)

mivoqaAlN mvqAl
mivoqaAlN The weight (miyzaAn, JK, S, K, or wazon, Msb, TA, and Jel in iv. 44 and x. 62 and xxi. 48, or zinap, TA) of a thing, (JK, S, Msb, K,) of the like thereof (mino mivolihi [but why this is added I do not see]); (S, Msb, K;) [i. e.] its equal in weight; (PS, and Bd in x. 62;) its quantity (miqodaAr). (Bd in xxi. 48.) maA yaEozubu Eano rabRika mino mivoqaAli carRapK, in the Kur x. 62, means There is not hidden from thy Lord aught of the weight of the smallest ant: (Jel:) or a thing equal in weight to a small ant; or to the motes that are seen in a ray of the sun that enters through an aperture. (Bd.) ― -b2- A thing with which one weights; as also viqolN↓; i. e., any of the weights of the balance. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- A certain weight, of which the quantity is well known; (JK;) a dirhem and three sevenths of a dirhem; (Msb, and K in art. mk;) i. e., the seventh part of ten dirhems: (Msb:) or [a dirhem and a half; so in the present day; i. e.,] seventy-two sha'eerehs: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or twenty keeráts. (Hidáyeh, TA.) ― -b4- [A certain coin;] i. q. diynaArN, q. v.; (Msb in art. dnr;) a mivoqaAl of gold: pl. mavaAqiylu. (S, K.) ― -b5- OaloqaI Ealayohi mavaAqiylahu He threw upon him his weight, or burden; syn. maWuwnatahu [perhaps meaning the burden of supporting him]. (Aboo-Nasr, S, K.) [See also viqolN.]

mutavaAqilN mtvAql
mutavaAqilN Bearing one's weight upon a thing: whence the saying, waTiYahu waToOapa AlmutavaAqili [He trod upon him, or it, with the tread of him who bears his weight, or presses heavily]. (TA.)

musotavoqalN mstvql
musotavoqalN: see vaqiylN.

1 vakilatohu vklth vkltp
1. vakilatohu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
vakala
, (Msb,) inf. n. vakalN, (S, Msb,) or vukolN, (Mgh,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and vakolN, (Mgh,) [or this last is also a simple subst.,] She (a mother) lost him, or became bereft of him; namely, her child, (S, Mgh, Msb,) by death: (Mgh:) and vakilahu, aor.
vakala
, (K,) inf. n. vakalN, (TA,) he lost him; namely, a friend, or person beloved, or a child. (K.) vakilatoka OumRuka [lit. meaning May thy mother be bereft of thee] is an imprecation against him to whom it is addressed, not said with the desire of its having effect, but on an occasion of vehement love, like laA OabaA laka, [and qaAtalaka QllRehu,] &c. (Har p. 165.)

4 Oavokalato c
4. Oavokalato A state of bereavement clave to her; (K;) namely, a woman: or she became in a state of bereavement. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OavokalahaA QllRehu waladahaA God made her to be bereft of her child [by death]. (Msb, K.) And Avklhu QllRehu OumRahu God made him to be bereft of his mother [by death]. (S.)

vakolN vkl
vakolN: see what next follows.

vukolN vkl
vukolN The loss, or the state of being bereft, of a child [by death], (S, Msb, K,) or of a friend, or person beloved; (K;) i. e., a woman's loss of her child; (S, Msb;) as also vakalN↓ [which is the inf. n. by general consent], (S, K,) and vakolN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlEuquwqu vukolu mano lamo yavokalN [Undutiful treatment of a parent is (like) the bereavement of him who is not (really) bereft of his child]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Death: and a state of perdition or destruction. (K.)

vakalN vkl
vakalN: see vukolN.

vakolaAn vklAn
vakolaAn; fem. vakolaI and vakolaAnapN: see vaAkilN.

vakuwlN vkwl
vakuwlN: see vaAkilN. ― -b2- falaApN vakuwlN (tropical:) A desert in which the traveller becomes lost. (K, TA.)

vaAkilN vAkl
vaAkilN, applied to a man, Bereft of a child, or of a friend, or person beloved; as also vakolaAnu↓ or vakolaAnN [with or without tenween, as is shown by the two forms of the fem. mentioned in what follows, but generally without]: (K:) and applied to a woman; (S, Msb, K;) and sometimes vaAkilapN; (Msb;) as also vakolaI (S, Msb, K) and vakolaAnapN, (IAar, K,) which is rare, (K,) and vakuwlN↓; (S, K;) meaning bereft of her child [by death]; (S, Msb;) pl. (of vaAkilN, TA, [and of vaAkilapN,]) vawaAkilu, [and of vAkl also vakolaI, as is implied in the TA voce EuborN,] and (of vakolaI, TA) vakaAlaI. (Msb, TA.)

UivokaAlN AvkAl
UivokaAlN and OuvokuwlN↓ i. q. EivokaAlN (S, K) and EuvokuwlN, i. e., The fruit-stalk (XimoraAx) upon which are the ripening dates: pl. OavaAkilu, [app. a contraction of OavaAkiylu, like EavaAkiylu,] occurring in poetry. (S.) These two words are mentioned here by J and Sgh, and F has followed them; but they should be mentioned among words whose first radical letter is hemzeh, for the O is a radical, substituted for E. (TA.)

OuvokuwlN c
OuvokuwlN: see what next precedes.

muvokilN mvkl
muvokilN A woman whose state of bereavement is constant: (K:) or who is in a state of bereavement: (TA:) pl. mavaAkiylu (K) [or this is pl. of mivokaAlN]. Hence, nisaMCu AlguzaApi mavaAkiylu [The wives of the warriors are constantly bereft, or often bereft, of their husbands]. (TA.) ― -b2- qaSiydapN muvokilapN (tropical:) An ode in which bereavement is mentioned. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Z, K.)

rumoHuhu lilowaAlidaAti mavokalapN rmHh llwAldAt mvklh rmHh llwAldAt mvklp
rumoHuhu lilowaAlidaAti mavokalapN [His spear is a cause of bereavement to mothers] (S, K) is a saying similar to Alwaladu maboxalapN wamajobanapN [explained in art. bxl]. (S.)

mivokaAlN mvkAl
mivokaAlN A woman much, or often, bereft of her children: (Msb, TA:) pl. mavaAkilu (TA) [or mavaAkiylu: see muvokilN]. ― -b2- And A she-camel that is accustomed to lose her young by death or by slaughter or by gift: pl. mavaAkiylu. (Ham p. 746.)

1 valRa vl
1. valRa, (T, S, K,) aor.
valula
, inf. n. valRN, (T,) He put [or poured] back the earth into a grave, and a well, after digging it: (T:) or he poured the earth into a well, (S, K,) &c. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) He poured forth pieces of money. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and valovala↓; (M, K;) He moved, or put in motion, with his hand, or he broke at one of its sides, [app. so as to make it pour down, or fall,] a quantity of earth collected together, or a sand-heap, (M, K,) or a house: (O, TA:) or he dug it. (TA.) ― -b4- And the former, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (S, M,) and so the inf. n., (M, TA,) He threw down, or demolished, a house, (S, M, K,) by digging beneath the wall, and then pushing, so that it fell in ruins: (S, TA:) and he demolished, and broke, a thing. (M.) ― -b5- [Hence,] valRa QllRehu EaroXahumo (tropical:) God destroyed their dominion:
and vulRa EaroXuhumo (tropical:) Their might, or power, departed: (S:) or valRa QllRehu EaroXahu (tropical:) God caused him to die; or caused his dominion, or his might, or power, to depart: (K, TA:) and vulRa EaroXuhu, inf. n. valRN, (tropical:) His means of support became destroyed, and ceased; (M, A; *) or he became abased, or in an abject condition; (IDrd, M;) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, it means OusoqiTato vlRp minohu [perhaps a company of men (vulRapN) was made to fall away from him]: (TA:) El-'Otbee says that ErX here has two meanings; namely, a throne, and a booth, or shed, constructed for shade. (TA. See art. ErX.) You say also, vulRa EaroXuhu and EuroXuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was slain: and a poet says, of a sword, valRa EuroXayohi, meaning (assumed tropical:) [It severed] the base of his neck; the part where his neck was set on his back. (IDrd, M.) ― -b6- And valRa, (As, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (As, S, M,) inf. n. valRN (As, S, M, K) and valalN, (As, S, K,) He killed, or destroyed, (As, S, M, K,) a man, (As, S,) or men. (M, K.) And vulRa He died, or perished. (T.) ― -b7- valRa AlbiYora, (M, K,) aor.
valula
, inf. n. valRN, (M,) He took, or cast, forth the earth from the well; (M, K;) and the mud from the bottom of the well. (M.) ― -b8- valRa AlwiEaMCa, aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding case, He took what was in the receptacle; as also AvtlRhu↓; the latter from Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.) ＝ -A2- valRati AldRaAbRapu, (S, K,) and valRa AlHaAfiru, (M, O,) aor.
valula
[irregularly], (S, TA,) inf. n. valRN, (TA,) The beast, and the solid-hoofed animal, dunged. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- And valRa He became rich, or in a state of competence. (T.)

4 AvlR Ovl Avl vl
4. AvlR He (a man, S) abounded in what is termed valRap, (S, K,) which may mean either wool or a flock of sheep or goats: both these meanings are assigned to it in this case by Z. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AvlRhu He ordered, or commanded, the repairing of it; (M;) or the repairing of what had been thrown down, or demolished, of it. (IAar, S, K.)

5. tvlRl It (a house) became thrown down, or demolished; (K;) as also AnvlR↓: (TA:) or it (a house) became thrown down, or demolished, and it fell by degrees, part after part. (M.) And tavalRalati AlrRakiyRapu The well became demolished. (TA.)

7 AnvlR Onvl Anvl QnvAl Qnvl
7. AnvlR It (a thing) poured forth, or became poured forth. (TA.) ― -b2- AinovalRuwA i. q. AinovaAluwA [app. as meaning They poured themselves forth]. (K.) You say, AnvlRwA Ealayohi They poured forth, or down, upon him, or against him. (Z, TA in art. vlm.) ― -b3- See also 5.

8 Uivotalala
8: see 1, near the end.

R. Q. 1 valovala vlvl
R. Q. 1. valovala: see 1, near the beginning.

valRapN vl vlh vlp
valRapN The earth that is taken forth from a well: (T, S, M, K:) and the mud that is taken forth from the bottom of a well: (M:) and the space upon which is cast the earth taken forth from a well, around its mouth; which space, when the well has been dug in a place that is not the property of any one, belongs exclusively to the owner of the well: (A 'Obeyd, T:) pl. vulalN. (K.) ― -b2- valRapN mavoluwlapN↓ A grave (turobapN) filled up with earth, after it has been dug. (T.) ＝ -A2- A thing that is made of clay, or mud, (M,) like a manaArap [q. v.], (K,) in the desert, for the sake of its shade. (M, K. [Erroneously written by Golius and Freytag mavalRapN, and compared to maZalRapN.]) ＝ -A3- Wool, (T, S, M, K,) alone: (M, K:) or a portion of wool collected together: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and wool and goats' hair (XaEar) and camels' hair (wabar) together; (Aboo-Yoosuf, T, S, K;) but not the second of these alone, nor the third alone: (Aboo-Yoosuf, T, S:) or it signifies camels' hair (wbr) also: (T:) or wool and XEr and wbr together; but none of these alone. (M.) kisaMCN jiyRidu AlvRalRapi is said to mean A ksAC of good wool: (S, M:) and Habolu valRapK, a rope of wool. (S.) It is said in a prov., laA taEodamu SanaAEN valRapF [A clever woman is not without wool to spin or weave when she has nothing else to do]: applied to a skilful man. (TA.) And you say, Einoda fulaAnK valRapN kaviyrapN, meaning Such a one has much wool and goats' hair (XEr) and camels' hair (wbr). (Aboo-Yoosuf, S.) [Hence,] fulaAnN kaviyru AlvRalRapi [sometimes] means (tropical:) Such a one has much hair on his body. (TA.) ― -b2- A flock of sheep or goats, (T, M, K,) whether many or few: (M:) or many thereof: (M, K:) or specially a flock of sheep: or sheep, absolutely: (M:) or a numerous flock of sheep: (ISk, T, S, K:) and numerous sheep and goats together: many goats are not thus called; but are called HayolapN: (Aboo-Yoosuf, S, M:) pl. vilalN, (S, M, K,) which is extr., (M,) and vilaAlN. (M, K.) ― -b3- Many pieces of money; or much money; (M, K;) as also vulRapN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A4- In relation to the times of camels' coming to water, (fiI mawaAridi AlUibili, TA, [in the copies of the K, fI is omitted, and mawaAridu is put for mawaAridi,]) The interval of two days, or keeping from water during two days, between two drinkings. (K, TA. [The word to which this signification is assigned is erroneously written by Golius and Freytag mavalRapN; and explained as meaning “Locus ubi aquantur cameli postquam per biduum non biberint.”])

vulRapN vl vlh vlp
vulRapN A party of men; (T;) a company of men: (S, M, K:) or a numerous company. (Bd in lvii. 13.) You say, fulaAnN laA yaforuqu bayona AlvRalRapi waAlvRulRapi [Such a one will not distinguish] between a flock of sheep or goats and a company of men. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- See also valRapN.

vilRapN vl vlh vlp
vilRapN Death; or a state of perdition or destruction; (K;) and so valalN↓; (S, M, K;) which latter is also an inf. n. of valRa signifying “ he killed, ” or “ destroyed: ” (As, S, K:) pl. of the former vilalN. (K.)

vulRaI vlI vly
vulRaI (tropical:) Might, power, or elevated condition, perishing, or passing away. (K, TA.)

valalN vll vlp
valalN: see vlRapN.

muvilRN mvl
muvilRN A man (S, M) abounding in what is termed valRap. (S, M, K. [See 4, OavalRu, mentioned by Golius with this word, as syn. therewith, and as from the S and K, is not in either of those Lexicons.])

muhorN mivalRN mhr mvl
muhorN mivalRN [A colt that dungs much]. (M. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed.])

muvalRilN mvll
muvalRilN Collecting wealth, (Ibn-' Abbád, K,) and disposing it well, or putting it into a good state or condition. (Ibn-' Abbád, TA.)

mavoluwlN mvlwl
mavoluwlN A house thrown down, or demolished. (TA. [See 1.]) ― -b2- See also valRapN, second sentence.

1 valabahu vlb vlbh vlbp
1. valabahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
valiba
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. valobN (T, S, M, A, Msb) and mavolabN, (T,) He blamed him; reprehended him; found fault with him; imputed to him, or charged him with, a fault, vice, or the like: (M, A, Msb, K:) or he charged him plainly, or openly, with a fault, vice, or the like; (S;) spoke against him; (TA;) censured him, reproached him, detracted from his reputation, or impugned his character: (S, Msb:) or he blamed him severely; and assailed him with his tongue; as is done in punishings and the like. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- valabahu, (M, K,) inf. n. valobN, (M,) also signifies He drove him (a man, M) away; expelled him; or put him at a distance, away, or far away. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b3- And He turned it (a thing, M) upside down, or over, or inside out; or changed its manner of being, or state. (M, K.) ― -b4- And I. q. valamahu: (M, K:) formed from the latter by substitution of b for m. (M.) ＝ -A2- valiba, (M,) inf. n. valabN, (M, K,) It (one's skin, M, or a garment, TK) was, or became, dirty, or filthy: (M, K:) and it (a thing, TK) was, or became, contracted. (K, TK.) ― -b2- Also It was, or became, broken in the edge or middle, [like valima,] and split, or cracked. (KL.)

2 vlRb vlb
2. vlRb, (As, S, M,) inf. n. tavoliybN, (S,) He (a camel) became such as is termed vilob. (As, S, M.)

vilobN vlb
vilobN Blamed; reprehended; found fault with; charged with a fault, vice, or the like; as also valibN↓; applied to a man. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also A camel extremely old, or old and weak, (M, A,) and having his teeth much broken: (M:) or a camel whose canine teeth are broken (S, K) much (K) by reason of extreme old age, or age and weakness, and the hair of whose tail has fallen off by degrees: (S, K:) fem. with p; (S, M, K;) but some disallow this, and say that the female is termed naAbN: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OavolaAbN (M, K) and [of mult.] vilabapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- Hence, (A,) (tropical:) A man extremely old, or old and weak, (A, TA,) whose teeth are much broken: (TA:) or an aged man; a man advanced in years: (IAar, M, K:) [said to be] of the dial. of Hudheyl; but IAar mentions it without assigning it to the dial. of any particular tribe of the Arabs. (M.) ― -b4- Also A camel that does not impregnate. (M, K. *) ― -b5- See also what next follows.

valibN vlb
valibN: see vilobN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a spear, (S, M, A, K, but in a copy of the A written vilobN↓,) Much notched, or broken in the edges
[of the head]: (S, M, K:) or weak, or weak and soft. (A.) You say vilobN EalaI vilobK wabiyadihi valibN [An extremely old, or old and weak, man, whose teeth are much broken, upon a camel in the like condition, and having in his hand a spear that is much notched, or weak, or weak and soft]. (A, TA.)

vaAlibapN AlXRawaI c
vaAlibapN AlXRawaI A woman having cracked, or chapped, feet: (S, K:) from valbN as an epithet applied to a spear. (S.)

OavolabN c
OavolabN and UivolibN, (Fr, T, S, M, K,) the former of which is the more common, (Fr, T,) Dust, or earth; and stones: (Fr, T, M, K:) or small fragments, or particles, of stones, (S, K,) and of dust or earth: (S:) or stone (A' Obeyd, Sh, T) in the dial. of El-Hijáz: and dust, or earth, in the dial. of Temeem: (T:) and El-Hejeree says, AlOavolamu is like AlOavolabu; but [ISd says,] whether it be formed by substitution or be a dial. var., I know not. (M, TA.) One says, bifiyhi AlOavolabu and AlUivolibu In his mouth are, or be, dust, or earth, and stones; (Fr, T;) or, particles of stones and of dust or earth. (S.) Lh mentions the phrase AlOavolaba laka or AlUivoliba [Dust, or earth, and stones, be thy lot]; and AltRuraAba: and he says that the noun is thus put in the accus. case, as though the phrase were an imprecation [of the ordinary kind]: he means, as though the noun were an inf. n. used in an imprecation; though it is a simple subst. (M.) liloEaAhiri AlUivolibu or AlOavolabu, occurring in a trad., means For the adulterer, or fornicator, stone (AlHajaru [but see this word, and see also art. Ehr]): or dust, or earth: or small stones. (TA.)

mivolabN mvlb
mivolabN Accustomed to blame, reprehend, or find fault. (A, TA.)

mavolabapN mvlbh mvlbp
mavolabapN (S, M, Msb, K) and mavolubapN (M, K) A fault, vice, or the like: (S, M, * K: *) or [properly] a cause of [blame or] reviling: (Msb:) pl. mavaAlibu. (S, A, Msb.) You say, maA Earafotu fiI fulaAnK mavolabapF [I have not known in such a one a fault, or vice, or cause of blame, &c.]. (A, TA.)

1 valava Alqawoma vlv Alqwm
1. valava Alqawoma, aor.
valuva
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. valovN, (TA,) He took the third of the goods, or property, of the people, or company of men. (S, M, Msb, K.) And vulivati AltRarikapu The property left at death had a third of it taken. (A.) And valava, aor.
valiva
, [but in this case it seems that it should be
valuva
, as above,] is also said to signify He slew a third. (L.) ― -b2- valava Alqawoma, (T, S, K,) or AlAivonayoni, (Fr, T, M,) or AlrRajulayoni, (Msb,) aor.
valiva
, (S, M, Msb, K,) [thus distinguished from the verb in the first sense explained above,] inf. n. valovN, (TA,) signifies He was, or became, the third of the people, (T, S, K,) or a third to the two, (Fr, T, M,) or to the two men: (Msb:) or he made them, with himself, three: (T, S, K:) and similar to this are the other verbs of number, to ten [inclusive], except that you say, OarobaEuhumo and OasobaEuhumo and OatosaEuhumo, with fet-h, because of the E. (S.) A poet says, (IAar, S,) namely, AbdAllah Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr El-Asadee, satirizing the tribe of Teiyi, (IB, TA,)
faUino tavolivuwA narobaEo waUino yaku xaAmisN
yakuno saAdisN HatRaI yubiyrakumu Alqatolu
[And if ye make up the number of three, we will make up the number of four; and if there be a fifth of you, there shall be a sixth of us; so that slaughter shall destroy you]: (IAar, S, IB:) he means, if ye become three, we will become four: or if ye slay three. (IB, TA.) ― -b3- Also; (S, M, TA;) in the K, “ or, ” but this is wrong; (MF, TA;) valava Alqawoma signifies He made the people, with himself, thirty; (A 'Obeyd, S, M, K;) they being twenty-nine: and in like manner one uses the other verbs of number, to a hundred [exclusive]. (A 'Obeyd, S.) And valava also signifies He made twelve to be thirteen. (T.) ― -b4- valava AlOaroDa He turned over the ground three times for sowing, or cultivating. (A, TA.) ― -b5- See also 2. ― -b6- valava, (T, M, L, TA,) [as though intrans., an objective complement being app. understood,] or vlRv↓, (K, [but the former is app. the right reading, unless both be correct,]) said of a horse, He came [third in the race; i. e., next] after that which is called AlmuSalRiI: (T, M, L, K: [in the CK, AlcI, after Alfarasu, should be omitted:]) then you say rabaEa: then, xamasa. (T, M, L.) And in like manner it is said of a man [as meaning He came third]. (T.) ― -b7- laA yavoniI walaA yavolivu, (so in a copy of the M in art. vnI, but in the present art. in the same copy written lA yvniI wlA yvolivu,) or laA yuvanRiI walaA yuvalRivu↓, (so in a copy of the A, [in the CK in art. vnI, and in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 545, laA yuvanRaI walaA yuvalRavu,]) or laA yuvoniI walaA yuvolivu↓, (so in a copy of the K in art. vnI, [in the TA, in the present art. and in art. vnI, without any syll. signs,]) said of an old man, meaning He cannot rise, (M, A, TA,) when he desires to do so, a first time, nor can he (M, TA) the second time, nor the third. (M, A, TA.)

2 vlRvhu vlv vlvh vlvp
2. vlRvhu He made it three; or called it three: (Esh-Sheybánee, and K in art. wHd:) tavoliyvN signifies the making [a thing] three [by addition or multiplication or division]; as also valovN↓ [inf. n. of valava]: and the calling [it] three. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence, vlRv, inf. n. tavoliyvN, He asserted the doctrine of the Trinity.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] fulaAnN yuvanRiI walaA yuvalRivu Such a one counts two Khaleefehs, namely, the two Sheykhs [Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar], and [does not count three, i. e.,] rejects the other [that succeeded them]: and fulaAnN yuvalRivu walaA yurabRiEu Such a one counts three Khaleefehs, [namely, those mentioned above and 'Othmán,] and [does not count a fourth, i. e.,] rejects ['Alee,] the fourth. (A, TA.) ― -b4- laA yuvanRiI walaA yuvalRivu: see 1. ― -b5- vlRv liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained three nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.) ― -b6- vlRv binaAqatihi He tied, or bound, three of the teats of his she-camel with the SiraAr. (S.) ― -b7- valRavato said of a she-camel, and of any female: see 4. ― -b8- vlRv said of a horse in a race: see 1. ― -b9- vlRv Albusoru, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) The full-grown unripe dates became, to the extent of a third part of them, ripe, or in the state in which they are termed ruTab. (M, K.) ― -b10- tavoliyvN also signifies The watering seed-produce [on the third day, i. e.,] another time baEoda AlvRunoyaA [which app. means after excepting, or omitting, one day]. (M.) ― -b11- And The making [a thing] triangular [or trilateral]. (KL.) ― -b12- [The making a letter three-pointed; making it to have three dots.] ― -b13- The making [a thing] to be a third part. (KL.) ― -b14- The making the electuary, or confection, of aromatics, or perfumes, that is called muvalRav. (KL.)

4 Avlv Alqawomu Avlv Alqwm
4. Avlv Alqawomu The party of men became three: (Th, S, M, L, K:) and similar to this are the other verbs of number, to ten [inclusive]: (S:) also The party of men became thirty: and so in the cases of other numbers, to a hundred [exclusive]. (M, L.) ― -b2- Avlvt She (a camel, and any female,) brought forth her third young one, or offspring; (Th, M;) and so vlRvt↓, or Avtlvt↓. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b3- laA yuvoniI walaA yuvolivu: see 1. ― -b4- Avlv said of a grape-vine, It had one third of its fruit remaining, two thirds thereof having been eaten. (M.)

8 Uivotalava
8: see 4.

vulovN vlv
vulovN: see vuluvN.

vilovN vlv
vilovN The third young one or offspring, (M, A, K,) of a she-camel, (M, K,) and, accord, to Th, of any female: (M:) and in like manner others are termed, to ten [inclusive]. (A.) But one should not say naAqapN vilovN [after the manner of vinoIN, q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- saqaI naxolahu AlvRilova He watered his palm-trees once in three days: (A:) or he watered them baEoda AlvRunoyaA [which app. means after excepting, or omitting, one day]. (K.) vilovN is not used [thus] except in this case: there is no vilov in the watering of camels; for the shortest period of watering is the rifoh when the camels drink every day; then is the gibR, which is when they come to the water one day and not the next day; and next after this is the riboE; then, the ximos; and so on to the EiXor: so says As: (S, TA:) and this is correct, though J's assertion that vilov is not used except in this case is said by F to require consideration. (TA.) ― -b3- HumRaI AlvRilovi i. q. HumRaI AlgibRi, [The tertian fever;] the fever that attacks one day and intermits one day and attacks again on the third day; called by the vulgar AlmuvalRivapu↓. (Msb.)

vulavN vlv
vulavN: see what next follows.

vuluvN vlv
vuluvN (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and vulovN↓ (Msb, K) and vulavN↓, which last is either a dial. var. or is so pronounced to make the utterance more easy, (MF,) A third; a third part or portion; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also valiytN↓, (As, T, S, M, Msb, K,) like vamiynN and sabiyEN and sadiysN and xamiysN and naSiyfN, (S,) though AZ ignored valiyvN (T, S) and
xamiysN: (S:) [and mivolaAvN↓, q. v., app, signifies the same:] the pl. of vlv, (M, Msb,) and of vlyv also, (M,) is OavolaAvN. (M, Msb.) It is said in a trad., diyapu Xibohi AlEamodi OavolaAvFA [The expiatory mulct for that homicide which resembles what is intentional shall be thirds]; i. e., thirty-three she-camels each such as is termed HiqRap, and thirtythree of which each is such as is termed jacaEap, and thirty-four of which each is what is termed vaniyRap. (TA.)

UinaMCN valovaAnu AnMC vlvAn
UinaMCN valovaAnu A vessel in which the corn &c. that is measured therein reaches to one third of it: and in like manner one uses this expression in relation to beverage, or wine, &c. (M, L.)

vilovaAnN vlv vlvAn
vilovaAnN, (so in a copy of the M,) or valivaAnN, and valavaAnN, (K,) I. q. Einabu AlvRaEolabi; (K;) the tree thus called. (M, TA.)

valaAvN vlAv
valaAvN, also written valevN: see valaAvapN, in six places: and vulaAvu, in two places.

vulaAvu vlAv
vulaAvu and mavolavu↓ (S, L, K) Three and three; three and three together; or three at a time and three at a time; (L;) imperfectly decl. [because] changed from the original form of valaAvapN valaAvapN; (K;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of valaAvapN: they are epithets; for you say, mararotu biqawomK mavonaI wavulaAva [I passed by a party of men two and two, and three and three, together]: (Sb, S:) or they are imperfectly decl. because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to valaAvapN valaAvapN: but the dim. is vulayRivN↓, perfectly decl., like OuHayRidN &c., because it is like HumayRirN [dim. of HimaArN], assuming the form of that which is perfectly decl., though it is not so in the cases of OaHosanu and the like, as these words, in assuming the dim. form, do not deviate from the measure of a verb, for maA OuHayosinahu [How goodly is he!] is sometimes said. (S.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 3], faQnokiHuwA maA TaAba lakumo mina AlnRisaMCi wavulaAva warubaAEa, i. e. Then marry ye such as please you, of women, two [and] two, and three [and] three, and four [and] four: [meaning, two at a time, &c.:] here mvnI &c. are imperfectly decl. because deviating from the original form of Aivonayoni Aivonayoni, &c., and from the fem. form. (Zj, T, L.) And one says mavolava mavolava↓, like vulaAva vulaAva. (T.) You say also, faEalotu AlXRaIoCa mavonaI wavulaAva warubaAEa, meaning I did the thing twice and twice, and thrice and thrice, and four times and four times. (L.) ― -b2- [vulaAvN is app. fem. of vulaAvapN, a dial, var. of valaAvapN, of which the fem. is valaAvN: and hence,] cuw vulaAvK, with damm [to the initial v], A camel's [girth of the kind called] waDiyn. (K.) You say, Ailotaqato EuraA ciI vulaAvihaA (tropical:) [lit., The loops of her girth met together]; (A, TA; [but in a copy of the former, cI valaAvihaA↓;]) meaning, she was, or became, lean, or lank in the belly. (A. [See a similar saying voce biTaAnN.]) And a poet says,
waqado Damarato HatRaI badaA cuw vulaAvihaA
[And she had become lean, or lank in the belly, so that her girth appeared]: but some say that cw vlAvhA [here] means her belly, and the two skins, [namely,] the upper, and that which is pared, or scraped off, after the flaying: (TA:) or, accord. to some, the phrase is HatRaI QrotaqaI cw vlAvhA, meaning, so that her fœtus rose to her back; the vlAv [here again in a copy of the A written with fet-h to the initial v, and in like manner vlAvhA,] being the saAbiyaMC and the salaA and the womb. (A, TA.) You say also Ealayohi cuw valaAvK↓, [so I find it written, but perhaps it should be cw vulaAvK,] meaning, (tropical:) Upon him is a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC made of the wool of three sheep. (A, TA. [In the latter without any syll. sign to show that vlAv here differs from the form in the exs. cited before.])

vilaAv vlAv
vilaAv: see vaAlivN.

valuwvN vlwv
valuwvN A she-camel that fills three vessels (S, M, A, L, K) such as are called OaqodaAH, (M, L,) when she is milked, (S, K,) [i. e.,] at one milking. (A.) This is the utmost quantity that the camel yields at one milking. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel three of whose teats dry up: (S, M, A, K: [accord. to the TA, it is said in the T that such is termed mavoluwvN↓; but I think that this is a mistranscription:]) or that has had one of her teats cut off (IAar, T, M, L, K) by cauterization, which becomes a mark to her, (IAar, M,) and [in some copies of the K “ or ”] is milked from three teats: (T, M, L, K:) or that has three teats; (IAar, TA;) [and] so muvalRivapN↓: (T, TA:) or a she-camel having one of her teats dried up in consequence of something that has happened to it. (ISk.)

valiyvN vlyv
valiyvN: see vuluvN.

valaAvapN vlAv vlAvh vlAvp
valaAvapN, also written valevapN, a noun of number, [i. e. Three,] is masc., (S, M, Msb,) and is also written and pronounced vulaAvapN↓, with damm: (IAar, M, TA:) the fem. is valaAvN↓, also written valevN; (S, M, Msb;) [and app. vulaAvN also, mentioned above, under the head of vulaAvu, but only as occurring with cuw prefixed to it.] You say vulaAvapu rijaAlK [Three men]: and nisowapK valaAvu↓ [three women]. (Msb.) In the saying of Mohammad, rufiEa Alqalamu Eano valaAvK↓ [The pen of the recording angel is withheld from three persons] vlAv is for valaAvi OanofusK. (Msb. [See art. rfE.]) [In like manner, valaAvN↓ occurs in several trads. for valaAvu xiSaAlK; as, for instance, in the saying,] valaAvN mano kunRa fiyhi HaAsabahu QllRehu HisaAbFA yasiyrFA [There are three qualities: in whomsoever they be, God will reckon with him with an easy reckoning]: these are, thy giving to him who denies thee, and forgiving him who wrongs thee, and being kind to him who cuts thee off from him. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) The people of El-Hijáz say, OatawoniI valaAvatahumo [The three of them came to me], and OarobaEatahumo, and so on to ten [inclusive], with nasb in every case; and in like manner in the fem., OatayonaniI valaAvahunRa↓, and OarobaEahunRa: but others decline the word with the three vowels, making it like kulRuhumo: after ten, however, only nasb is used; so that you say, OatawoniI OaHada EaXarahumo [and valaAvapa EaXarahumo], and UiHodaI EaXoratahunRa [and valaAva EaXoratahunRa]. (S.) The saying waladu AlzRinaA XarN AlvRalaAvapi means [The offspring of adultery, or fornication, is the worst of the three] if he do the deeds of his parents. (Mgh.) [It is said that when vlAvp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name; and so are other ns. of number. (See vumaAniypN.) See also sitRapN.] ― -b2- valaAvapa EaXara [indecl. in every case, meaning Thirteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs valaAvapa EoXara: and [the fem.] EaXorapa valaAva↓, thus in the dial. of El- Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced valaAva EaXirapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. EXr.)

AlvRalaAvaMCu AlvlAvMC
AlvRalaAvaMCu, also written AlvRalevaMCu, (Lth, T, S, M,) or yawomu AlvRalaAvaMCi or AlvRalevaMCi, (A, Msb, K,) and AlvRulaAvaMC↓, with damm, (A, K,) [meaning The third day of the week, Tuesday,] has this form for the sake of distinction; for properly it should be AlvRaAlivu: (S, M:) or it has meddeh in the place of the p in the noun of number [valaAvapN] to distinguish it from the latter: (Lth, T:) [it is without tenween in every case; when indeterminate as well as when determinate; being fem.:] the pl. is valaAvaAwaAtN (S, M, Msb) and OavaAlivu. (Th, M.) It has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) Lh relates that Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaI AlvRalaAvaMCu bimaA fiyhi [Tuesday passed with what occurred in it]; making vlAvAC sing. and masc.; [but this he did because he meant thereby yawomu AlvRalaAvaMCi; ywm being masc.:] Th is related to have said, bimaA fiyhaA; making it fem.: and Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDati AlvRalaAvaMCu bimaA fiyhinRa, treating the word as a numeral. (M.)

(Sb, M.)

vaAlivN vAlv
vaAlivN [Third]: fem. with p. (T, &c.) The final v in AlvRaAlivu is sometimes changed into I. (M.) You say, huwa vaAlivu valaAvapK [He, or it, is the third of three]: thus you say when the two [terms] agree, each with the other; but not vaAlivN valaAvapF; vAlv being regarded in the former case as though it were a subst.; for you do not mean to convey by it a verbal signification, but only mean that he, or it, is one of the three, or a portion of the three: (Fr, ISk, T, S:) and in like manner you say, hiIa vaAlivapu valaAva [She is the third of three]; but when there is among the females a male, you say, hiIa vaAlivapu valaAvapK, making the masc. to predominate over the fem. (T.) When the two [terms] are different, you may make the former to govern the gen. case or to govern as a verb; saying, huwa raAbiEu valaAvapK or huwa raAbiEN valaAvapF, like as you say DaAribu zayodK and DaAribN zayodFA; and thus you also say, hecaA vaAlivu Qvonayoni and hecaA vaAlivN Qvonayoni, meaning This makes two to be three, with himself, or itself. (ISk, T, * S. [In most copies of the S, for vaAlivN Qvonayoni is put vaAliva Qvonayoni; and, in the explanation of this phrase, valRava Qvonayoni for valava Qvonayoni: IB has remarked that these are mistakes.]) vilaAv↓ occurs in the sense of vaAliv in a trad. cited voce vaAnK in art. vnI. (Sh, T in art. vnI.) ― -b2- vaAlivapu AlOavaAfiI means A projecting portion of a mountain, by which are placed two pieces of rock, upon all which is placed the cooking-pot. (S, K.) Hence the saying, ramaAhu QllRehu bivaAlivapi AlOavaAfiI [explained in art. Avf]. (TA.) ― -b3- [vaAliva EaXara and vaAlivapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Thirteenth, are generally held to be indecl. in every case without the art.; but with the art., most say in the nom. AlvRaAlivu EaXara, accus. AlvRaAliva EaXara, and gen. AlvRaAlivi EaXara; and in like manner in the fem. Accord. to some,] you say, huwa vaAlivu EaXara as well as huwa vaAliva EaXara [He, or it, is a thirteenth]: he who uses the former phrase says that he means huwa vaAlivu valaAvapa EaXara, (T, S,) i. e. He, or it, is one of thirteen, (T,) and that he suppresses vlAvh, and leaves vAlv decl. as it was; and he who uses the latter phrase says that he likewise means this, but that, suppressing vlAvp, he gives its final vowel to the word vAlv, (T, S,) to show that there is a suppression: (S:) but IB says that the former of these two phrases is wrong; that the Koofees allow it, but that the Basrees disallow it, and pronounce it a mistake. (L.) [And accord. to J, one says, hecaA AlvRaAliva EaXara and hecihi AlvRaAlivapa EaXorapa This is the thirteenth, or this thirteenth: for he adds,] and you say, hcaA AlHaAdiI EaXara and AlvRaAniIa EaXara and so on to twenty [exclusive]; all with fet-h; for the reason which we have mentioned: and in like manner in the fem., in which each of the two nouns is with p. (S.) You say also, vaAliva EaXara valaAvapa EaXara [The thirteenth of thirteen]; and so on to taAsiEa EaXara tisoEapa EaXara: and in like manner in the fem. (I' AK p. 316.)

(TA.) And OaroDN muvalRavapN A three-sided piece of land. (TA.) ― -b2- A thing composed of three layers or strata, or of three distinct fascicles or the like; (M, TA;) [see also mavoluwvN;] and in like manner what are composed of four, and more, to ten [inclusive], are called by similar epithets: (TA:) or a thing of three folds. (Lth, T.) ― -b3- [As a conventional term in lexicology, A word having a letter which has any of the three vowels: ex. gr., badoOapN is muvalRavapu AlbaMCi; i. e., it is written badoOapN and budoOapN and bidoOapN. As such also, A verb having its Eayon (or middle radical letter) movent by any of the three vowels: ex. gr., bahaOa bihi is muvalRavN; i. e., it is written bahaOa and bahuWa and bahiYa. And as such, muvalRavapN (not muvolavapN) signifies Three-pointed; having three diacritical points: it is an epithet added to vaMC, to prevent its being mistaken for baMC or taMC or yaMC.] ― -b4- Wine (XaraAb) cooked until the quantity of two thirds of it has gone; (S, K;) the expressed juice of grapes so cooked. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And A certain electuary, or confection, of aromatics, or perfumes. (KL.)

muvalRivN A calumniator, or slanderer, of his brother [or fellow] to his prince; because he destroys three; namely, himself and his brother and his prince: (Sh, T, M, * K:) as also muvolivN↓; (K;) or thus accord. to Aboo-'Owáneh. (Sh, T.) ― -b2- See also vilovN, last sentence: ― -b3- and see valuwvN.

mavoluwvN Property of which a third part has been taken. (A.) ― -b2- [Applied to a verse,] That of which a third has been taken away: (M, K:) whatever is mavoluwv is manohuwk: (TA:) or the former word signifies as above, and the latter signifies that of which two thirds have been taken away: this is the opinion of the authors on versification with respect to the metres called rajaz and munosariH: (M, TA:) the mvlwv in poetry is that whereof two feet out of six have gone. (TA.) ― -b3- A rope composed of three strands (Lth, T, S, M, A, K) twisted together, (Lth, T, A,) and in like manner woven, or plaited: (Lth, T:) and ropes composed of four, five, six, seven, and nine, strands, but not of eight nor of ten, are similarly called. (M.) ― -b4- A garment of the kind called kisaMC woven of wool and camels' hair (wabar) and goats' hair (XaEar). (Fr, T.) ― -b5- mazaAdapN mavolawvapN A mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] made of three skins. (T. S, A, K.) ― -b6- OaroDN mavoluwvapN Land turned over three times for sowing or cultivating. (A.) ― -b7- See also valuwvN.

valaja
, (K,) inf. n. valajN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His heart became cool, or refreshed, and relieved of a thing: (IAar:) and he rejoiced; or was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy: (IAar, K:) and he was, or became, at ease, at rest, tranquil, or free from disquietude. Collect thou [for them; namely, the cattle &c.; like vimo lahaA from wavama]. (TA.) And huwa yavumRuhu wayaqumRuhu He sweeps it, and collects the good and the bad. (S.) ― -b5- vamRa AlTRaEaAma, (M, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M,) He ate the good of the food and the bad thereof; (M, K;) as also qamRahu. (TA.) ― -b6- vamRatopu, (T, * S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) She (a ewe or a goat, M, K, or, as some say, only the latter, M) pulled it, or plucked it, up, or out, with her mouth; (T, S, M, K;) namely, a thing, (T, M,) or a plant, (S, K,) and anything by which she passed. (TA.) ― -b7- vamRa yadahu biAlHaXiyXi, (M, K,) or biAlOaroDi, (S, M,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (TA,) He wiped his hand (S, M, K) with the dry herbage, (M, K,) or upon the ground. (S, M.)

vamRa vm
vamRa There; syn. hunaAka; (Zj, S, M, K;) a noun of indication, (Zj, T, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) denoting a place that is remote (Zj, T, S, M, Mughnee, K) from the speaker, (Zj, T, M,) like as hunaA denotes that which is near; (Zj, T, S;) or denoting a place other than that of the speaker: (Msb:) it is an adverbial noun, not to be used otherwise
than as such; (Mughnee, K;) indecl. because of its vagueness, and with fet-h for its termination to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters. (Zj, T, M.) Thus in the saying [in the Kur xxvi. 64], waOazolafonaA vamRa AlMxariyna [And we brought near, there, the others]. (Mughnee.) He who makes it decl. as an objective complement (Mughnee, K) in this ex., (Mughnee,) and in the saying in the Kur [lxxvi. 20], waUicaA raOayota vamRa raOayota naEiymFA, is in error: (Mughnee, K: *) Zj says that the meaning is, And when thou castest thine eyes, or thy sight, there, thou shalt behold [scenes of] enjoyment: that Fr asserted the meaning to be, UicaA raOayota maA vamRa [when thou seest what is there]; but that this is an error; for mA, accord. to this interpretation, is a conjunct noun, and it is not allowable to suppress a conjunct noun and leave its complement. (T.) ― -b2- [mino vamRa is used by postclassical writers as meaning Therefore; for that reason; on that account.]

vumRa vm
vumRa, (T, S, M, &c.,) for which one also says fumRa, (M, Mughnee,) substituting f for the v, (M,) and vumRata (T, S, M) and vumRato, (M, TA,) but vumRata is the more common, (Mughnee and K on the letter t,) and fumRata and fumRato, (M, TA,) [meaning Then, i. e., afterward, or afterwards,] a particle, (M, K,) or conjunction, (Zj, T, S, Msb, Mughnee,) denoting order (Zj, T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee) and a delay, (S, Msb,) or having three properties, namely, that of virtually associating in the same case [the latter of the two members which it conjoins with the former of them], and denoting order, and denoting a delay; but respecting all of these there is a difference of opinions. (Mughnee, K. *) As to the associating in the same case, Akh and the Koofees assert that it sometimes fails to have this property, by its occurring redundantly, so as not to be a conjunction at all; and they hold to accord with this assertion the saying in the Kur [ix. 119], HatRaI UicaA DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu bimaA raHubato waDaAqato Ealayohimo Oanofusuhumo waZanRuwA Oano laA malojaOa mina QllRehi UilRaA Uilayohi vumRa taAba Ealayohimo [Until, when the earth became strait to them, notwithstanding its amplitude, and their minds became straitened to them, and they knew that there was no repairing for refuge from God save unto Him, then He returned to forgiveness towards them]: (Mughnee, K: *) but this has been resolved by the subaudition of the complement [of what precedes vumRa, as though the meaning were, then (they betook themselves unto Him, begging forgiveness, and) He returned &c.]. (Mughnee.) And as to its denoting order, some hold that there are exs. of its not necessarily implying this; (Mughnee, K; *) one of which is the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 8], xalaqakumo mino nafosK waAHidapK vumRa jaEala minohaA zawojahaA: (Mughnee: [in which are added other similar exs., one of which is given in the K:]) but to this there are five replies: 1st, that this passage is elliptical; the meaning being, He created you from one person (which He originated); then He made therefrom its mate: 2nd, that the meaning is, He created you from a person that was alone; then &c.: 3rd, that the progeny of Adam were made to come forth from his back like little ants; then Eve was created from his [rib called the] quSayoraI: 4th, that the creation of Eve from Adam being unusual, vmR is used to notify its order and posteriority in respect of wonderfulness and of the manifestation of power; not to denote order and posteriority of time: 5th, that vmR is here used to denote the order of enunciation; not the virtual order: the replies preceding this last are better than it, inasmuch as they verify the order and the delay; whereas the last verifies the order only, as there is no delay between the two enunciations; but the last reply is of more common application, applying to the ex. given above and to others: (Mughnee:) Fr says that the meaning of the ex. given above is, He created you from a person (which He created) single; then &c.; and in like manner says Zj. (T.) And as to its denoting a delay, Fr asserts that sometimes this is not the case, as is shown by the saying, OaEojabaniI maA SanaEota Alyawoma vumRa maA SanaEota Oamosi OaEojabu [What thou didst to-day excited my wonder, or admiration, or pleasure; then (I tell thee) what thou didst yesterday was more wonderful, or admirable, or pleasing]; for vmR is here used to denote the order of the enunciation; not a delay between the two enunciations. (Mughnee, K. *) ― -b2- [It is said that] it denotes order and a delay when it conjoins single words: but Akh says that it has the meaning of wa [And], because it is used in cases in which there is no order; as in waQllRehi vumRa waQllRehi laOafoEalanRa [By God, and (I say again,) By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: and when it conjoins propositions, it does not necessarily denote order, but has the meaning of wa: (Msb:) it has the meaning of wa, (S, Msb,) the conjunction, (S,) in the saying in the Kur [x. 47], vumRa QllRehu XahiydN EalaI maA yafoEaluwna [And God is witness of what they do]. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- The Koofees allow its being used in the manner of fa and wa so as that the aor. immediately following it after a conditional verb may be man- soob: and Ibn-Málik allows its being thus used so as that the aor. immediately following it after the expression of a desire that the thing shall not be done may be marfooa and mejzoom and man- soob. (Mughnee.)

vumRN vm
vumRN: see vumaAmN. ＝ -A2- In the saying maA lahu vumRN walaA rumRu [He has not vumR nor rumR], the former of these two nouns signifies water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels; (M;) or what is bad, or the worst, of those things, (S, K,) accord. to ISk; (S;) or men's household-goods, or furniture and utensils, and their water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels; (T, TA;) which last is the right meaning: (TA:) and the latter noun signifies maramRapu Albayoti [app. meaning, accord. to analogy, (for I find no suitable explanation of it in any of the lexicons,) the means by which a house, or tent, is put into a good state; and therefore, good furniture and utensils]. (ISk, S, M, K.) You say also, maA yamoliku vumRFA walaA rumRFA, meaning the same: (S, TA:) or he possesses not little nor much: it is not used save with a negation. (M, TA.) An Arab of the desert said, jaEojaEa biIa AldRahoru Eano vumRihi warumRihi, [thus in some copies of the S, and in the TA, in which latter the last two nouns are expressly said to be with damm, but in two copies of the S, in this instance, erroneously written, vamRihi waramRihi,] i. e. [Fortune has debarred me] from its little and its much. (S, TA.) And hence the saying of the vulgar, jaMCa biAlvRumRi waAlrRumRi, except that they pronounce both these nouns with kesr, meaning He brought little and much. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

UivomidN [An ore of antimony: or antimony itself; stibium; or stimmi:] collyrium-stone (Hajaru AlkuHoli), (K, TA,) which is black inclining to red, the mines whereof are in Ispahán, whence the best is obtained, and in the West, whence the hardest is obtained: (TA:) a certain stone used as a collyrium: (S:) a certain stone from which collyrium (kuHol) is prepared: or collyrium (kuHol) itself: (M:) or a substance resembling it: (Seer, M:) or a species thereof: (Lth, T:) or black kuHol, the mine whereof is in the East: said by some of the lawyers to be that of Ispahán: and said to be an arabicized word. (Msb.) The women of the Arabs used also to sprinkle [or rub] it upon the lips and gums, in order that the teeth might glisten the more. (EM p. 62.) [And for the same purpose, many of them tattoo their lips, so as to make them of a uniform dull bluish hue.] ― -b2- One says of a man who remains awake at night, journeying or working, fulaAnN yajoEalu AllRayola UivomidFA [Such a one makes the night a collyrium]; the blackness of the night being as though it were a collyrium to his eyes because he labours all the night in seeking the means of attaining to eminence. (T, S, M, A.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A man exhausted of his seminal fluid by women. (S, A, K.)

, (tropical:) It (a man's wealth) became abundant. (A, TA.) ― -b2- fulaAnN majoduwdu maA yavomaru (tropical:) [Such a one is fortunate in the abundance of his wealth: or] such a one possesses wealth. (A, TA.)

(T.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (God) made a man's wealth abundant. (S) And (tropical:) He (a man) increased, and made abundant, his wealth. (M, K.)

vamura
: (TA:) or [Avmr signifies it bore fruit; and vamara↓, it attained the time of bearing fruit: or the former, it bore unripe fruit; and the latter, it bore ripe fruit: or the former, it attained the time for the plucking of its fruit; and the latter, it put forth its fruit: for it is said that] mavomirN↓ signifies bearing fruit; and vaAmirN↓, that has attained the time of bearing fruit: or the former, unripe fruit; (M;) and the latter ripe fruit: (T, M:) or the former, that has attained the time for plucking; (AHn, M, K;) and the latter, that has put forth its fruit: (K:) or the latter of these epithets is applied to a tree, signifying bearing ripe fruit; and to fruit, signifying ripe. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- He (a man) had fruit that had come forth but that was not yet ripe. (T.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man) became abundant in wealth; (T, S, M, A, K;) as also ↓, vamara, (A, K,) aor.

, (TA,) inf. n. vumuwrN. (A, TA.) ― -b4- maA Oavomara Qbonu vamiyrK↓ (tropical:) [As long as the
moonlight-night renews itself, or recurs; i. e. ever]. Avmn lh mtAEh, or slEth,] signify the same, (T, S, *) He gave the man the price of his commodity: (K:) or Avmn AlrRajula bimataAEihi, and Avmn lahu mataAEahu, he named to the man a price for his commodity, and assigned it to it, or to him. vumonN vmn vmnn
vumonN: see vumunN.

vimonN vmn vmnn
vimonN The eighth young one or offspring. (A in art. vlv.) ＝ -A2- One of the periods between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels: (S:) [or the end of one of those periods; namely, the night of coming to water which is] the eighth night of
a period between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels, (K,) [counting the night of the next preceding drinking, or watering, as the first: see riboEN and ximosN &c.] See also 4.

vamanN vmn vmnn
vamanN The price of a thing; i. e. the thing that the seller receives in return for the thing sold, whether money or a commodity; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the vaman of a thing sold: (S:) and also (Er-Rághib, TA) a compensation, or substitute, (Mgh, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) whatever it be, for a thing, (Er-Rághib, TA,) i. e., for a thing that is sold; but in the sense commonly known, such as it is incumbent upon one to pay, of pieces of silver, and of gold [or other money]; not commodities and the like: (Mgh:) or the value, or worth, of a thing; (K;) its qiymap: (T:) or the estimated value, or worth, of a thing, by mutual consent, even though it be really excessive or deficient; whereas the qiymap is its real value or worth, its equivalent: (MF:) pl. OavomaAnN (T, Mgh, Msb, K) and OavomunN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter used only as a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and [so] OavominapN. (CK: not in the TA.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 38 and v. 48], walaA taXotaruwA biMyaAtiI vamanFA qaliylFA is metaphorical, meaning (tropical:) And take ye not in exchange for my signs a small substitute: [i. e. purchase not in exchange for belief in my word the happiness, or enjoyments, of the present life.] (Mgh.) With respect to this saying, Fr remarks, when vamanFA occurs in the Kur, with bi prefixed to the name of the thing sold or bought, in most cases it relates to two things whereof neither is a vmn in the sense commonly known, i. e., such as pieces of gold and of silver: and such is the case when you say, AiXotarayotu vawobFA bikisaMCK [I purchased a garment with a ksAC, q. v.]: either of these may be termed a vmn for the other: but in speaking of pieces of silver and of gold, you prefix the b to the vmn [only]; as is done in [the chapter of] Yoosuf, [i. e. ch. xii., v. 20, where it is said,] waXarawohu bivamanK baxosK daraAhima maEoduwdapK [And they sold him for a deficient, or an insufficient, price: for pieces of silver not many, so as to require their being weighed, but few, and therefore counted]: for pieces of silver are always a vmn: and when you purchase pieces of silver and of gold with the like, you prefix the b to whichever of the two you will, because each of them in this case is a purchase and a price. (T.)

vumunN vmn vmnn
vumunN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and vumonN↓ (M, Msb, K) An eighth; an eighth part or portion; as also vamiynN↓; (S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K;) agreeably with a general rule applying to fractions, accord. to some; (M, K;) but valiyvN was ignored by AZ (T and S in art. vlv) and by others, (TA,) and so was xamiysN: (S in art. vlv:) pl. OavomaAnN. (M, K.)

vamaAnK vmAn vmAny vmyn
vamaAnK and vamaAnN: see vamaAniyapN.

vamiynN vmyn
vamiynN: see vumunN. ＝ -A2- Also High-priced; or of high value; (S, TA;) and muvominN↓ [signifies the same; or] having a price, or value: (TA:) but accord. to the Durrat el-Ghowwás, the assertion that the former has the meaning here assigned to it is a mistake; for it means [only] the same as vumunN; and a thing that has a price, or value, is termed mvmn [app. muvominN, as above; but perhaps muvomanN, q. v.]. (Har p. 42.)

vamaAniyapN vmAny vmAnyh vmAnyp
vamaAniyapN a noun of number, well known; [meaning Eight;] as also vamaAnK↓, (M, TA,) which is like yamaAnK, (M, K,) in form: (M:) the former is the masc. form: the latter, the fem.: (Msb:) this is not a rel. n. [though likened above to yamaAnK]: (M, K:) or it is originally a rel. n. from AlvRumunu, because it is the part, or portion, that makes seven to be eight, so that it is its eighth: they make the first letter to be pronounced with fet-h, because they make changes [in some other cases] in the rel. n., (S, K,) as when they say suholiIRN and duhoriIRN, [which are rel. ns. of saholN and dahorN,] (S,) and they suppress one of the two I which are characteristic of the rel. n., and compensate it by the insertion of A, as they do in the rel. n. of Alyamanu [when they say yamaAnK, originally yamaAniIN, for yamaniIRN]: (S, K: [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) El-Fárisee says that the A of vamaAnK is the characteristic of the rel. n., because this word is not a broken pl. like SaHaArK; and IF assents to this, and says that were it not so, the p would be inseparable, as it is in EabaAqiyapN &c. (M.) You say vamaAniyapu rijaAlK [Eight men], (T, S, Mgh,) and vamaAniyapu OayRaAmK [eight days]. (Msb.) And when vmAn is prefixed to another noun, its I is retained, like the I in AlqaADiI: (S, Msb, K:) and it is decl. in the same manner as words of the class to which this last belongs: (Msb:) you say vamaAniI nisowapK [Eight women], (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and vamaAniI miAYapK [eight hundred], (S, Msb, K,) [in the nom. and gen. cases;] and raOayotu vamaAniIa nisowapK [I saw eight women], pronouncing the fet-hah [at the end, in this case]. (Msb.) When it is with tenween, the I is dropped in the nom. and gen. cases, but it is retained in the accus. case: (S, K:) [i. e.,] when the fem. form is not prefixed to another noun, you say, EinodiI mina AlnRisaMCi vamaAnK [I have with me, of women, eight], and mararotu minohunRa bivamaAnK [I passed by, of them, eight], and raOayotu vamaAniyFA [I saw eight]. (Msb.) It sometimes occurs, in poetry, indecl.: (S, M:) this is because it is fancied to be a pl.; (S;) or because it is likened, as to the letter, but not as to the meaning, to jawaAriIa. (M.) The people of El-Hijáz pronounce the masc. and the fem. with nasb in every case, in phrases like OatawoniI valaAvatahumo and OatayonaniI valaAvahunRa; and so on to ten [inclusive]. (S voce valaAvapN, q. v.) Th mentions vamaAnN↓; (TA;) and some instances of its occurrence are cited; but As disallows it. (T, Mgh, TA.) kisaMCN cuw vamaAnK means A [garment of the kind called] ksAC made of eight fleeces. (T.) tuqobilu biOarobaEK watudobiru bivamaAnK [She advances with four and goes back with eight] is a saying of one of the muxanRavuwn of El-Medeeneh; meaning, with four creases (Eukan) of the belly, and with eight extremities thereof; each crease having two extremities, towards the two sides of the woman spoken of. (Mgh in art. hyt.) The saying AlvRawobu saboEN fiI vamaAnK should properly be fiI vamaAniyapK, (S,) which means, The garment, or piece of cloth, is seven cubits in length by eight spans in breadth; (Msb;) because the length is measured by the ciraAE, which is fem., and the breadth by the Xibor, which is masc.; but they use the fem. when they do not mention things; as when they say, SumonaA mina AlXRahori xamosFA [We fasted, of the month, five], though meaning days: (S:) or because crAE is fem. in most instances, and Xbr is masc. (Msb.) [But it is said that when vmAnyp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name: thus] you say, tisoEapu Oakovaru mino vamaAniyapa [Nine things are more than eight things]. (TA voce tisoEapN, q. v.) [See also sitRapN.] ― -b2- When you make it a compound [with the number ten], you say, EinodaI vamaAniyapa EaXara rajulFA [I have with me eighteen men]: and in the case of the fem., you may either make the I to be with fet-h or make it quiescent, saying, EinodiI mina AlnRisaMCi vamaAniIa EaXorapa QmoraOapF or vamaAniIoEaXorapa [I have with me, of women, eighteen women]; but the former is the more chaste; and in one dial., the I is elided, on the condition of [saying vamaAna EaXorapa,] making the n to be with fet-h; (Msb;) or in this case you say vamaAni EaXorapa, with kesr. (T.) A poet says, (T, S,) namely, El-Aashà, (K,)
falaOaXorabanRa vamaAniyFA wavamaAniyFA
wavamaAni EaXorapa waQvonatayoni waOarobaEaA
[And I will assuredly drink eight cups of wine, (a pl. of kaOos, which is fem., being understood,) and eight more, and eighteen, and two, and four]: (T, S, K: but in the S and K, walaqado Xaribotu; and in the K, and in one copy of the S, wavamaAna:) he should properly have said vamaAniIa EaXorapa or vamaAniIo EaXorapa, (accord. to different copies of the T and S and K,) but he elides the I after the dial. of him who says TiwaAlu AlOayodi [for AlOayodiI], (S, K,) and he makes the n to be with kesr in order to indicate the I. (T.) ― -b3- The dim. of vamaAniyapN may be formed either by suppressing the A, which is the preferable way, so that you say vumayoniyapN↓, or by suppressing the I, saying vumayRinapN↓, changing the A into I and incorporating into it the I that is the characteristic of the dim.; and you may compensate for both [of these suppressed letters by saying vumayoniyRapN↓ and vumayRiynapN↓]. (S.) ― -b4- AlvRamaAniI is also the name of A certain plant. (As, T, K.)

vamaAnuwna vmAnwn
vamaAnuwna a well-known noun of number; [meaning Eighty;] sometimes used as an epithet: ElAashà says,
laYino kunota fiI jubRK vamaAniyna qaAmapF
waruqRiyta OasobaAba AlsRimaMCi bisulRami
[Assuredly if thou wert in a well eighty fathoms deep, and wert made to ascend the tracts of heaven by a ladder]: he uses it thus as meaning deep. (TA. [But in this verse, as cited in the present art in the TA, OabowaAba is put in the place
of AsbAb, which is the reading commonly known, and given in the S and TA in art. sb, and in the TA in art rqI-]) OaHomaqu mino SaAHabi DaOonK vamaAniyna [More stupid than an owner of eighty sheep], (S, K,) or mino raAEiI DaOonK vamaAniyna [than a pastor of eighty sheep], as in some of the copies of the S, or, as in the Proverbs of Aboo-'Obeyd, mino TaAlibi DaOonK vamaAniyna [than a demander of eighty sheep], (TA,) is a saying that originated from the fact that an Arab of the desert announced to Kisrà an event that rejoiced him, whereupon he said, “ Ask of me what thou wilt; ” and he asked of him eighty sheep. (S, K.) ― -b2- [It also signifies Eightieth.]

vumayoniyapN vmyn vmynyh vmynyp
vumayoniyapN and vumayRinapN and vumayoniyRapN and vumayRaynapN: see vamaAniyapN, last sentence but one.

vaAminN vAmn
vaAminN [Eighth: fem. with p]. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- [vaAmina EaXara and vaAminapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Eighteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.] ― -b3- UibilN vawaAminu, [the latter word pl. of vaAminapN,] Camels that come to water on the eighth night [after the next preceding watering]: from vimonN. (TA.)

Oavomanu c
Oavomanu Of more [and of most] price or value. (S.)

muvomanN mvmn
muvomanN Sold for a price: (Msb:) or having a price named for it, and assigned to it. (Mgh.) [See also vamiynN.]

muvominN mvmn
muvominN: see vamiynN

mivomanapN mvmn mvmnh mvmnp
mivomanapN A mixolaAp [or nose-bag]: (IAar, T:) or the like thereof. (S.)

muvamRanN mvmn
muvamRanN Octangular. (S, K.) ― -b2- A verse composed of eight feet. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Collected together. (T, TA.) ＝ -A3- Poisoned; syn. masomuwmN. (K.) ― -b2- Fevered; syn. maHomuwmN. (K.)

2 vnRn vnn vnp
2. vnRn He (a horse) lifted his vunRap [or fetlock] so that it did not touch the ground in his running, by reason of his briskness, or lightness: (M:) [or] his vunRap touched the ground in consequence of his being ridden by a heavy person. (T.)

4 AvnR Ovn OvnI Avn vnI
4. AvnR He (a weak old man) became wasted and worn out. (K.)

5 tvnRn tvnn
5. tvnRn He pastured, or fed, upon vinR [q. v.]. (T.)

vinRN vn
vinRN Dry herbage: (S:) or dry herbage when it lies heaped together, one part upon another: (T:) or dry herbage, (K,) or what has become dried up of HaliIR and buhomaI and HamoD, (M,) when it is much in quantity, and lies heaped together, one part upon another: or what has become black of any branches, or twigs; not consisting of baqol nor of EuXob: (M, K:) or dry herbage broken in pieces: (IDrd, M:) or [simply] herbage, or pasture: (Th, M:) or herbage that is weak, and soft, or easily broken. (IJ.)

vunRapN vnh vnp
vunRapN, of a human being, (Lth, T,) The part below the navel, (Lth, T, M,) above, (Lth, T,) or extending to, (M,) the hair of the pubes, (Lth, T, M,) in the lower part of the belly; (Lth, T;) the part between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (S:) or the thin skin (murayoTaMC) between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (M, K:) or the hair of the pubes, (T, M, K,) itself. (M.) ― -b2- And, of a horse (T, S, M, K) and the like, (T, S, K,) The fetlock; i. e. the hairs on the hinder part of the pastern-joint, (T, S, M, K,) hanging down (S, M) over the part called OumRu AlqirodaAn so as nearly to reach the ground: (S:) pl. vunanN. (S, M.) ― -b3- kunRaA fiI vunRapK mina AlkalaAmi wagunRapK (tropical:) [app. meaning We were engaged in light and confused talk] is a metaphorical saying, borrowed from the vunRap of the horse and the singing [or humming or buzzing of the flies and other insects] of the meadow or garden. (A, TA.)

vinaAnN vnAn
vinaAnN Numerous, or abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant, plants or herbage. (T, K.)

vinotaAni vnp vntAn
vinotaAni fem. of AivonaAni, which see in art. vnI.

vunoduwapN vndwh vndwp
vunoduwapN and vanoduwapN and vunoduWapN and vanoduWapN: see art. vdO.

vanowaI vnwI vnwy
vanowaI and vunowaI: vanawiIRN and vanawiyRapN: AivonawiIRN: mavonawiIRN: mavonawiyRapN: see art. vnI.

1 vanaAhu vnAh vnAp vnI
1. vanaAhu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) said in the K to be like saEaI, implying that the aor. is
vanaIa
, but this is a mistake, (MF, TA,) [for it is well known that] the aor. is
vaniIa
, (Msb,) inf. n. vanoIN, (S, M, Msb, &c.,) He doubled it, or folded it; (T;) he turned one part of it upon another; (M, K;) he bent it; (T, S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) he drew, or contracted, one of its two extremities to [or towards] the other; or joined, or adjoined, one of them to the other; thus bending it; (Mgh;) namely, a stick, or branch, or twig, (Mgh,) or a thing, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of any kind. (T.) One says of a man with the mention of whom one begins, in relation to an honourable or a praiseworthy quality, or in relation to science or knowledge, bihi tuvonaI AlxanaASiru, (T,) meaning With [the mention of] him, (T, and Msb in art. xSr,) among others of his class, (Msb ib.,) the little fingers are bent. (T, and Msb ubi suprá. [For the Arabs, in counting with the fingers, first bend the tip of the little finger down to the palm of the hand; then, the tip of the next; and so on; bending the thumb down upon the other fingers for five; and then continue by extending the fingers, one after another, again commencing with the little finger.]) And a poet says,
faUino EudRa majodN Oawo qadiymN limaEoXarK
faqawomiI bihimo tuvonaI hunaAka lOaSaAbiEu
[And if glory, or any old ground of pretension to honour, be reckoned as belonging to a body of men, it is my people, with the mention of them, in that case, the fingers are bent]; meaning that they are reckoned as the best; (IAar, M;) for the best are not many. (M.) One says also, vanaI warikahu fanazala [lit. He bent his hip, and alighted], meaning he alighted from his beast. (T.) And vanaI rijolahu Eano daAbRatihi, meaning He drew up his leg to his thigh, and alighted. (M.) But qabola Oano yavoniIa rijolahu, occurring in a trad., means Before he turned his leg from the position in which it was in the pronouncing of the testimony of the faith. (IAth.) vanaI Sadorahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, [lit. He folded his breast, or bosom,] means (assumed tropical:) he concealed enmity in his breast, or bosom: or he folded up what was in it, in concealment. (TA.)
