It is said in the Kur [xi. 5], OalaA UinRahumo yavonawna Suduwrahumo, meaning [Now surely] they infold and conceal [in their bosoms] enmity and hatred: (Fr, T:) or they bend their breasts, or bosoms, and fold up, and conceal, what is therein: (Zj, T:) I'Ab read, Suduwruhumo tavonawoniI↓: you say, AivonawonaI Sadoruhu EalaI AlbagoDaMCi, meaning his breast, or bosom, infolded, or concealed, vehement hatred: (T:) or the phrase in the Kur, accord. to the former reading, means they bend, or turn, their breasts, or bosoms, from the truth; they turn themselves away therefrom: or they incline their breasts, or bosoms, to unbelief, and enmity to the Prophet: or they turn their backs: (Bd:) [for] ― -b2- vanaAhu, (T, S, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (T, Msb, TA,) also signifies He turned him, or it, away or back. (T, S, Msb, TA.) Also He turned him, or turned him away or back, (Lth, T, S,) from the course that he desired to pursue, (Lth, T,) or from the object of his want: (S:) or you say, vanaAhu Eano wajohihi, (Mgh,) and Eano HaAjatihi, (TA,) and Eano muraAdihi, (Msb,) he turned him, or turned him away or back, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) from his course, (Mgh,) and from the object of his want, (TA,) and from the object of his desire. (Msb.) One says also, fulaAnN laA yuvonaI Eano qironihi walaA Eano wajohihi [Such a one will not be turned, or turned away or back, from his antagonist, nor from his course]. (T.) ― -b3- Also He tied it; or tied it in a knot or knots; or tied it firmly, fast, or strongly. (TA.) You say, vanayotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning, accord. to As, as related by A'Obeyd, I bound both the fore legs of the camel with two bonds: but correctly, I bound the two fore legs of the camel with the two ends of a rope; the last word meaning a single rope: (T:) Eaqalotuhu bivanoyayoni means I bound one of his fore shanks to the arm with two ties, or tyings. (T, M.) ― -b4- vanoIN [as inf. n. of vanaI] also signifies The act of drawing, or joining, or adjoining, one [thing] to another; (Lth, T, Mgh;) and so tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vnRI]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- [As valavahumo signifies “ he took the third of their property, ” and “ he made them, with himself, three, ” and other verbs of number are used in similar senses, so] vanaAhu signifies He took the half of their property: or he drew, or adjoined, to him what became with him two: (TA:) or vanayotuhu, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) signifies I became (S, Msb) to him, (S,)
or with him, (Msb,) a second; (S, Msb;) or I was a second to him, or it: (Er-Rághib:) or one should not say thus, but that AZ says, (M,) huwa waAHidN faQvonihi (M, K [but in the latter, hecaA in the place of huwa, and in the CK, fOavonih↓,]) he is one, and be thou a second to him. (M, K.) ― -b6- vanaI, aor. as above, also signifies He made eleven to be twelve. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b7- vanaI AlOaroDa, inf. n. as above, He turned over the land, or ground, twice for sowing, or cultivating: (Mgh, and A * and TA * in art. vlv:) and tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vnRI] and vunuyaAnN [app. another inf. n. of vanaI, and app. correctly written vunoyaAnN] are often used by [the Imám] Mohammad in the sense of vanoIN: he who explains tavoniyapN as signifying the turning over [the land, or ground,] for sowing, or cultivating, after the harvest, or as signifying the restoring land to its owner turned over for sowing, or cultivating, commits an inadvertence. (Mgh.) ― -b8- faQvoniniI, occurring in a poem of Kutheiyir 'Azzeh, is explained as meaning Then give thou to me a second time: (M, TA:) but this is strange: (TA:) [ISd says,] I have not seen it in any other instance. (M.) ― -b9- laA yavoniI walaA yavolivu, (a phrase mentioned by IAar, M,) or walaA yuvalRivu laA yuvanRiI↓, or walaA yuvolivu laA yuvoniI↓: see 1 in art. vlv.

2 vnRAhu vnAh vnAp vnI
2. vnRAhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. tavoniyapN, (S, K,) He made it two; or called it two. (S, M, MS b, K.) [Hence,] vanRaI means also He counted two; whence the saying, fulaAnN yuvanRiI walaA yuvalRivu; see art. vlv: (A and TA in art. vlv:) [and so, app., AivRanaI↓; for] a poet says,
badaA biOabiI vumRa QvRanaI biOabiI OabiI
[which seems plainly to mean He began with my father; then counted two with the father of my father]. (M.) ― -b2- [He dualized it, namely, a word; made it to have a dual. ― -b3- He marked it with two points, namely, a t or a I.] ― -b4- He repeated it; iterated it. (Mgh.) See 1, in three places. ― -b5- vnRI liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained two nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.) ― -b6- vnRI biAlOamori He did the thing immediately after another thing. (T.) ― -b7- tavoniyapN also signifies A man's requesting others [who are playing with him at the game called Almayosir] to return, for [a chance of] the stakes, his arrow, when it has been successful, and he has been secure, and has won. (Lh, M.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 Oavonato c
4. Oavonato, or Aivotanato↓, She brought forth her second offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- AvnI, (inf. n. UivonaMCN, TA,) He shed his tooth called the vaniyRap; (S, Mgh, Msb;) he became what is termed vuniIR; said of a camel [&c.]: (M, K:) he shed his rawaADiE [pl. of raADiEap which is the same, in this case, as vaniyRap]; said of a horse [&c.]. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A2- AvnI Ealayohi, (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UivonaMCN; (T;) and vnRI↓, inf. n. tavoniyapN, accord. to the K, but this is a mistake for vbRI↓, inf. n. tavobiyapN; (TA;) He praised, eulogized, commended, or spoke well of, him: and he dispraised, censured, discommended, or spoke ill of, him: (T, * M, Msb, K:) the object is either God or a man: (T:) or it has the former meaning only: (M, K;) or the former meaning is the more common: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, AvnI signifies he spoke, or said, well, or good; and ill, or evil; and AnvI, “he defamed,” or “did so in the absence of the object;” and “he disdained, scorned, shunned, disliked, or hated,” a thing: (T:) and you say, AvnI Ealayohi xayorFA [He spoke, or said, well, or good, of him]; (S, and TA from a trad.;) and XarRFA [ill, or evil], also. (TA from the same trad.) One says also, Oavonayotu fiEolahu [I praised his deed]; meaning EalaI fiEolihi; or because OavonaI means madaHa. (Ham p. 696.)

5 tvnRI OvnI tvnI tvny vnI
5. tvnRI: see 7. ― -b2- Also He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side; syn. tamaAyala: (Har pp. 269 and 271:) and he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; or with a twisting of the back, and with extended steps; syn. tabaxotara. (Idem p. 271.) You say, tvnRI fiI miXoyatihi (S, and Har p. 269) He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side, in his gait. (Har ib.) [And in like manner, and more commonly, one says of a woman.]

7 AnvnI Onv OnvnI Onvny AnvnI Anvny QnvnI
7. AnvnI, (T, S, M, K,) and tvnRI↓, and AivRanaI↓, of the measure AifotaEala, (M, K,) originally AivotanaI, (M,) and AivonawonaI↓, (T, S, K,) of the measure AifoEawoEala, (T, S,) It was, or became, doubled, or folded; (T;) it had one part turned upon another; (M, K;) it was, or became, bent. (T, S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnvnI signifies also He turned, or turned away or back, (Har pp. 44 and 120,) Eano OamorK from an affair, after having determined to do it. (Lth in TA art. zmE.)

8 UivotanaIa
8: see 7, and 4: ― -b2- and see also 2.

10 AstvnAhu AstvnAh AstvnAp QstvnAh QstvnI
10. AstvnAhu He set it aside as excluded; or he excluded it, or excepted it; mino XaIoCK from a thing; syn. HaAXaAhu: (M:) or he set it aside, or apart, for himself: and in the conventional language of the grammarians, [he excepted it; i. e.] he excluded it from the predicament in which another thing was included, or in which other things were included: (Mgh:) AlQisotivonaMCu [in grammar] is the turning away the agent from reaching the object of the AisotivonaMC: (Msb:) in the case of an oath [and the like], it means the saying Uino XaMCa QllRehu [If God will]. (Mgh.) [See vunoyaA.]

12 AvnwnI OvnI Ovnwny AvnwnI Avnwny
12. AvnwnI: see 7; and see also 1.

vinoIN vnI vny
vinoIN A duplication, or doubling, of a thing: (T, * S, Msb:) pl. OavonaMCN; (S, Msb;) or the sing. may be vanFI↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- A folding: so in the saying, Oanofacotu kacaA vinoIa kitaAbiI, (S, TA,) or fiI vinoIi kitaAbiIi (so in a copy of the S,) i. e., fiI TayRihi [lit. I sent, or transmitted, such a thing within the folding of my writing, or letter; meaning infolded, or enclosed, in it; and included in it]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A duplicature, or fold, of a garment, or piece of cloth: (TA:) or what is turned back of the extremities thereof: (T:) pl. as above: whence, in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, kaAna yavoniyhi Ealayohi OavonaMCF mino saEatihi [He used to fold it upon him in folds by reason of its width]; meaning the garment. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] wakaAna celika fiI OavonaMCi kacaA, i. e., fI guDuwnihi [lit And that was in the folds, meaning, in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair, or event]. (TA.) And jaAWuwA fiI OavonaMCi AlOamori They came in the midst of the affair, or event. (Msb.) [And hence, app.,] maDaI vinoIN mina AllRayol An hour, or a period, or a short portion, of the night passed; (M, K; *) syn. saAEapN, (Th, M, K,) or waqotN. (Lh, M, K.) [See also what is said below respecting its pl. in relation to a night.] ― -b4- Also sing. of OavonaMCN meaning The parts of a thing that are laid together like the strands of a rope, or that are laid one upon another as layers or strata, or side by side as the things that compose a bundle; (quwaAhu, and TaAqaAtuhu; [rendered by Freytag “ virtutes, facultates rei; ”]) and mavaAnK↓, of which the sing. is mavonaApN↓ and mivonaApN↓, signifies the same. (M, K.) ― -b5- Also A bending of the neck of a sheep, or goat, not in consequence of disease: (K: but in the M, vanoIN [inf. n. of 1]:) and a serpent's bending, or folding, of itself: (M, K:) and also (thus in the M, but in the K “or”) a curved part of a serpent that has folded itself; (M, K;) pl. OavonaMCN, (M,) i. e. the folds of a coiled serpent. (T.) The pl. is used metaphorically [as though meaning (tropical:) The turns] of a night. (M. [But see explanations of the sing. as used in relation to a night in what precedes.] ― -b6- A part that is bent, or folded, or doubled, of a wiXaAH [q. v.]; (TA;) pl. as above: (T, TA:) and so of a rope: (S:) or a portion of the extremity of a rope folded, or doubled, [so as to form a loop,] for binding therewith the pastern of the fore leg of a beast, to serve as a tether. (T.) Tarafeh says,
laEamoruka UinRa Almawota maA OaxoTaOa AlfataI
lakaAlTRiwali AlmuroxaI wavinoyaAhu biAloyadi
[By thy life, death, while missing the strong young man, is like the tether that is slackened while the two folded extremities thereof are upon the fore leg, or in the hand: see TiwalN]: (T, S:) he means that the young man must inevitably die, though his term of life be protracted; like as the beast, though his tether be lengthened and slackened, cannot escape, being withheld by its two extremities: (so in a copy of the T:) or by vnyAh he means its extremity; using the dual form because it is folded, or doubled, upon the pastern, and tied with a double tie: (so in another copy of the T:) or he means, while its two extremities are in the hand of its owner: (EM p. 91:) by mA AxTO, he means fiI UixoTaAYihi, (S in art. Twl,) or mudRapa UixoTaAYihi: and the l [prefixed to the k of comparison] is for corroboration. (EM ubi suprá.) You say also, rabRaqa OavonaMCa AlHaboli, meaning He made loops in the middle of the rope to put upon the necks of the young lambs or kids. (T.) ― -b7- Also A bend, or place of bending, of a valley, (S, M, * K,) and of a mountain: (S:) pl. as above: (M,
K:) and mavaAnK↓ [likewise] signifies the bends of a valley. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- A she-camel that has brought forth twice, (S,) or two, (M,) or a second time: (K:) or, as some say, that has brought forth once: but the former is more analogical: (M:) one does not say vilovN [as meaning “ that has brought forth thrice ”], nor use any similar epithet above this: (S, TA:) pl. vunaMCN, like ZuWaArN pl. of ZiYorN, accord. to Sb, (M, TA,) and OavonaMCN accord. to others: (TA:) in like manner it is applied to a woman, (S, M,) metaphorically: (M:) and to the she-camel's second young one: (S, M:) accord. to As, as related by A'Obeyd, a she-camel that has brought forth once: also that has brought forth twice: [so says Az, but he adds,] but what I have heard from the Arabs is this; that they term a she-camel that has brought forth her first young one bikor; and her first young one, her bikor; and when she brought forth a second, she is termed vinoIN; and her young one, her vinoI: and this is what is correct. (T.) [Hence the saying,] maA hecaA AlOamoru minoka bikorFA walaA vinoyFA (tropical:) This thing, or affair, is not thy first nor thy second. (A and TA in art. bkr.) ― -b2- See also vunoyaAnN.

vanFI vnI vny
vanFI: see vinoIN, first sentence.

vunFI vnI vny
vunFI: see vinFI: ― -b2- and see also vunoyaAnN: ― -b3- and AivonaAni.

vinFI vnI vny
vinFI The repetition of a thing; doing it one time after another: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) or a thing, or an affair, done twice: (S, Msb, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) and vunFI↓ signifies the same. (IB, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA vinaI fiI AlSRadaqapi There shall be no repetition in the taking of the poor-rate; (IAth, TA;) [i. e.] the poor-rate shall not be taken twice in one year: (As, Ks, T, S, M, Mgh, K:) or two she-camels shall not be taken in the place of one for the poor-rate: (M, IAth, K: *) or there shall be no retracting of an alms; or no revoking it: (Mgh, K, * TA:) this last is the meaning accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (Mgh, TA,) i. e. Ed-Dareeree, (Mgh,) who, in explaining this trad., as relating to the giving an alms to a man and then desiring to take it back, says he does not deny that vinFI has the meaning first assigned to it above in this paragraph. (TA.) ― -b2- See also vunoyAnN: ― -b3- and AivonaAni.

vanowaI vnwI vnwy
vanowaI and vunowaI: see vunoyaA, in four places.

vunoyapN vny vnyh vnyp
vunoyapN: see vunoyaA, in three places.

vinoyapN vny vnyh vnyp
vinoyapN The lowest, most ignoble, or meanest, of the people of his house; applied to a man. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also pl. of vunoyaAnN, q. v. (S, K.)

vunoyaA vnI vny vnyA
vunoyaA a subst. from AisotivonaMCN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also vanowaI↓; the former with damm, and the latter with fet-h: (S, Msb:) both are syn. with AisotivonaMCN [used as a subst., meaning An exception]; (T;) as also vaniyRapN↓, (T, K,) or vunoyapN↓, (accord. to one copy of the T,) and mavonawiyRapN↓: (T:) so in the saying, Halafa yamiynFA layosa fiyhaA vunoyaA and vunowaI↓ and vaniyRapN↓ or vunoyapN↓ and mavonawiyRapN↓ [he swore an oath in which there was not an exception]; for when the swearer says, “ By God I will not do such and such things unless God will otherwise, ” he reverses what he [first] says by God's willing otherwise: (T: [see 10:]) [and so in the saying,] HalofapN gayoru caAti mavonawiyRapK↓ a swearing not made lawful [by an exception]: (M:) [so too in the saying,] bayoEN maA fiyhi mavonawiyRapN↓ [and vunoyaA &c.] (K in art. lHj) a sale in which there is not an exception: (TA in that art.:) or vunoyaA signifies a thing excepted, (M, Mgh, K,) whatever it be; (K) as also vanowaI↓, (M, K,) with w substituted for I, (M,) or vunowaI↓, (so in the TA, [but probably through inadvertence,]) and vaniyRapN↓, (M, K,) or vunoyapN↓. (TA.) In a sale, it is unlawful when it is the exception of a thing unknown; and when one sells a slaughtered camel for a certain price and excepts the head and extremities: (T, TA:) or when an exception is made from things sold without measuring or weighting or numbering: and in a contract with another for labour upon land on the condition of sharing the produce, it is when one excepts a certain measure after the half or the third. (IAth, TA.) The saying of Mo- hammad, mani QsotavonaI falahu vunoyaAhu means Whoso maketh an exception, his shall be what he excepteth: (M, TA: *) as, for instance, when one says, “ I divorce her thrice, save once: ” or “ I emancipate them, except such a one. ” (TA.) ― -b2- It also means particularly The head and legs of a slaughtered camel; (T, M, * K;) because the seller of the camel used, in the Time of Ignorance, to except them; (T;) and IF adds, but incorrectly, the back-bone: (Sgh, TA:) whence, applied to a she-camel, mucakRarapu AlvRunoyaA, (T, M,) meaning Resembling the make of the male in [the largeness of] her head and legs; (Th, M;) or jumaAliyRapu AlvRunoyaA, having thick legs, like those of the male camel in thickness. (T.) [Also, app., The exception, or omission, of a day, in irrigation: see 3 in art. vlv, and vilovN in the same art.] And vaniyRapN↓ signifies also A palm-tree that is excepted from a bargain. (M, K.) And The martyrs whom God has excepted from those who shall fall down dead or swooning: (M, K:) these, accord. to Kaab, are QllRehi fiI AlOaroDi vaniyRpu↓ [those whom God has excepted on the earth]; (T, M;) alluded to in the Kur [xxxix. 68], where it is said, “ And the horn shall be blown, and those who are in the heavens and those on the earth shall fall down dead, or swooning, except those whom God shall please [to except]. ” (T.)

vunoyaAnN vny vnyAn
vunoyaAnN The second chief; the person who comes second as a chief; (A'Obeyd, T;) the person who is [next] below the sayRid, (S, M, K, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, syl,]) in rank; (S;) as also vinFI↓ (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and vunFI↓ (A'Obeyd, T, S, K) and vinoIN↓: (K:) pl. (of the first, S) vinoyapN [which is also a sing., mentioned above]. (S, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce badoCN.] ― -b2- A man having no judgment nor intelligence, or understanding. (M, K.) ― -b3- Applied to judgment, or an opinion, (M, K,) (tropical:) Wrong, or having a wrong tendency; (M;) bad, corrupt, unsound, or wrong. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also a pl. of vaniIRN [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)

vanawiIRN vnwI vnwy
vanawiIRN rel. n. of AivonaAni, and of AivonaA EaXara, when either or these is used as the proper name of a man; as also AivoniIRN↓ [with Q when connected with a preceding word]; like binawiIRN and AiboniIRN as rel. ns. of AibonN. (S.) ― -b2- And AlvRanawiyRapu [The Dualists;] the sect who assert the doctrine of Dualism [AlQivonayoniyRap]. (TA.)

vanaMCN vnMC
vanaMCN, [and accord. to the CK, vaniyRapN, but this is a mistranscription for tavoniyap, inf. n. of vanRaI, and tavoniyap is a mistake for tavobiyap, inf. n. of vabRaI, (see 4,)] Praise, eulogy, or commendation, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of a man, (T, M,) and of God: (T:) and dispraise, censure, or discommendation, (T, M, Msb, K,) of a man: (T, M:) or the former only: (M, K:) or more frequently the former: (Msb:) so termed because it is repeated: (Ham p. 696:) that it relates to good speech and evil is asserted by many. (TA.)

vunaMCu vnMC
vunaMCu and vunaMCa: see mavonaI.

vinaMCN vnMC
vinaMCN The cord, or rope, with which a camel's fore shank and his arm are bound together; (S, K;) and the like; consisting of a folded, or doubled, cord, or rope: each of the folds, or duplicatures, thereof would be thus termed if the word were used in the sing. form: (S:) Ibn-EsSeed [in the CK, erroneously, Ibn-Es-Seedeh] allows it; and therefore it is given as on his authority in the K: (TA:) and Lth allows it; but in this instance he allows what the Arabs do not allow: (T:) you say, Eaqalotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning I bound together the fore shanks and the arms of the camel with a rope, (S,) or with two ropes, (M, [but this is probably a mistake of a copyist,]) or with the two ends of a rope; (AZ, T, S, M;) without C because the word has no sing.: (Kh, Sb, T, S:) Lth allows one's saying bivinaMCayoni also; but the Basrees and Koofees [in general] agree that it is without C: (T:) IB says that it has no sing. because it is a single rope, with one end of which one fore leg is bound, and with the other end the other leg; and IAth says the like: (TA:) this rope is also called vinaAyapN↓; but a single rope for binding one fore shank and arm is not thus called. (T.) See also vinaAyapN. ― -b2- And see vaAnK. ＝ -A2- The finaMC [or court, or open or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides,] (M, K,) of a house: (M:) [in the CK, AlginACu is erroneously put for AlfinACu:] accord. to IJ, from vanaI, aor. yavoniI, because there one is turned back, by its limits, from expatiating; but A'Obeyd holds the v to be a substitute for f. (M.)

vaniIRN vnI vny
vaniIRN Shedding his tooth called the vaniyRap [q. v.]: (S, M, Msb:) or that has shed the tooth so called: (T, Mgh:) applied to a camel &c., as follows: (T, S, M, &c.:) or, as some say, to any animal that has shed that tooth, except man: (M:) fem. with p: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) a camel in the sixth year; (T, S, M, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K;) the least
age at which he may be sacrificed: (T:) and a horse in the fourth year; (IAar, T, Mgh, K;) or in the third year: (S, Msb:) and a cloven-hoofed animal, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or a sheep or goat and an animal of the bovine kind, [respecting which last see EaDobN,] (T, IAth, K,) in the third year: (T, S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K:) or a sheep and a goat, (M,) the latter accord. to the persuasion of Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal], (TA,) in the second year: (M:) and a gazelle after the age at which he is termed jacaEN: (M: [see XaSarN:]) in all cases, after what is termed jacaEN and before what is termed rabaAEK: (Mgh:) pl. (masc., S, TA) vunoyaAnN and vinaMCN (S, M, Mgh, Msb) and vunaMCN, and, accord. to Sb, vunK; (M;) and pl. fem. vaniyRaAtN. (S.)

AlvRunaIRu Olvny AlvnI Alvny lAv vny
AlvRunaIRu, or AlvRuniIRu: see AivonaAni.

vaniyRapN vny vnyh vnyp
vaniyRapN I. q. EaqabapN: (AA, M, Mgh, K:) or the latter means a long mountain that lies across the road, and which the road traverses; and the former, any such mountain that is traversed: (T:) so called because it lies before the road, and crosses it; or because it turns away him who traverses it: (Mgh:) or the road of what is termed Eaqabap: (S; and so in copies of the K:) or a high road of what is thus termed: (K accord. to the TA:) or a road in, or upon, a mountain, (M, K,) like that which is termed naqobN [q. v.]: (M:) or a road to a mountain: (M, K:) or a mountain (M, K) itself: (M:) or a part of a mountain that requires one, in traversing it, to ascend and descend; as though it turned the course of journeying: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. vanaAyaA: (T, S:) which signifies also [such roads as are termed] madaArij. (T.) Hence the phrase, fulaAnN TalRaAEu AlvRanaAyaA Such a one rises to eminences, or to lofty things or circumstances, or to the means of attaining such things; like the phrase TalRaAEu OanojudK [q. v.]: (S:) or, like the latter phrase, is accustomed to embark in, or undertake, or to surmount, or master, lofty and difficult things: (Mgh:) or is hardy, strong, or sturdy; one who embarks in, or undertakes, great affairs. (TA. [See an ex. under the heading of Aibonu jalaA, in art. jlw: and see also art. TlE.]) ― -b2- Also, (T, S, M, &c.,) pl. vanaAyaA (T, S, Mgh, Msb) and vaniyRaAtN, (Msb,) One of certain teeth, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) the foremost in the mouth, (M,) [namely, the central incisors,] four in number, (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) to man, and to the camel, (T, M, &c.,) and to the wild beast, (M,) in the fore part of the mouth, (T, Mgh, K,) two above and two below: (T, M, Mgh, K:) so called as being likened to the vaniyRap of a mountain, in form and hardness; (TA;) or because each of them is placed next to its fellow. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- Also fem. of vaniIRN [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) ＝ -A3- See also vunoyaA, in five places.

vinaAyapN vnAyh vnAyp
vinaAyapN A cord, or rope, of goats' hair (XaEar), or of wool, (S, K,) or of other material; (K;) as also vinaMCN↓ (K) and mivonaApN↓ and mavonaApN↓; (M, K;) which last is explained by IAar as signifying [simply] a cord, or rope: (M:) [or] the first has the meaning assigned to it above, voce vinaMCN; syn. with vinaAyaAni: and signifies also a long rope; whence the saying of Zuheyr, describing the [she-camel termed] saAniyap,
tamoTuw AlrRiXaMCa watujoriI fiI vinaAyatihaA
mina AlmaHaAlapi qabRFA raAYidFA qaliqaA
(T,) meaning [She draws the well-rope, and causes to run,] with her vnAyp upon her, (ISk, T,) [a wabbling, unsteady, sheave (?) of the large pulley;] the vnAyp here being a rope of which the two ends are tied to the saddle (qatab) of the sAnyp; the [upper] end of the well-rope being tied to its mivonaAp↓ [which here means the folded middle part]: (T:) but Aboo-Sa'eed says that it [here] means a piece of wood by which are connected the two extremities of the cheeks, or side-pieces, (TrfA Almylyn, [the latter of which words I here render conjecturally, supposing it to be similar in meaning to AlqaEowi or AlqaEowayoni,]) above the mHAlp, and a similar piece below; the mHAlp and [qu. or] the sheave turning between the tow pieces thus called. (T, in a later portion of the art.)

vunaAYiIRN c
vunaAYiIRN [a rel. n. from AivonaAni, anomalously formed, but analogous with other rel. ns. from ns. of number, as rubaAEiIRN vulaAviIRN, &c., Of, or relating to, two things]. ― -b2- kalimapN vunaAYiyRapN A word comprising, or composed of, two letters; as yadN, and dumo [or damN?]. (TA.)

vinotaAni vnp vntAn
vinotaAni a fem of AivonaAni, q. v.

vaAnK vAn vAny
vaAnK [act. part. n. of 1; Doubling, or folding; &c.]. Hence, huwa vaAnK rijolahu While he was bending his leg before rising, or standing up. (TA from a trad.) [And jaMCa vaAniIa EiTofihi: see art. ETf.] One says of a horseman who has bent the neck of his beast on the occasion of his vehement running, jaMCa vaAniIa AlEinaAni [He came bending the rein by pulling it with both hands a little apart]: (T:) or jaMCa vaAniyFA mino EinaAnihi [he came bending a part of his rein]. (S.) And of the horse himself, one says, jaMCa saAbiqFA vaAniyFA, i. e. He came outstripping, with bent neck, by reason of briskness; because when he is fatigued, he stretches out his neck; and when he is not fatigued nor jaded by running, but comes in his first run, he bends his neck: and hence the saying of the poet,
wamano yafoxaro bimivoli OabiI wajadRiI
yajiYo qabola AlsRawaAbiqi wahuwa vaAniI
i. e. [And he who glories in the like of my father and my grandfather, let him come before the mares that outstrip,] he being like the horse that outstrips [all others], with bent neck; or it may mean, he bending the neck of his horse which has outstripped the others. (T.) [Hence also,] XaApN vaAniyapN A sheep, or goat, bending the neck, not in consequence of disease. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Also Second; the ordinal of two: fem. with p.] You say, hecaA vaAniI hecaA [This is the second of this]; i. e. this is what has made this a pair, or couple: (M:) and fulaAnN (T) or hecaA (S) vaAniI Qvonayoni, (T, S,) i. e. Such a one, or this, is [the second of two, or] one of the two; (T, S;) like as you say vaAlitu valaAvapK; and so on to EaXarap: but not with tenween: (S:) [i. e.,] you may not say vAnK Qvonayoni: (T: [see vaAlivN:]) but if the two [terms] disagree, you may use either mode; (S;) you may say, hecaA (S) or huwa (Mgh) vaAniI waAHidK and vaAnK waAHidFA, (S, Mgh,) i. e. This has become a second to one, (S,) [or rather, becomes &c. (i. e. yavoniI rather than vanaI),] or he, or it, makes one, with himself, or itself, to be two. (Mgh.) vinaMC↓ also signifies the same in a trad. respecting the office of commander, or governor, or prince; where it is said, OawRaluhaA malaAmapN wavinaAWuhaA nadaAmapN wavilaAvuhaA EacAbu yawomi AlqiyaAmapi UilRaA mano Eadala, i. e. [The first result thereof is blame, and] the second [is regret, and] the third [is the punishment of the day of resurrection, except in the case of him who acts equitably]: so says Sh. (T.) ― -b3- And AlvRawaAniI [pl. of AlvRaAniyapu] signifies [The second horns;] the horns that are [next] after the OawaAYil. (M.) ― -b4- [vaAniIa EaXara and vaAniyapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Twelfth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv.]

OavonaMCN c
OavonaMCN pl. of vinoIN and of AivonaAni: and also syn. with this latter, q. v.

AivoniIRN OvnI Ovny AvnI Avny vnI QvnA Qvny
AivoniIRN: see vanawiIRN.

AivonaAni AvnAn QvnAn
AivonaAni a noun of number; (S, Msb;) applied to the dual number; (Msb;) meaning [Two;] the double of waAHidN; (M, K;) with a conjunctive A [when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, written QvonaAni]; (T, S, Msb;) but this is sometimes made disjunctive when connected with a preceding word by poetic license: (T, S:) of the masc. gender: (S:) fem. AivonataAni, (T, S, Msb,) in which, also, the A is conjunctive; (T, Msb;) and vinotaAni↓; (T S, M, Msb, K;) the latter sometimes used, (T,) [much less frequently than the former, though the only fem. form mentioned in the M and K,] and of the dial. of Temeem; (Msb;) like as one says, hiIa Qbonapu fulaAnK and hiIa binotuhu: (T:) the t in the dual is a substitute for the final radical, I, (M, TA,) as it is in OasonatuwA, the only other instance of this substitution except in words of the measure AifotaEala: (Sb, M, TA:) in AivonaAni, the final radical, I is suppressed: (Msb:) it has no sing.: (Lth, T:) if it were allowable to assign to it a sing., it would be AivonN [for the masc.] and AivonapN [for the fem.], like AibonN and AibonapN: (S:) accord. to some, (Msb,) it is originally vinoIN; (T, Msb, CK;) and hence the dual vinotaAni: (Msb:) or it is originally vanaIN, (M, Msb, and so in a copy of the K,) the conjunctive A being then substituted for the I whence the dual QvonaAni, like QbonaAni: (Msb:) this is shown by the form of its pl., which is OavonaMCN, (M, K,) like OabonaMCN [pl. of QbonN, which is originally banaIN or banawN,] and MxaMCN [pl. of OaxN, which is originally OaxawN]. (M.) In the saying in the Kur [xvi. 53], laA tatRaxicuwA Uielhayoni Qvonayoni [Take not to yourselves two gods], the last word is added as a corroborative. (M.) The phrase vinotaA HanoZalK occurs, by poetic license, for AivonataAni mino HanoZalK, meaning HanoZalataAni [Two colo-
cynths]. (S.) You say also, AlqadaHi Xaribotu OavonaMCa↓, and Xaribotu QvonaIo hecaA AlqadaHi, meaning [I drank] twice as much as the bowl, and as this bowl: and in like manner, Xaribotu QvonaIo mudRi AlbaSorapi and Qvonayoni bimudRi AlbaSorapi [I drank twice the quantity of the mudR of El-Basrah]. (M.) And a poet says,
famaA Hulibato UilRaA AlvRalaAvapa waAlvRunaI↓
walaA quyRilato UilRaA qariybFA maqaAluhaA
meaning [And she was not milked save] three vessels and two, [nor was she given her middaydrink save when her midday-resting was near.] (IAar, M.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) yawomu AlQivonayoni, (S, Msb,) or AlQivonaAni alone, (M, K,) One of the days of the week; [the second; namely, Monday;] because the first, with the Arabs, is AlOaHadu; (M;) as also AlvRinaI↓, like UilaI; (K;) so in the copies of the K; [or,] accord. to some, AlvRuniIRu↓, [originally AlvRunuwIu,] of the measure fuEuwl, like vudiIRN [pl. of vadoIN], is used in this sense; (TA;) or Alyawomu AlvRunaIRu↓, [so in the M, accord. to the TT,] mentioned by Sb, on the authority of certain of the Arabs: (M:) the pl. is OavonaMCN and OavaAniynu, (M, K,) the latter mentioned on the authority of Th: but it has no dual: and those who say OavonaMCN form this pl. from AlQivonu, although this has not been in use: (M:) or it has neither dual nor pl., (S, Msb,) being itself a dual; (S;) but if you would form a pl. from it, you would regard it as itself a sing., and make its pl. OavaAniynu: (S, Msb:) IB says that OavaAniynu has not been heard [from the Arabs], and is only mentioned by Fr, on the ground of analogy; that it is far-fetched in respect of analogy; and that the pl. heard is OavonaMCN: Seer and others mention, as heard from the Arabs, UinRahu layaSuwmu AlOavonaMCa [Verily he fasts on the Mondays]. (TA.) Alvnyn in ywm Alvnyn has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) IJ says that the article Al in Alvnyn is not redundant, though the word is not an epithet: Abu-l-'Abbás says that the prefixing of the article in this case is allowable because the virtual meaning is Alyawomu AlvRaAniI [the second day]. (M.) The saying Alyawomu AlQivonaAni means The name of to-day [is AlAvnAn]; and is like the saying Alyawomu yawomaAni [to-day is two days] and Alyawomu xamosapa EaXara mina AlXRahori [to-day is fifteen of the month]. (Sb, M.) Sometimes, yawomu Qvonayoni, without the article Al, occurs in poetry. (M, K.) When a pronoun refers to AlAvnAn [as meaning Monday], this word may be treated in two ways, [as a sing. and as a dual,] but the more chaste way is to treat it as a sing., as meaning the day: (Msb:) [thus,] Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaI AlQivonaAni bimaA fiyhi [Monday passed with what occurred in it]; making it sing. and masc.; and thus he did in the case of every day of the week, except that he made AljumoEap fem.: Abu-I-Jarráh used to say, maDaI AlQivonaAni bimaA fiyhimaA, treating the word as a numeral; and thus he treated the third and fourth and fifth days, saying in each of these cases bimaA fiyhinRa. (M.) ― -b3- [AivonaA EaXara, fem. AivonataA EaXorapa; respectively, in a case of nasb and khafd, AivonaIo EaXara and AivonataIo EaXorapa; and with Q when not immediately preceded by a quiescence; mean Twelve: see EaXarapN.]

AivonawiIRN AvnwI Avnwy
AivonawiIRN, [with Q when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, in the CK erroneously written AavonawiIR,] One who fasts alone on the second day of the week. (IAar, Th, M, K.)

AlQivonayoniyRapu c
AlQivonayoniyRapu [The doctrine of dualism: see vanawiIRN]. (TA.)

mavonaI mvnI mvny mvnyy
mavonaI (S, Mgh) and vunaMCu↓ (T, S) [Two and two; two and two together; or two at a time and two at a time]: they are imperfectly decl., in like manner as [mavolavu and] vulaAvu, as explained in art. vlv; (S, TA;) [because] changed from the original form of AivonaAni QvonaAni; (T, Mgh, TA;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of AivonaAni; (Sb, S in art. vlv, q. v.;) or because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to AivonaAni QvonaAni. (S ibid.) You say, jaAWuwA mavonaI and vunaMCa↓ (M, K) or mavonaI mavonaI, (S,) but this is a repetition of the word only, not of the meaning, (Mgh,) and in like manner one says of women, (M, K, *) i. e. They came two [and] two. (S, M, K.) And it is said in a trad., SalaApu AllRayoli mavonaI mavonaI, i. e. The prayer of night is two rek'ahs [and] two rek'ahs (rakoEataAni rakoEataAni). (TA.) [See also other exs. voce vulaAvu.] ― -b2- mavonaI AlOayaAdiI The repeating a benefit, or benefaction; or reiterating it; conferring it twice, or thrice; (As, T, K;) or twice, or more than twice: (K:) or the shares remaining of the slaughtered camel (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) in the game called Almayosir, (A'Obeyd, T, S, K,) which shares a bountiful man used to purchase, and give for food to the OaboraAm, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) i. e., those who took no part in the game, not contributing: (M:) or the taking a portion time after time. (AA, T, S, M.) ― -b3- mavaAnK [is pl. of mavonFI as signifying A place of doubling, or folding &c.: and hence means ― -b4- ] The knees and elbows of a horse or similar beast. (T, K.) ― -b5- And The bends of a valley. (T, K. See vinoIN.) ― -b6- And, as pl. of mavonFI, The chords of the lute that are after the first: (M, K:) or mvnI signifies a chord [of a lute] composed of two twists: or, as some say, the second chord. (Har p. 244. See mavolavN.) ― -b7- mavonFI also signifies The zimaAm [or noserein] of a she-camel: and Er-Rághib says that the mvnAp [i. e. mavonaAp↓ or mivonaAp↓] is the doubled, or folded, part of the extremity of the zimaAm. (TA.) ― -b8- AlmavaAniI as relating to the Kur-án is pl. of mavonFI, (Mgh,) or of mavonaApN↓: (AHeyth, T, Mgh:) it has three applications, accord. to A'Obeyd: (T, Mgh:) it signifies The Kur-án altogether; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) so in the Kur xxxix 24; (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh;) meaning that the mention of reward and punishment is repeated, or reiterated, in it; (Fr, T;) or so called because the verse of mercy is conjoined with that of punishment; (S;) or because narratives and promises and threats are repeated in it; or because one peruses it repeatedly without being wearied: (Mgh:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh,) [the first chapter, called] the faAtiHap, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh,) or AlHamodu, (K,) which means the same; (TA;) so in the Kur xv. 87; (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh;) because it is repeated, or recited twice, in every [act of prayer termed a] rakoEap, (Fr, Zj, AHeyth, T, S,) or with every chapter, (Th, M,) or in every prayer; (Mgh;) or because containing praise of God: (Zj, T, Mgh:) [but see AlsRaboEu AlmavaAniI voce saboEapN:] or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh,) the chapters that are less than those containing a hundred verses, (S, M, Mgh,) or that are less than the long ones (AlTRuwal, q. v.), and less than those containing a hundred verses, (A'Obeyd, T, K, but in [most of] the copies of the K duwna AlmiOatayoni is put in the place of duwna AlmiYiyna, which is the right reading, TA,) and more than [those of the portion called] the mufaSRal, (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh, K,) as is related on the authority of the Prophet by Ibn-Mes'ood and 'Othmán and Ibn- 'Abbás; (AHeyth, T;) because, (Mgh,) or as though, (T,) occupying the second place after those containing a hundred verses: (T, Mgh:) or the chapters, (T, K,) six and twenty in number, (T,) entitled AlHajR and AlqaSaS and AlnRamol and AlnRuwr and AlOanofaAl and maroyam and AlEanokabuwt and AlrRuwm and yaAsiyn and AlfuroqaAn and AlHijor and AlrRaEod and sabaA and AlmalaAYikap and UiboraAhiym and SaAd and muHamRad and luqomen and Alguraf and AlmuWomin and AlzRuxoruf and AlsRajodap and AlOaHoqaAf and AljaAviyap and AldRuxaAn (T, K) and AlOaHozaAb, (K,) which last has been omitted by the copyists of the T: (TA:) or the chapters of which the first is the baqarap, and the last is baraMCap: or what is repeated, of the Kur-án, time after time. (M, K.)

mavonaApN mvnAh mvnAp mvnI
mavonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoIN: and vinaAyapN: and mavonFI; the last in two places. ― -b2- It is said in a trad. that one of the signs of the resurrection will be the public reading, or reciting, of the mavonaAp, (T, S,) which means That which has been desired to be transcribed from a source other than the Book of God: (T:) or a certain book, (T, K,) [the Mishna,] which the learned men, and the recluses, of the Children of Israel, after Moses, composed after their own desire, from a source other than the Book of God, as A'Obeyd says on the authority of a man learned in the books of the earlier times, (T,) containing the histories of the Children of Israel after Moses, in which they allowed and disallowed what they pleased: (K:) or what is sung: (K:) or what is called in Persian duw bayotiI, (S, K,) which means two verses, each composed of a pair of hemistichs; (TA;) i. e. what is sung; but A'Obeyd explains it otherwise than thus: (S:) it is what is known among the 'Ajam by the term mavonawiIRN↓, as though this were a rel. n. from mavonaApN: the vulgar say [erroneously] cuw bayot, with the pointed c. (TA.)

mivonaApN mvnAh mvnAp mvnI
mivonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoIN: and vinaAyapN; the latter in two places: and see also mavonFI.

muvanRFI mvnI mvny mvnyy
muvanRFI [pass. part. n. of 2. ― -b2- Dualized: a dual. ― -b3- muvanRaApN fawoqiyRapN Marked with two points above: an epithet added to tMC to prevent its being mistaken for bMC or vMC or yMC. And muvanRaApN taHotiyRapN Marked with two points below: an epithet added to yMC to prevent its being mistaken for bMC or tMC or vMC.] ― -b4- AlTRawylu AlmuvanRaI (assumed tropical:) That which passes away [out of sight, or disappears,] by length; mostly used of a thing that is long without breadth. (TA.)

mavoniIRN mvnI mvny mvnyy
mavoniIRN [pass. part. n. of 1; Doubled or folded &c.] ― -b2- OaroDN mavoniyRapN Land, or ground, turned over twice for sowing, or cultivating. (Mgh, and A and TA in art. vlv.)

mavonawiIRN mvnwI mvnwy
mavonawiIRN: see mavonaApN.

mavonawiyRapN mvnwyh mvnwyp
mavonawiyRapN: see vunoyaA, in four places.

vuwRapN vwh vwp
vuwRapN [mentioned in the M under the head of vw, as the radical letters, but in the T and K in art. vwI,] sing. of vuwFI, (IAar, T, K,) which latter, (IAar, T,) or the former, (K,) signifies The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent: (IAar, T, K:) or the former, pieces of rag made in the form of a ball of thread or string, upon a peg, or stake, upon which the skin of milk is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated; as also vuwiIRN↓; (M, K;) which latter we hold to be from vww because syn. with vuwRapN, like quwRapN: (ISd in the M:) or a piece of rag, which is moistened, and put upon the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated: (T:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) a piece of rag, (M, K,) or some wool wound upon the head of a peg, or stake, (IB, TA,) put beneath the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, in order to preserve it from being injured by the ground; (M, IB, K;) pl. vuwFI: (IB, TA:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) an elevated and a rugged spot, upon which, sometimes, stones are set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way; (M, K;) like SuwRapN. (M. See also vaAyapN, in art. vwI.)

vuwIRN vwI vwp vwy
vuwIRN: see above.

4 OavaOotuhu bisahomK c
4. OavaOotuhu bisahomK, (S in art. vO, [incorrectly there mentioned, as is said by IB and others and in the K,] and K in the present art. and in art. AvO,) inf. n. UivaMCapN, (S,) I shot him, or shot at him, with an arrow; (S, K;) so says AA, and Ks says the like; (S;) as also Oavawotuhu, and, accord. to As, Oavayotuhu, (TA in art. vO,) which is a strange word. (TA in the present art.) It is mentioned in the present art. by Sgh; (K in art. AvO;) and this is its proper place; (TA in the present art.;) the verb, accord. to him, being like OaqaAma: (TA in art. AvO:) A 'Obeyd has mentioned it in art. AvO, (K in that art.,) as also Az; holding the verb to be like SanaEa; and so IKtt and IKoot assert it to be. (TA.)

vaMCN vMC
vaMCN The name of the letter v, q. v.; as also vaA: pl. [of the former,] vaMCaAtN; and [of the latter,] OavowaMCN and OavoyaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.) ＝ -A2- It also stands for vanaMCN, and vawaAbN, and the like. (Idem ubi suprà.) ＝ -A3- Also The best of anything; as, for instance, of wheat, and of flesh-meat, and of sugar. (Kh, TA ubi suprà.)

vaAYiIRN c
vaAYiIRN and vaAwiIRN rel. ns. of vaMCN and vaA, the names of the letter v; as also vayawiIRN. (TA ubi suprà.)

1 vaAba vAb
1. vaAba, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yavuwbu, (S, Mgh, &c.,) inf. n. vawobN (S, M, Msb, K) and vawabaAnN (S) and vuWuwbN, (M, K,) He, or it, (a thing, M,) returned; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also vwRb↓, inf. n. tavowiybN: (M, K:) he returned to a place to which he had come before; or it returned &c.: (T:) he (a man) returned, after he had gone away. (S.) You say, tafarRaquwA vumRa vaAbuwA i. e. [They became separated, or dispersed: then] they returned. (A.) ― -b2- vAb UilaI QllRehi, like taAba, (assumed tropical:) He returned [from disobedience] to obedience to God; he repented; as also OanaAba. (T.) ― -b3- vAb also signifies (assumed tropical:) He returned to a state of advertency, or vigilance; or he had his attention roused. (Th, T.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) He returned to a state of health, or soundness: (TA, from a trad.:) he became convalescent, and fat, after leanness. (Mgh.) And vAb jisomuhu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. vawabaAnN; (M, K;) and jisomuhu AvAb↓; (IKt, M;) and vAb Uilayohi jisomuhu; (T, M, A;) and AvAb↓, alone; (S, M, A;) (tropical:) He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (S, M, K; *) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.) ― -b5- vAb Uilayohi Eaqoluhu (tropical:) [His reason, or intellect, returned to him]: and Hilomuhu [his forbearance, or clemency]. (A.) ― -b6- vAb AlmaMCu (assumed tropical:) The water of a well returned, or collected again: (T:) the water attained again its former state after some had been drawn: (M:) the water collected [again] in a wateringtrough, or tank. (S.) ― -b7- vAb AlnRaAsu (assumed tropical:) The people collected themselves together, and came. (S.) And vAb Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The company of men came following one another: the verb is not used in this sense in speaking of one person. (M.) ― -b8- vAb said of a man's property, (tropical:) It became abundant, and collected. (A.) ― -b9- Said of dust, (tropical:) It rose, or spread, or diffused itself, and became abundant. (A.) ― -b10- Said of a watering-trough, or tank, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. vawobN (AZ, T, M, K) and vawabaAnN (AZ, T) and vuWuwbN, (M, K,) (tropical:) It became full: (AZ, T, M, A, K:) or nearly full. (AZ, T, M, K.)

2 vwRib vwb
2. vwRib, inf. n. tavowiybN: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- vwab baEoda xaSaASapK (tropical:) [He returned to a state of richness, or competence, after poverty, or straitness, or being in an evil condition]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tavowiybN meaning The calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh, K,) to prayer, (M, K,) and to other things, (M,) is said to be from vawobN “ a garment, ” (Mgh,) because a man, when he comes crying out for aid, makes a sign with his garment, (M, Mgh,) moving it about, raising his hand with it, in order that he to whom he calls may see it, (Mgh,) and this action is like a calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh,) and an announcing, to him; so the calling, or summoning, by reason to frequent usage of this word [as meaning the making a sign with a garment], came to be thus called; and one said of the caller, or summoner, vwab: (Mgh:) or it means the calling, or summoning, twice; (M, K;) or the repeating a call or summons; from vAb “ he returned: ” (Mgh:) you say, vwRb, inf. n. as above, (T, Msb,) meaning he called, or summoned, one time after another; (T;) he repeated his call, or cry: (Msb:) and hence tvwyb in the OacaAn; (T, Msb;) i. e., the saying of the muWacRin, after having, by the AcAn, called the people to prayer, AlSRalaAho raHimakumu QllRehu AlSRalaAho [Prayer: may God have mercy on you! Prayer!]; thus calling to it a second time: (T:) or his saying, (S, TA,) in the morning call to prayer, (S,) AlSRalaApu xayorN mina AlnRawomN [Prayer is better than sleep]; (S, TA;) for he resumes his call by saying this after he has said, HaIRa EalaI AlSRalaAho [and HaIRa EalaI AlfalaAHN]; desiring the people to hasten to prayer: (TA:) or his saying, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyrmn Alnwm twice, (T, K,) after having said, HaIR Ely AlSlAh HIR Ely AlflAH: (T:) or the old tvwyb was the saying of the muWacRin, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyr mn Alnwm: and the modern, AlSRalaAho AlSRalaAho; or qaAmato qaAmato. (Mgh.) It also signifies The UiqaAmap; (Mgh, K, TA;) [meaning, the chanting, by the mubalRiguwn, in a mosque, not by the muWacRin, the common words of the OacaAn, with the addition of qado qaAmati AlSRalaAho (The time of prayer has come), pronounced twice after HIR ElI AlflAH;] i. e. the AqAmp of prayer: (IAth, TA:) and this is what is meant by the phrase, in a trad., UicaA vuwRiba biAlSRalaApi [When the words of the AqAmp are chanted]. (IAth, Mgh, TA.) And The praying after the prayer divinely ordained. (Yoo, T, K.) You say, vwRb, meaning He performed a supererogatory prayer after the prescribed; tvwyb being only after the prescribed; being the praying after praying: (T:) and tvwRb↓ signifies the same. (K.) And vRwb birakoEatayoni He performed two rek'ahs as a supererogatory act. (A.) But this and the similar significations are said to be post-classical. (MF.) ― -b4- See also 4, in four places. ＝ -A2- vayRabato, (T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. tavoyiybN; (T, Mgh;) formed from vayRibN, upon supposition [that the medial radical letter of this word is I, whereas many hold that letter to be w]; (Mgh;) or tavayRabato↓; (K in art. vyb; [the author of which seems to have supposed that, for vayRabato, one should read vuyRibato; and therefore he gives muvayRabN as syn. with vayRibN;]) She (a woman) became what
is termed vayRib. (T, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Accord. to my copy of the Mgh, it also signifies She (a camel) became what is termed naAb: but I think that, in this instance, it is a mistranscription, for nayRabato.] ＝ -A3- [See also the last sentence of the second paragraph of art. vrb; and compare, with what is there said by SM, meanings assigned below to mavaAbN and mavaAbapN.]

3 AlxuTRaAbu yuvaAwibuwnahaA AlxTAb yvAwbwnhA
3. AlxuTRaAbu yuvaAwibuwnahaA The suitors return to her (namely, a woman such as is termed vayRib,) time after time. (A, Mgh.)

4 AvAb OvAb AvAb
4. AvAb: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- It may also mean (assumed tropical:) It (a valley, or a well,) had a return of water after a stoppage thereof. (Ham p. 598.) ＝ -A2- AvAb QllRehu jisomahu (tropical:) God restored him to fatness, after leanness; (A;) restored his body to a good state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- UinRa Eamuwda AldRiyni laA yuvaAbu biAlnRisaMCa Uino maAla (assumed tropical:) Verily the column of the religion cannot be set upright again by women, if it incline: said by Umm-Selemeh to 'Áïsheh, when the latter desired to go forth to El-Basrah. (T, L.) ― -b3- AvAbhu QllRehu, (T, S, * M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UivaAbapN; (Mgh;) and Oavowabahu [dev. from rule]; (M, K;) and vwRbhu↓, (T, A,) inf. n. tvowiybN; (T, Mgh;) God recompensed, compensated, requited, or rewarded, him: (T, S, * M, A, Mgh, * Msb, K:) said in relation to good and to evil. (T.) And AvAbhu, (Lh, M,) and Oavowabahu, (T,) mavuwbapF HasanapF, (Lh, T, M,) and mavowabapF, (Lh, M,) He (God) gave him a good recompense, compensation, &c. (M.) And mavuwbatahu vwRbhu↓ He gave him his recompense, &c. (M, K.) It is said in a trad., OaviybuwA OaxaAkumo, i. e. Recompense ye your brother for his good deed. (TA.) And in the Kur [lxxxiii. last verse], halo AlkufRaAru maA kaAnuwA yafoEaluwna vuwRiba↓ Have the unbelievers been recompensed for what they did? (T, S, M.) And one says also, AvAbhu mino hibatihi, meaning He gave him a substitute, something instead or in exchange, or a compensation, for his gift. (Mgh, * and TA in art. jnb.) And mino kacaA vwRbhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tavowiybN, (K,) He gave him a substitute, &c., for such a thing. (M, K. *) ― -b4- AvAb AlvRawoba, inf. n. UivaAbapN, He sewed the garment, or piece of cloth, the second time: when one sews it the first time, [in a slight manner,] you say of him malRahu [and XalRahu, i. e. “ he sewed it in the manner termed ‘ running ’ ”]. (T.) ― -b5- AvAb AlHawoDa (tropical:) He filled the watering-trough, or tank: (K, TA:) or nearly filled it. (K.)

5 tvwRb tvwb vAb vwb
5. tvwRb: ― -b2- and tavayRabato: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b3- The former also signifies He gained, or earned, a vawaAb [or recompense, &c.]. (K.) But this is said to be post-classical. (MF.)

6 tvAwb tvAwb
6. tvAwb: see vuYiba, in art. vOb.

10 AstvAb maAlFA AstvAb mAlA
10. AstvAb maAlFA He restored to himself, or repossessed himself of, property; syn. AisotarojaEahu; (T, A, K;) his property having gone away. (T, A.) And Aisotavabotu bimaAlika I restored to myself, or repossessed myself of, property, by means of that which thou gavest me; my property having gone away. (A.) El-Kumeyt says,
UinRa AlEaXiyrapa tasotaviybu bimaAlihi
fayugiyru wahowa muwafRirN OamowaAlahaA
[Verily the tribe restore to themselves wealth by means of his property; and he makes incursions into hostile territories at his own expense, making their property abundant by the spoil that they gain with him]. (T, TA.) ― -b2- AstvAbhu He asked him to recompense, compensate, requite, or reward, him. (S, K.)

vawobN vwb
vawobN A garment, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [or piece of cloth or stuff,] that is worn by men, composed of linen, cotton, wool, fur, xazR [q. v.], (Mgh, Msb,) silk, or the like; (Msb;) but [properly] not what is cut out of several pieces, such as the shirt, and trousers, or drawers, &c.; (Mgh;) [though often applied to a shirt or shift (qamiyS or diroE) and to a jubRap &c.:] it seems to be so called because the wearer returns to it, or it to the wearer, time after time: (Mgh:) [also a garment worn by women and girls over the shift; (see OuSodapN;) app., as in the present day, a long gown, reaching to the feet, with very wide sleeves:] pl. viyaAbN [the pl. of mult.] (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and OavowaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, Msb, K) and OavowubN and OavoWubN, (S, M, K,) the last two being pls. of pauc., and the latter of them being thus pronounced with C by some of the Arabs because the dammeh immediately after w is deemed difficult of utterance; for which reason they substitute C for w in all instances like this. (S.) ― -b2- Curtains, and the like, are not [properly] called viyaAb; but OamotiEapu Albayoti: (Mgh, Msb:) though Es-Sarakhsee uses the phrase viyaAbu Albayoti. (Mgh.) taEalRaqa biviyaAbi QllRehi (tropical:) [He clung to the curtains of the House of God], i. e., to the curtains of the Kaabeh, is a tropical expression. (A.) ― -b3- Sometimes, vawobN is used metonymically to signify (tropical:) A thing [of any kind] that veils, covers, or protects: as in the saying of a poet,
kavawobi Qboni biyDK waqaAhumo bihi
fasadRa EalaI AlsRaAlikiyna AlsRabiylaA
[Like the means of protection adopted by Ibn-Beed: he protected them by it, and closed the way against the passengers]. (TA.) Ibn-Beed was a wealthy merchant of the tribe of 'Ád, who hamstrung his she-camel upon a mountain-road, and stopped the way [to his abode] with it. (K in art. byD.) ― -b4- In the same manner, also, viyaAbN is used to signify (tropical:) Weapons. (Ham p. 63.) ― -b5- And OavowaAbN is sometimes employed to signify (assumed tropical:) The wearers of garments; the wearers' bodies. (R, TA.) Esh-Shemmákh says, (T,) or Leylà, describing camels, (TA,)
wamawohaA biOavowaAbK xifaAfK falaA taraI
lahaA XabahFA UilRaA AlnRaEaAma AlmunafRaraA
i. e. They mounted them, namely, the travellingcamels, (T,) with their [light, or agile,] bodies: [and thou seest not anything like them, except ostriches scared away.] (T, TA.) And in like manner, also, the dual is employed to signify (assumed tropical:) The wearer's body, or self; or what the garments infold: and viyaAb is employed in the same manner. (TA.) You say, lilRhi vawobaAhu, i. e. (tropical:) To God be he [meaning his excellence] attributed! [for nothing but what is excellent is to be attributed to God:] (A:) or it means lilRhi darRuhu [To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from him! or his good deed! &c.: see arts. Alh and dr]. (K.) And fiI vawobaIo OabiI Oano Oafiyahu meaning (tropical:) [On me and on my father it rests, or lies, or be it, that I pay it: or] fiIcimRatiI wacimRapiOabiI [on my responsibility and the responsibility of my father]. (K, TA.) And Ausolulo viyaAbaka mino viyaAbiI (tropical:) Withdraw, or separate, thyself from me. (A.) ― -b6- [The following exs. are mostly, or all, tropical.] ― -b7- UinRi AlmayRita layuboEavu fiI viyaAbihi AlRatiI yamuwtu fiyhaA, (K, * TA,) a saying of Mohammad, repeated by Aboo-Sa'eed El-Khudree, when, being about to die, he had called for new garments, and put them on: (TA:) it means Verily the dead will be raised in his garments in which he dies; accord. to some; and was used in this sense by Aboo-Sa'eed: (ElKhattábee, MF, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) [agreeably with] his works (K, TA) with which his life is closed: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) in the state in which he dies, according as it is good or evil. (TA.) ― -b8- waviyaAbaka faTahRiro, in the Kur [lxxiv. 4], means And purify thy garments: (Abu-l-'Abbás, T:) or shorten thy garments; for the shortening them is a means of purity: (T:) or (assumed tropical:) put not on thy garments in a state of disobedience or unrighteousness: (I'Ab, T:) or (assumed tropical:) be not perfidious; for [figuratively speaking,] he who is so pollutes his garments: (Fr, T:) or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) purify thy heart: (Abu-l-'Abbás, T, K:) or (assumed tropical:) purify thyself (IKt, T, TA) from sins, or offences: (IKt, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) rectify thine actions, or thy conduct. (TA.) ― -b9- You say, fulaAno naqiIRu AlvRawobi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one is free from vice, or fault: (A:) and TaAhiru AlvRawobi (tropical:) [the same; or pure in heart, or conduct, or reputation]. (TA in art. nSH.) And danisu AlvRiyaAbi (tropical:) Vicious, or faulty: (A:) or perfidious: (Fr, T:) or foul, or evil, in reputation, (T, TA,) in conduct, or actions, and in the way that he follows [with respect to religion and morality]. (TA.) ― -b10- kalaAbisi vawobaIo zuwrK: see mutaXabRiEN. ― -b11- OaEoraDa vawobu Almalobasi and Almilobasi &c.: see EaruDa. ― -b12- vawobu AlmaMCi (assumed tropical:) [The membrane called] AlsRalaI and Algirosu. (K. See these two words.)

viybN vyb
viybN: see vaAYibN, in two places.

vubapN vbh vbp
vubapN The place where the water collects in a valley or low ground; so called because the water returns to it: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) and the middle of a watering-trough or tank, (T, S, M,) to which the water returns when it has been emptied, (S,) or to which what remains of the water returns; (T;) as also mavaAbN↓: (S:) the p is a substitute for the w, the medial radical, which is suppressed; (S, L;) the word being from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu: (L:) Aboo-Is-hák infers that this is the case from its having for its dim. vuwayobapN↓: but it may be from vabRayotu “ I collected together: ” (M:) it is
mentioned in the K in art. vbI or vbw, and not here. (TA.) See also art. vbw or vbI. ― -b2- Also A company of men; (T, M, L;) and so OuvobiyRapN: (M:) or a company of men in a state of separation or dispersion; (T;) a distinct body, or company, of people: (Yoo, T:) and a troop of horsemen: (M:) pl. vubaAtN and vubuwna (T, M) and vibuwna: (S and M in art. vbI, and M in art. vbw also:) accord. to some, from vaAba, being originally vuwbapN; and its dim. is vuwayobapN↓: accord. to others, it is originally vuboyapN; (T, L;) and its pl. is vubFI. (L.) Hence, in the Kur [iv. 73], faQnofiruwA vubaAtK, i. e. [And go ye forth to to war against the unbelievers] in troops, (Fr, T,) or in distinct bodies. (Yoo, T.) See, again, art. vbw or vbI.

vuwabaMCu vwbMC
vuwabaMCu: see vuWabaMCu, in art. vOb.

vawaAbN vwAb
vawaAbN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and mavaAbapN↓ (T, Msb) and mavuwbapN↓ (T, S, M, K) and mavowabapN↓, (EtTemeemee, T, M, K,) the last anomalous, (M,) and unknown to the Kilábees, who knew the second of these words, (T,) A recompense, compensation, requital, or reward, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of obedience [to God]: (S:) or absolutely; for good and for evil; as appears from the words of the Kur, halo vuwRiba AlkufRaAru [cited above, see 4]; but more especially and frequently, for good. (IAth, L, MF, TA.) ― -b2- vawaAbN is also used as a quasi-inf. n., in the sense of UivaAbapN; and in this case, accord to the Koofees and Baghdádees, it may govern as a verb, [like the inf. n.,] as in the saying,
liUanRa vawaAba QllRhi kulRa muwaHRidK
jinaAnN mina Alfirodawosi fiyhaA yuxalRadu
[For God's rewarding every believer in his unity will be the giving gardens of Paradise, wherein he will be made to abide for ever]. (Expos. of the Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.) ― -b3- It signifies also (tropical:) Honey; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the good that proceeds from bees. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And in like manner, (tropical:) [Rain; i. e.] the good that results from the winds. (A, TA. [See vaAYibN.]) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Bees; (M, K;) because they return [to their hives]. (M.)

vayRibN vyb
vayRibN, [like sayRidN; originally vawiybN, or vayowibN; i. e.] of the measure faEiylN, (Mgh,) or fayoEilN; (Msb;) A woman who has become separated from her husband (Lth, T, M, Mgh, K) in any manner: (Lth, T, M, Mgh:) or a woman whose husband has died, or who has been divorced, and has then returned to the marriage-state: (AHeyth, TA:) or one that is not a virgin: (IAth, TA:) or a woman to whom a man has gone in; and a man who has gone in to a woman: (Ks, ISk, S, Mgh, K:) or a person who has married: (Msb:) applied to a man and to a woman; (As, S, M, Msb;) like bikorN and OayRimN: (Mgh, Msb:) from vaAba; (IAth, Mgh, Msb;) because they generally return time after time to the marriage-state: (Mgh:) but mostly applied to a woman; because she returns to her family in a manner different from the first [state]; (Msb;) or because the suitors return to her time after time: (Mgh:) or it is not applied to a man (Lth, El-'Eyn, T, M, Mgh, K) except in the dual form, as when one says waladu AlvRayRibayoni: (Lth, El-'Eyn, T, M, K:) and a woman is also termed muvayRibN↓; (M;) or muvayRabN↓, like muEaZamN: (K: [but see 2, last sentence but two:]) the pl. of vayibN applied to a woman is vayRibaAtN, (T, Mgh, Msb,) and the post-classical writers say vuyRabN, which has not been heard as genuine Arabic: (Mgh, * Msb:) its pl. if applied to a man is vuyRibuwna. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., AlvRayRibaAni yurojamaAni waAlbikoraAni yujoladaAni wayugarRabaAni [The two persons of whom each has previously had carnal intercourse in marriage with one of the other sex shall be stoned if they commit adultery together; and the two who have previously had no connubial intercourse with others shall be flogged and banished if they commit fornication together]. (T.) ― -b2- It is also applied to (assumed tropical:) A woman who has attained the age of puberty, though a a virgin; tropically, and by extension of its proper signification. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- This word is mentioned in the K [and M] in art. vyb; and its mention in art. vwb is said by the author of the K to be wrong: but IAth and many others decisively assert that it is from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu, “ he returned. ” (MF, TA.)

vuwayobapN vwybh vwybp
vuwayobapN: see vubapN, in two places.

viyAbapN vwb vyAbh vyAbp
viyAbapN and vuyuwbapN, as meaning The state of being a vayRib, are not of the genuine language of the Arabs. (Mgh.)

viyaAbiIRN vwb vyAbI vyAby
viyaAbiIRN One who takes care of the clothes in the bath. (K.) [A post-classical word.]

vawRaMbN vwMb
vawRaMbN i. q. tawRaAbN [One who repents, or returns from disobedience to obedience to God, much or often]. (T.) ＝ -A2- A seller of garments, or pieces of cloth: (AZ, T, L, K:) and a possessor thereof. (Sb, S, L, K.)

biYorN lahaA vaAYibN c
biYorN lahaA vaAYibN (tropical:) A well into which water returns after one has drawn from it; (A, TA;) see mavaAbN; and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense in the second of the following phrases,] biYirN lahaA viybN↓, and waEiybK ciAtu viybK↓ [in which wEyb is an epithet]: (T, L, TA:) or the first of these three phrases means a well of which the water stops sometimes, and then returns. (Ham p. 598.) You say of a well (bYr), maA OasoraEa vaAYibahaA (assumed tropical:) How quick is its returning supply of water! (T.) ― -b2- vaAYibu AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) The water of the sea when it flows after ebbing. (K.) Hence, kalaON mivolu vaAYibi AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) Fresh, sappy, [green,] herbage. (T, L.) ― -b3- qawomN lahumo vaAYibN (tropical:) A people, or number of men, who come company after company. (A, TA.) ― -b4- vaAYibN also signifies (tropical:) A violent wind that blows at the beginning of rain. (S, K, TA.)

mavaAbN mvAb
mavaAbN: see mavaAbapN, in four places: ― -b2- and see vubipN. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The place from which the water returns [to supply the place of that which has been drawn, in a well]: whence biYorN lahaA vaAYibN↓ [see vaAYibN]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The station of the water-drawer, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) above the EuruwX [which means the pieces of wood upon which he stands], (A 'Obeyd, T,) or at the brink, where is the EaroX [sing. of EuruwX], (S,) or which forms part of the EuruwX, (M,) of a well: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) or the middle of a well: (K:) or it has this meaning also: (M:) pl. mavaAbaAtN. (T, M.) [See also mavaAbpN.] ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The construction, or casing, of stones (TIRu AlHijaArapi) that succeed one another from top to bottom [round the interior of a well]. (IAar.) [See again mavaAbapN.]

mavaAbapN mvAb mvAbh mvAbp
mavaAbapN (accord. to Aboo-Is-hák originally mavowabapN↓, T) A place to which people return, (ISh, Aboo-Is-hák, T, S, Msb,) or to which one returns, (ISh, S, Msb,) time after time; (S;) and mavaAbN↓ signifies the same: (Aboo-Is-hák, T:) and the former, a place of assembly or congregation: (ISh:) or a place where people assemble, or congregate, after they have separated, or dispersed; as also ↓the latter word: (M, K:) and a place of alighting or abode; an abode; or a house; because the inhabitants thereof return to it (ISh, S) after having gone to their affairs: (S:) the pl. is mavaAbaAtN; [also mentioned above as pl. of mavaAbN;] (ISh;) or it is mavaAbN↓; (S;) [or this is a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to Fr and others, mavaAabapN and mavaAbN↓ are the same: Th says that a house, or tent, (bayot,) is called mavaAbapN; and some say mavowabapN↓; but no one reads thus [in the Kur]. (TA.) It has the first of all these meanings in the Kur ii. 119: (T, S, Bd, Jel, TA:) or it there means a place of recompense or reward for the pilgrimage to the Kaabeh and the visitation thereof. (Bd.) ― -b2- And, sometimes, The place where the hunter, or fowler, puts his snare. (S.) ― -b3- mavaAbapN AlbiYori (tropical:) The place where the water of the well collects: (A, TA:) or the place reached by the water of the well when it returns and collects after one has drawn from it. (M, K.) [Hence,] jamRato mavaAbapu jaholihi (tropical:) His ignorance became confirmed. (A, TA.) And kaAna yasotajimRu mavaAbapa safahihi (tropical:) [He used to wait for his lightwittedness, or silliness, to attain its full degree]: a metaphorical phrase, occurring in a trad. (Har p. 68.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) The stones that project, or overhang, around the well, (M, K,) upon which the man sometimes stands in order that the bucket (dalow or garob) may not strike against the side of the well: (M:) or the place where it is walled round within (mawoDiEu TayRihaA): (K:) or, accord. to IAar, it means TaIRu AlbiYori; but [ISd says,] I know not whether he mean thereby mawoDiEu TayRihaA, or the building it [or walling it round within] with stones; though it is rarely that a word of the measure mafaEalapN [like mvAbp] is an inf. n. (M.) [See mavaAbN: and see what is said of tavowiybN in the last sentence of the second paragraph of art. vrb.] ― -b5- mavaAbaAtN [the pl.] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The foundations of a house. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A2- See also vawaAbN.

mavuwabapN mvwbh mvwbp
mavuwabapN: see vawaAbN.

mavowabapN mvwbh mvwbp
mavowabapN: see mavaAbapN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also vawaAbN.

muvayRibN mvyb
muvayRibN and muvayRibN: see vayRibN.

musotavaAbaAtu AlrRiyaAHi 1
musotavaAbaAtu AlrRiyaAHi (tropical:) Winds that are attended by prosperity and blessing; from which one hopes for a good result [i. e. rain]. (A, TA.)

1 vaAxa c and saAxa
1. vaAxa saAxa both signify He, or it, sank into the ground; and Yaakoob asserts that the v in the former is a substitute for the s in the latter. (L, TA.) You say, vaAxato qadamuhu biAlwaHoli, (S,) or fiI AlwaHoli, (L,) aor. tavuwxu and taviyxu, His foot sank, or entered, into the mire. (S, L.) And vaAxati AlUiSobaEu, aor. as above, (L, K,) inf. n. vawoxN, (L,) The finger entered, or sank, into a swollen, or tumid, or a soft, or yielding, substance; (L, K;) as also saAxat, (L,) and taAxat: (Lth:) but this last is disapproved by IDrd, and J and others do not mention it. (TA in art. twx.)

1 vaAra mstvAbAt AlryAH
1. vaAra, aor. yavuwru, (M,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN and vawaraAnN, (M, K,) It (a thing, M) became raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked; syn. haAja; (M;) syn. of the inf. n. hayajaAnN: (K:) as also tvwRr↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- Said of dust, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) and of smoke, (M, A,) and of other things, (M, TA,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN (S, M, Msb, K) and vawaraAnN, (K,) (tropical:) It became raised, or stirred up; (Mgh, Msb;) and spread: (Mgh:) or rose, (S, M, A, K,) and appeared; (M;) as also tvwRr↓: (K:) also said of the redness in the sky after sunset, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, (tropical:) it spread upon the horizon, and rose: (TA: [see vaworN:]) and vAr, said of anything, means (assumed tropical:) it appeared and spread. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Said of a camel lying upon his breast, He became roused, or put in motion or action; as also tvwRr↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Said of the bird called AlqaTRA, (M, A,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (K,) or vaworN and vawaraAnN, (M,) It rose (M, A, K) from the place where it lay; (M, A;) as also tvwRr↓: (K:) and of a swarm of locusts, it rose; (M, K;) as also tvwRr↓: (K:) or appeared; as also AnvAr↓. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (S, M,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (M, K,) He leaped, or sprang; (M, K;) as also tvwRr↓. (K.) You say, vAr Uilayohi He leaped, or sprang, to, or towards, him, or it. (M.) And vArbihi AlnRaAsu The people leaped, or sprang, upon him. (S.) And vAr UilaI AlXRarRi He rose, or hastened, to do evil, or mischief. (Msb.) ― -b6- vAr AlmaMCu The water flowed forth with force; gushed forth. (TA.) ― -b7- vAr bihi AldRamu, (TA,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (K,) (tropical:) The blood appeared in him; as also tvwRr↓. (K, * TA.) And vAr AldRamu fiI wajohahi (tropical:) The blood appeared in [or mantled in or mounted into] his face; as also AnvAr↓. (M.) ― -b8- vArt bihi AlHaSobapu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. vaworN and vuWuwrN and vawaArN [or vuwaArN?] and vawaraAnN, (M,) (tropical:) The measles spread [or broke out] in him: (M:) and in like manner one says of anything that appears: (M:) one says, vAr, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, meaning (assumed tropical:) it appeared. (T.) And accord. to Lh, one says, vAr AlrRajulu, inf. n. vawaraAnN, meaning (tropical:) The man had the measles appearing in him. (M.) ― -b9- vAr biAlmaHomuwmi AlvRaworu (tropical:) Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, appeared in the fevered man. (A.) ― -b10- vArt AlHumRaI (assumed tropical:) [The fever rose, or became excited]. (TA from a trad.) ― -b11- vArt nafosuhu (tropical:) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. jaXaOatN, (T, S,) i. e. AirotafaEato; (T;) or jaAXato, (TA,) i. e. faAratN. (T.) ― -b12- vAr AlgaDabu, (Msb,) inf. n. vaworN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) [Anger became roused, or excited, or inflamed: or became roused, or excited in the utmost degree: or boiled: or spread: (see vaAYrN, below:) or] became sharp. (M, Msb.) ― -b13- vArt bayonahumo fitonapN waXarRN (A, Msb *) (tropical:) Discord, or dissension, or the like, and evil, or mischief, became excited among them, or between them. (Msb.)

2 vawRara
2: see 4, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, vwRr AlOamora, inf. n. tavowiyrN, (assumed tropical:) He searched, or sought, for, or after, the thing, or affair; inquired, or sought information, respecting it; searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it. (M.) And vwRr AlquroMna (assumed tropical:) He searched after a knowledge of the Kur-án, (S, K,) or its meanings: (M:) or he read it, and inquired of, or examined, diligently, those skilled in it, respecting its interpretation and meanings: (Sh:) or he scrutinized it, and meditated upon its meanings, and its interpretation, and the reading of it. (TA.)

3 vAwrhu vAwrh vAwrp
3. vAwrhu, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. muvaAwarapN (S, M, K) and viwaArN, (Lh, M, K,) He leaped, or sprang, upon him, or at him; he assaulted, or assailed, him; syn. waAvabahu, (T, S, M, A, K,) and saAwarahu. (T, A.)

4 AvArhu OvAr OvArh OvArp Ovr UvArp AvArh AvArp MvArh
4. AvArhu, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and Oavarahu, and havarahu, (K,) [but in the M, I find Oavarotuhu and havarotuhu, (in the latter of which the h is substituted for the O of the former, as in haraAqa for OaraAqa,) and it is evident that the author of the K erroneously supposed them to be from Oavara and havara, whereas they are from OavaAra and havaAra, and are originally Oavowarutuhu and havowarotuhu, but, for Oavarahu, SM appears to have read Mvarahu, for he says that it is formed by transposition,] inf. n. UivaArapN and UivaArN; (Lh, M;) and vwRrhu↓; (M, K;) and AstvArhu↓; (T, M, A, K;) He raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked, him or it; (S, M, A, Mgh, K;) [as, for instance,] an object of the chase or the like, (T, M, A,) a beast of prey, (T,) a lion, (M, A,) (assumed tropical:) dust, (M, Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) smoke, and any other thing: (M:) or he drew it forth: (M:) AstvArhu↓ is [often used in this last sense, or as meaning he disinterred it, exhumed it, or dug it up or out,] said of a thing buried. (K in art. swE.) You say, AvAr fulaAnFA He roused such a one for an affair. (T.) And AvAr AlbaEiyra He roused the camel lying upon his breast, or put him in motion or action. (T.) And Albaroka vwRr↓, and AstvArhA↓, He roused the camels lying upon their breasts, and made them to rise. (S.) ― -b2- AvAr AltRuraAba biqawaAYimihi He [a beast] scraped up the earth, or dust, with his legs. (T, M.) ― -b3- AvAr AlOaroDa, (M, Mgh, Msb,) and OavowarahaA, (M,) He tilled the ground, or land; cultivated it by ploughing and sowing: (Mgh, Msb:) he turned the ground over upon the grain after it had been once opened: (M, TA:) he ploughed and sowed the land, and educed its increase, and the increase of its seed. (TA.) And OavaArati AlOaroDa [She (a cow) tilled the ground]. (TA.) ― -b4- AvAr Alfitonapa (tropical:) He (an enemy) excited discord, or dissension, or the like. (Msb.) And Ealayohimu AlXRarRa vwRr↓ (inf. n. tavowiyrN, Msb) (tropical:) He excited evil, or mischief, against them, (T, S, A, * Msb, *) and manifested it. (S.)

5 tavawRara
5: see 1, in seven places.

7 Uinovawara
7: see 1, in two places.

10 Uisotavowara
10: see 4, in three places.

vaArN vAr
vaArN: see vaOorN.

vaworN vwr
vaworN A bull: (S, M, Msb, K:) and vaworapN↓ a cow: (S, M, Msb:) pl. [of pauc] OavowaArN (M, Msb, K) and viyorapN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] viyraAnN and viyarapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and viwarapN (S, M, K) and viyaArN (M, K) and viyaArapN; (M, TA:) Sb says of the pl. viyarapN that w in it is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, though this is not accordant to general rule: (S:) accord. to Mbr, they said viyarapN to distinguish it from the viwarap of OaqT, and that it was originally of the measure fiEolapN: (S, M: * *) accord. to Aboo-'Alee, it is a contraction of viyaArapN. (M.) [Hence,] AlvRaworu (tropical:) [The constellation Taurus;] one of the signs of the Zodiac. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A lord, master, or chief, (M, A, K,) of a people. (A.) 'Othmán is called, in a trad., AlvRaworu AlOaboyaDu; the epithet AlAbyD being added because he was hoary; or it may denote celebrity. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (T, K:) a stupid, dull man, of little understanding. (T.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Possessed by a devil, or insane, or mad; syn. majonuwnN; so in copies of the K; but in some copies, [and in the CK,] junuwn [diabolical possession, or insanity, or madness]. (TA; and thus in Har p. 415.) ＝ -A2- A piece, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) or large piece, (M, K,) of OaqiT, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e. milk which [has been churned and cooked and then left until it] has become congealed and hard like stone: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] viwarapN (T, S, M, K) and OavowaArN. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- The green substance that overspreads stale water; (T, M, K;) this is called vaworu AlmaMCi; (S, Msb;) syn. TuHolubN, (AZ, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and EaromaDN, and galofaqN; (M;) and the like thereof: (T, M:) and small rubbish, or broken particles of things, (Msb, TA,) or anything, (K,) upon the surface of water, (Msb, K, TA,) which the pastor beats to make the water clear for the bulls or cows. (Msb.) Accord. to some, it has the first of these meanings in the following verse of Anas Ibn-Mudrik El-Khath'amee:
UinRiI waqatoliI sulayokFA vumRa OaEoqiluhu
kaAlvRawori yuDorabu lamRaA EaAfati Albaqaru
[Verily I, with respect to my slaying Suleyk and then paying the price of his blood, am like the green substance upon the surface of stale water, that is beaten when the cows loathe the water]: but accord. to others, by Alvwr the poet means the bull; for the cows follow him: (M, TA:) the cows are not beaten, because they have milk; but the bull is beaten that they may be frightened and therefore drink. (S.) [See a slightly-different reading, and remarks thereon, in Ham p. 416: and see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 330. The latter hemistich is used as a prov., applied to him who is punished for the offence of another.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, in a person who is fevered. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The redness shining, (naAYirapN, K,) or spreading and rising, (vaAYirapN, M,) in the faint light that is seen above the horizon between sunset and nightfall: (M, K:) or vaworu AlXRafaqi the spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset. (S, A, Mgh.) You say, saqaTa vaworu AlXRafaqi [The spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset sank down, or set]. (S, A.) With its suquwT commences the time of the prayer of nightfall. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The whiteness in the lower part of the nail (M, K) of a man. (M, TA.)

viyrN vyr
viyrN A covering of [or film over] the eye. (K.) One says, EalaI Eayonhi viyrN Upon his eye is a covering [or film]. (TK.)

vaworapN vwr vwrh vwrp
vaworapN: see vaworN. ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) An excitement: so in the saying, AinotaZiro HatRaI tasokuna hecihi AlvRaworapu [Wait thou until this excitement become stilled]. (S.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) Many; a great number; much; or a large quantity; of men; (T, M, K;) and of wealth, or of camels or the like; (T, K;) like varowapN: (T, M:) or not of wealth; for of this one says vrwp only. (M.)

vawRaArapN vAYr vwArh vwArp
vawRaArapN The [part of the body called the] xaworaAn [q. v.]. (K.)

dabFI vaAYirN c
dabFI vaAYirN [Locusts before they have wings] just coming forth from the dust, or earth. (T, S.) ― -b2- vaAYiru AlrRaOosi (tropical:) Having the hair of his head spreading out in disorder, and standing up: (As, T, * S, * TA:) or shaggy, or dishevelled. (T, A.) ― -b3- raOayotuhu vaAYirFAfariySu raqabatihi (tropical:) [I saw him with his external jugular veins, or with the sinews and veins of his neck, swelling by reason of anger]. (A.) ― -b4- vaAYirN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Angry. (T.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Anger: (S, A, K:) [or an ebullition of anger, rage, or passion: whence the phrase,] vaAra vaAYiruhu, (T, S, M, A,) like faAra faAYiruhu, (T, A,) (tropical:) He was angry: (T:) or his anger became roused, or excited, (S, M,) or inflamed: (A:) or became roused, or excited, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or boiled: (S in art. fwr:) or spread. (TA in that art.)

OaroDN muvaArapN c
OaroDN muvaArapN Land ploughed up. (T.)

OaroDN mavowarapN c
OaroDN mavowarapN A land abounding with bulls [and cows]. (Th, M, K.)

muviyrapN mvyr mvyrh mvyrp
muviyrapN A cow that tills the ground; (Mgh, K;) and in like manner applied to bulls (vyarapN). (T.)

1 vaAla vAl
