1. vaAla, (T, Sgh, K,) aor. yavuwlu, inf. n. vawolN, (T,) He (a man, T) was, or became, stupid, foolish, or disordered in his intellect: (K:) or he was, or became, affected with incipient madness or demoniacal possession, not such as had become confirmed. (T, Sgh, K.) You say to a man, when you order him to be stupid and ignorant, vulo vulo. (IAar, Th, T.) ― -b2- And vawila, (T, M, Msb, K,) aor. yavowalu, (T,) inf. n. vawalN, (T, M,) He (a man, and any animal,) was, or became, affected with confirmed madness or demoniacal possession: (T:) he (a sheep or goat) was, or became, affected with what is termed vawalN, explained below; (M, Msb, K;) as also, accord. to Sb, Avwl↓; (so in the TT, as from the M;) or AivowalRa↓, inf. n. AivowilaAlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- vAl AlwiEaMCa, (Sgh, K,) aor. yavuwlu, inf. n. vawolN, (TA,) He poured forth what was in the receptacle. (Sgh, K.)

4 Oavowala
4: see 1.

5 tvwRlt AlnRaHolu tvwlt AlnHl
5. tvwRlt AlnRaHolu The bees collected themselves together, and became dense. (M, K.) See also 7. ― -b2- tvwRl Ealayohi He, (a man, TA,) or they, (a company of men, S, M,) assailed him, or overcame him, with reviling (S, M, K) and beating (S, M) and oppressive conduct; (M, K;) as also AnvAl↓. (M.)

7 AnvAl OnvAl AnvAl QnvAl
7. AnvAl It poured forth: (K:) or it poured forth at once. (Msb.) AnvAl Ealayohi AltRuraAbu The dust, or earth, poured forth upon him. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnvAl Ealayohi AlnRaAsu mino kulRi wajohK The people poured forth upon him, or against him, from every quarter: (S, TA:) or collected themselves together against him: (Msb:) [for] AnvAlwA also signifies they collected themselves together; and so tvwRlwA↓. (TA. [See also 7 in art. vl.]) ― -b3- See also 5. ― -b4- AnvAl Ealayohi Alqawolu (assumed tropical:) Speech suggested itself to him uninterruptedly and abundantly, so that he knew not with what to begin. (M, K.)

9 UivowalRa
9: see 1.

vawolN vwl
vawolN A number, or collection, or swarm, of bees: (As, T, S, M, K:) or simply bees: (IAar, Th, T:) a word having no proper sing.; (As, T, S, M, K;) and of the fem. gender: (M:) or the male bee; (M, K;) thus Lth explains it; but the right explanation is the first, that of As. (T.) ― -b2- And A company of men. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b3- Also The kind of trees called HamoD. (M, K.)

vuwlN vwl
vuwlN a dial. var. of viylN, meaning The sheath of the penis of the camel. (Nh, TA.)

vawalN vwl
vawalN Madness, or demoniacal possession: (IAar, Th, T:) or madness, (S,) or an affection like madness, (Lth, T, M, K,) [i. e.] a certain disease resembling madness, (Msb,) that befalls a sheep or goat, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, * K,) in consequence of which the animal will not follow the other sheep or goats, but turns, or goes, round in his place of pasturage: (S, M, K:) or a laxness in the limbs of a sheep or goat; (M, K;) a certain disease that attacks a sheep or goat, occasioning a laxness in the limbs. (IF, Msb.)

vuwluwlN vwlwl
vuwluwlN: see vuWoluwlN, in art. vOl.

vuwiylp vwylh vwylp
vuwiylp A company, or an assemblage, of men come from detached, or scattered, houses or tents; (S, K; * [in Har p. 261, written vuwayolp; but in the TA, said to be like safiynapN, as written in the S and K;]) and of boys, or children; and of camels or the like (mAl): mentioned by Yaakoob, on the authority of Aboo-Sá'id. (S.) ― -b2- Also A place in which fresh herbage is, or becomes, collected together. (Th, M, K.)

vawRaAlapN vwAlh vwAlp
vawRaAlapN A swarm, or large number, of locusts; (As, T, M, K;) a subst., like jabRaAnapN (M, K) and jamRaAlapN: (M:) or an assemblage of locusts, and of men. (IAar, Th, T.)

Oavowalu c
Oavowalu Mad, or possessed: and stupid, foolish, or disordered in intellect: (M, K:) and, applied to a ram (M, Msb) or he-goat, (S, Msb,) affected by what is termed vawal, explained above; fem.

vawolaMCu vwlMC
vawolaMCu, applied to a ewe (S, M, Msb) or she-goat; (S, Msb;) or this, applied to a ewe or she-goat &c., signifies mad: (Mgh:) pl. vuwlN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also Slow in aiding, or in aiding against an enemy: and slow in doing good, and in acting: and slow in running: pl. as above. (K.) And OavaAwlapN↓, applied to old men, Slow (K, TA) in doing good, or in acting, or in running. (TA.)

OavaAwilapN c
OavaAwilapN: see what next precedes.

vuwmN vwm
vuwmN [Garlic; the allium sativum of Linn.;] a kind of baqol, (AHn, M,) well known, (S,) abundant in the country of the Arabs; (AHn, M;) of two sorts; wild, (AHn, M, K,) and growing in the cultivated tracts, (AHn, M,) or in gardens: (K:) the former sort is called vuwmu AlHayRapi, and is the stronger, (K,) and is brought from Syria: (TA:) each of them is heating, expels flatulence and worms, and is strongly diuretic; and this is the most excellent [property] that is therein: it is good for obliviousness, and asthma, and chronic cough, and [pain in] the spleen and the flank, and colic, and sciatica, &c.: (K: [in which are added many other supposed uses:]) n. un. with p. (AHn, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (M,) vuwmapN signifies also (tropical:) The pommel of a sword. (S, M, K.) Whence, OumRu vuwomapa, said to be the name of a certain woman, may mean (tropical:) A sword. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] vuwomapu cakari rajulK (assumed tropical:) [The glans of a man's penis]. (Az, in TA voce TurovuwvN.) ― -b4- AlvRuwmapu also signifies The channel [or oblong depression] between the two mustaches, against the partition between the two nostrils; (IAar, TA;) i. q. AlxunoEubapu, &c. (TA in art. xnEb.) ＝ -A2- vuwmN is also a dial. var. of fuwmN, meaning Wheat. (Lh, T, M.) And the latter is used in the [ordinary] sense of the former. (T.)

1 vawaI vwI vwp vwy
1. vawaI (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) biAlmakaAni, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and fiyhi, (Msb,) and vawaI AlmakaAna, (S, * M, Msb, K,) aor.
vawiIa
, (T, S, Msb,
K,) inf. n. vawaMCu (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and vuwiIRN (S, M, Mgh, K) and mavowFI; (T, M;) and AvwI↓ (T, S, M, Msb, K) bAlmkAn, (S, M, K,) or fyh; (so in the CK;) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) in the place: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, long (Lth, T, M, K) therein: (M, K:) or he alighted, or alighted and abode, in the place: (K:) or vawaI signifies also he alighted, or alighted and abode, (M,) or he settled, (TA,) bAlmkAn in the place. (M.) Hence, UinRaA nuTiylu AlvRuwiIRa fiI dRAri AlHarobi [Verily we prolong the stay in the seat of war]. (Mgh.) [You say also, vaway UilaI AlmaroOapi He betook himself to the woman to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, with her: see vawiyRapN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] vawaI, (T, M, IB, TA,) aor.
vawiIa
; in the K, incorrectly, vwRI↓, inf. n. tavowiyapN; (TA;) signifies also He was slain, (T, M,) and remained where he was: (M:) or he remained in his grave: (IB, TA:) or, as the latter verb is explained in the K, he died. (TA.) [See a verse cited in art. Hsb, conj. 2.] ＝ -A2- vuwiIa He was buried: (M, K:) because there is no longer dwelling than that of him who is buried. (M.)

2: see 4: ＝ -A2- and see also 1.

4 AvwI OvwI Ovwy AvwI Avwy vwI vwy
4. AvwI: see 1. ＝ -A2- AvwAhu He made him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide; (S, Msb, K;) or to remain, &c., long; (M, K;) in a place; (M, K;) and vwRAhu↓, (Kr, S, M, K,) inf. n. tavowiyapN, (S,) signifies the same. (Kr, S, M, K.) [In the CK, vawayotuhu is erroneously put for vawRayotuhu.] ― -b2- And He lodged him; made him his guest; or entertained him as a guest. (M, K.) You say, OanozalaniI faOavowaAniI vawaMCF HasanFA [He lodged me, and entertained me well as a guest]. (T.)

5 tvwRAhu tvwAh tvwAp
5. tvwRAhu He became his guest. (TA.)

vaMCN vMC
vaMCN [mentioned in this art. in the K, as “ A certain letter of the alphabet, ” namely, v]: see art. vwO: ISd holds its A to be originally w. (TA.)

vaAIN vAI vAy
vaAIN: see what next follows.

vaAwapN vAwh vAwp
vaAwapN: see what next follows.

vaAyapN vAyh vAyp
vaAyapN, (S, M, K,) without C, (S,) formed by permutation from vwyp, though the author of the Kitáb [i. e. Sb] holds the A to be originally I, (M,) The lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of camels, (ISk, S, M, K,) and of sheep or goats, (ISk, S,) when they have gone away to a distance in the pasture, or around the tents or houses; (ISk, S, M, K;) as also vawiyRapN↓ and vaAwapN↓: (K:) or the first and second, (AZ, T, S, M,) and the third also, (M,) signify the lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of sheep or goats, (AZ, T, S, M,) and of oxen, or bulls and cows; (M;) and the last is app. formed by permutation from the first. (M.) ― -b2- Also A combination of two or three trees, upon which is thrown a piece of cloth, used for shade, or shelter from the sun. (IAar, M. [And in like manner vaOoyapN is explained in the T, in art. vOI.]) ― -b3- Also, (AZ, T, S, M,) and vawiyRapN↓, (M,) Stones elevated for a sign of the way to direct the pastor when he returns by night: (AZ, T, S, M:) and the former, or latter, (M,) or both, and vuwRapN↓, (K,) with damm, (TA, [in the CK vawRap,]) the lowest sign of the way, of the height of a man in a sitting posture. (M, K.) ― -b4- Also The part which is the place of stabbing of a slaughtered camel. (TA.) ― -b5- The pl. of vAyp is vaAIN↓: (Lh, M:) [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.]

vuwRapN vwh vwp
vuwRapN: see art. vw: and see vaAyapN in the present art., above.

vawiIRN vwI vwp vwy
vawiIRN A guest: (IAar, T, S, M, K:) the vulgar erroneously pronounce it tiwiIRN. (TA. [See also mavowFI.]) ― -b2- Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding; as also tawiIRN; but the former is better known in this sense. (M in art. twI.) ― -b3- One who abides (mujaAwirN [generally meaning for the purpose of study]) in either of the two sacred cities or territories [of Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh]. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b4- One who is very patient in military and predatory expeditions, who is detained in the territory of the enemy, or on the frontier of the enemies' country. (IAar, T.) ― -b5- A captive. (Th, M, K.) ＝ -A2- A chamber, or house, or tent, prepared for a guest: (T, M, K:) and, (M,) accord. to Lth, (T,) a chamber within a chamber. (T, M.)

vuwiIRN vwI vwp vwy
vuwiIRN: see art. vw. ＝ -A2- Also an inf. n. of 1. (S &c.)

vawiyRapN vwy vwyh vwyp
vawiyRapN: see vaAyapN, above, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A woman (K, TA) to whom one betakes himself to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, with her (yuvowaI UilayohaA). (TA.)

vaAwK vAw
vaAwK part. n. of 1; (Msb;) [Remaining, &c.: or remaining, &c., long:] a stranger remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a country, or town: (T:) or vaAwiI balodapK a stranger who keeps to a country, or town. (M.) ― -b2- A man remaining in his grave. (IB, TA.)

vaAwiIRu vAwI vAwy
vaAwiIRu: see vaAYiIRN, in art. vwO. You say qaAfiyapN vaAwiyRapN [in the CK, erroneously, vAwiyapN] A rhyme of which the characteristic is v. (K, * TA.)

mavowFI 2
mavowFI A place where one remains, stays, dwells, or abides; (T;) a place of alighting or abode, an abode, or a dwelling, (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) of a man: (T:) pl. mavaAwK (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) Hence, Oabuw AlmavowaI The master (M, K) of the house or tent, (M,) or of the place where one alights or abides, or of the abode or dwelling. (K.) And OumRu AlmavowaI The mistress of the house or tent. (M.) And Oabuw mavowaI AlrRajuli The master of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (S:) the host who entertains the man; to whom he betakes himself for lodging, and at whose abode he stays: (Har p. 595:) and the guest whom the man entertains. (M, K. * [See also vawiIRN.]) And OumRu mavowaI AlrRajuli The mistress of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (S:) the mistress of the man's place of alighting, or abode, in which he passes the night; occurring in this sense in a trad., not meaning his wife. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. of vawaI. (T, M.)

2. vayRayotu vaMCN HasanapF HasanFA [I made, or wrote, a beautiful v]. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

viyRapN mvwI mvwy
viyRapN The lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of sheep or goats [when they have gone away to a distance in the pasture, or around the tents or houses]; (IB, K;) a dial. var. of vaAyapN [q. v. in art. vwI]. (IB, TA.)

vayawiIRN: see vaAYiIRN, in art. vwO.

vayotalN: see art. vtl.

1. vaAxa, aor. yaviyxu: see art. vwx.

vayolN vyl
vayolN: see what next follows.

viylN vyl
viylN The sheath of the penis of a camel (Lth, * AZ, T, S, M, K) &c.; (K;) [i. e.,] of a he-goat also, and of a bull: (M:) or the penis itself: (Lth, T, M, K:) sometimes also used in relation to a man: (M:) and vayolN↓ signifies the same; (K;) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád; and IAth adds vuwlN. (TA.) Hence the prov., Oaxolafu mino viyli Aljamali [More contrary to what is usual than the sheath of the penis, or than the penis, of the camel]: for the camel, like the lion, is a retromingent. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A kind of plant; (S, K;) as also vayRilN↓: (K:) a certain plant having a root and stem; when short, called najomN: and a certain herb, or, as some say, a plant, that is found on the banks, or sides, of rivers, in meadows: and, some say, a species of the [plants, or trees, called] janobap, which grows in the territory of [the tribe of] Temeem, and becomes large, so that the sheep, or goats, lie in its shelter: (M:) AHn says, (M,) in the “ Book of Plants, ” (Mgh,) the viyl, (M,) or vayRil↓, (Mgh,) [both appellations now applied to triticum repens, or dog's grass,] is the najomap; called in Persian ryzwPAdlh [?]; (Mgh;) its leaves are like those of wheat, but shorter, and it spreads upon the face of the ground, extending far, and becoming com-
plicated, or tangled, so as to be like felt (M, Mgh) upon the ground; (M;) it has many joints, or knots, and short internodal portions; and scarcely, or never, grows anywhere but over water, or in a place beneath which is water; (M, Mgh;) and it is one of the plants that are regarded as indicative of the existence of water: n. un. with p: (M:) Lth says that the viyl is a certain plant that tangles upon the ground: Th, on the authority of IAar, says that it is a kind of plant said to be that called liHoyapu AltRayosi: and Sh says that the viylap is a green small tree [or plant] resembling the first shoots that come forth from grain. (T.)

vayRilN vyl
vayRilN: see viylN, in two places.

Oavoyalu c
Oavoyalu A camel large in the viyl; (T, S, M, K;) wide therein: (M:) pl. viylN. (K.)

maviylap mvyl mvylh mvylp
maviylap A place in which is the kind of plant called viyl. (Mgh.)
